[1]http://emf.torolab.ibm.com/modeling/emf/downloads/index.php?showAll=1&hlbuild=N200711020028&sortBy=date&project=emf#N200711020028 [2]http://emf.torolab.ibm.com/modeling/emf/downloads/index.php?showAll=1&hlbuild=I200710311431&sortBy=date&project=emf#I200710311431  Full build logs are linked above. Below are some screenshots.

title: Export of plugin project fails, with space in path
desc: I20071120-1300  This seems to be a recent regression. It does not seem to happen if I reuse a workspace from which I have previously been able to export successfully. I'm marking this as critical because it needs to be fixed before the end of this milestone.  1. Launch Eclipse and when selecting a workspace use a name not in use so a new workspace gets created.  2. Dismiss the welcome screen.  3. Create a new plugin project "a.b.c" using the hello world template. Leave the checkbox checked to switch to the PDE perspective.  4. Right click on a.b.c, export. Select Deployable Plugins and Fragments  5. Select a destingation directory and hit finish in the export wizard  Expected result: completes without error Actual result:    Problems during export   Buildfile: C:\Documents and Settings\CGOLD\workspace1120A\.metadata\.plugins\org.eclipse.pde.core\temp\org.eclipse.pde.container.feature\build.xml does not exist   Buildfile: C:\Documents and Settings\CGOLD\workspace1120A\.metadata\.plugins\org.eclipse.pde.core\temp\org.eclipse.pde.container.feature\build.xml does not exist   Buildfile: C:\Documents and Settings\CGOLD\workspace1120A\.metadata\.plugins\org.eclipse.pde.core\temp\org.eclipse.pde.container.feature\build.xml does not exist   Buildfile: C:\Documents and Settings\CGOLD\workspace1120A\.metadata\.plugins\org.eclipse.pde.core\temp\org.eclipse.pde.container.feature\build.xml does not exist

title: archivesFormat does not work with groupConfigurations=true
desc: Created attachment 84189 [details] patch to BuildScriptGenerator  Build ID:  M20071023-1652  Steps To Reproduce: 1. In the build.properties, set configs to something besides *.*.* 2. Set groupConfigurations=true 3. Set archivesFormat to be folder for each of the configurations.  When you build, the archive will be a zip instead of a folder.   More information:  I debugged into it and found that the reason it doesn't work is because the configuration passed into BuildScriptGenerator.realSetArchivesFormat() is always (group, group, group), which doesn't match any of my real configs.    So, I tried setting the archiveFormat to group,group,group.  This didn't work either because it checks to see if it's a valid config before adding it to the archivesFormat table.  Then I tried adding group,group,group as a config as well but I got a message saying something about duplicate root_files.  Finally, I made a patch allowing an archiveFormat of group,group,group if groupConfigurations is true.  That works fine, though I don't know if that's the approach you'd like to take.  If you use the patch, you need to be sure to add a comment in the build.properties about needing to specify group,group,group as an archivesFormat if groupConfigurations=true.

title: Applications fetchScript and buildScript should be removed
desc: build F3  There are currently 2 ways of building a plugin using Eclipse headless:  running applications or Ant tasks provided by PDE Build. Note: Releng only  uses the Ant tasks.  Testing the applications today (after a long time without testing) we found  out that a parameter (-install) conflicts with a parameter provided by the  install/updated mechanism. Even using -noupdate we can't avoid the conflict -  what makes the applications useless. Seems that they have been broken for a  while and we did not get any bug reports about it - what makes us believe no  one is using them.  We propose removing them in favour of the Ant tasks (that have been tested and  are the ones used in our builds). Besides not being tested, another  disadvantage of using the applications is that for every step of the build  (fetch, generate scripts and run scripts) Eclipse is startup and shutdown.  When using the Ant tasks in a main script the startup and shutdown only  happens once.

title: Provide property to specify additional source roots
desc: In individual source bundles we want the source roots listed in the manifest, we should provide a property to add additional source roots for source being added through custom steps.

title: Compiler warnings in N20071201-0010
desc: 1. WARNING in /src/org/eclipse/pde/internal/build/builder/ClasspathComputer2_1.java  (at line 167) path = generator.replaceVariables(path, pluginId == null ? false : generator.getCompiledElements().contains(pluginId)); The static method replaceVariables(String, boolean) from the type ModelBuildScriptGenerator should be accessed in a static way  /src/org/eclipse/pde/internal/build/builder/ClasspathComputer3_0.java  (at line 304) path = generator.replaceVariables(path, pluginId == null ? false : generator.getCompiledElements().contains(pluginId)); The static method replaceVariables(String, boolean) from the type ModelBuildScriptGenerator should be accessed in a static way  In both cases, generator. should be replaced with ModelBuildScriptGenerator., since the method is static.

title: Headless build crashes with Windows UNC paths
desc: Build ID: M20071023-1652  Steps To Reproduce: 1. Take any working build in the form "java -jar c:\path\to\eclipse\plugins\org.eclipse.equinox.launcher_1.0.1.R33x_v20070828.jar -application org.eclipse.ant.core.antRunner -buildfile c:\path\to\eclipse\plugins\org.eclipse.pde.build_3.3.2.R331_v20071019\scripts\build.xml -Dbuilder=c:\path\to\buildConfiguration -DbaseLocation=c:\path\to\basLocation -DbuildDirectory=c:\path\to\buildDirectory" 2. Move Eclipse to a UNC path 3. Run "java -jar \\server\path\to\eclipse\plugins\org.eclipse.equinox.launcher_1.0.1.R33x_v20070828.jar -application org.eclipse.ant.core.antRunner -buildfile \\server\path\to\eclipse\plugins\org.eclipse.pde.build_3.3.2.R331_v20071019\scripts\build.xml -Dbuilder=c:\path\to\buildConfiguration -DbaseLocation=c:\path\to\basLocation -DbuildDirectory=c:\path\to\buildDirectory" 4. The build dies silently  More information: Adding -debug shows that the Equinox launcher builds incorrect URLs, because it uses the deprecated method File.toURL() which should be replaced by File.toURI().toURL(), but fixing that does not solve the problem.

title: Sort plugins across feature boundaries
desc: The compile order for a set of plugins is based on pre-requisite order determined by the resolver.  This is done only for plugins within a given feature.  Features are compiled in the order they are included.  More advanced build features (cycles, incremental building) will require that all plugins are sorted regardless of feature boundaries.  Doing this would require that the patterns calling children build scripts that currently live in the generated feature build script would need to move into a separate "orchestration" script.

title: When qualifier=none is specified, bundles fail to resolve during build
desc: +++ This bug was initially created as a clone of Bug #68066 +++  I have a bundle with Bundle-Version: 3.3.2.qualifier in the manifest and qualifier=none in build.properties. According to the documentation, I would think that the output should be a bundle with version 3.3.2. However, I get exceptions during the build:  [eclipse.buildScript] org.osgi.framework.BundleException: invalid format [eclipse.buildScript] 	at org.eclipse.osgi.internal.resolver.StateBuilder.createBundleDescription(StateBuilder.java:78) [eclipse.buildScript] 	at org.eclipse.osgi.internal.resolver.StateObjectFactoryImpl.createBundleDescription(StateObjectFactoryImpl.java:29) [eclipse.buildScript] 	at org.eclipse.pde.internal.build.site.PDEState.addBundle(PDEState.java:92) ...  (I added a print statement to get that exception printed out)  Closer investigation reveals that OSGi barfs when constructing a BundleDescriptor (in StateBuilder.createBundleDescriptor). When the version string is parsed, new Version(String) throws an IllegalStateException because it finds "3.3.2." as the version (quotes added). The culprit appears to be the following piece of code:  QualifierReplacer.replaceQualifierInVersion: ... 			//			newQualifier = '.' + newQualifier; 		} else if (replaceTag.equalsIgnoreCase(PROPERTY_NONE)) { 			newQualifier = ""; //$NON-NLS-1$ 		} else { ...  As you see, we end up with an empty string qualifier rather than no qualifier at all.  The fix is to strip off the entire qualifier component in this case only.

title: Jar Verification test  fails intermittently
desc: The test for bug 196754 (AssembleTests.testBug196754)is failing intermittently and should be removed from the builds until the problem can be identified and fixed.  java.lang.SecurityException: Either the manfiest file or the signature file has been tampered in this bundle: /Users/sdimitro/buildtest/N20071216-0010/eclipse-testing/test-eclipse/eclipse/pdebuild_folder/org.eclipse.pde.build.tests.builder/196754/tmp/eclipse/plugins/org.eclipse.equinox.launcher.win32.win32.x86_1.0.100.N20071216-0010.jar

title: Error building feature; Cannot find plug-in versions
desc: I have a situation where I am utilizing a third-party plugin (specifically, a  WSAD plugin) which I'll call plugin "A". I wrote a plugin called "B" which uses  one of the extensions from "A". Plugin "A" requires ["org.eclipse.ui"  version="2.1.0" match="equivalent"]. However, I have eclipse 2.1.1 installed in  which "org.eclipse.ui" is at version "2.1.1" and version "2.1.0" does not  exist. Plugin "A" works correctly in my eclipse environment and even my  plugin "B" works using its extension when running the Runtime Environment. The  problem is when I try to build the feature. It spits up a message  saying "Cannot find plug-in: org.eclipse.ui_2.1.0". Shouldn't this be able to  find "org.eclipse.ui_2.1.1" since match="equivalent" was defined?

title: javaCompiler*.args generated just once per session
desc: Build ID: 3.4M4  Steps To Reproduce: 1. Right click on a plugin's plugin.xml file and select PDE Tools => Create Ant Build File  More information: The step above generates a build.xml and javaCompiler.*.args file which is used for classpath and possibly other things. If I then delete build.xml and these javaCompiler.*.args files and try to recreate these using the above step, only build.xml is regenerated. Executing build.xml without the javaCompiler.*.args files present results in build errors.

title: [doc] Property naming in the builder and the packager
desc: Here is the list of the properties used in the builder and the packager with a  brief description.  (xxx) are old name or properties, the new name is given after.   Packager ========  workingDirectory: The directory where all the packaging related files will be  generated, unzipped, ... downloadDirectory: The directory where the files will be downloaded tempDirectory: The directory in which the files will be unzipped, and zipped  from resultDirectory: The directory where all the results of the packager will be  stored (used now)  packagingInfo: The directory in which the file called packager.properties is  located packagingProperties: A relative path to the file containing the properties for  element to package  contentFilter: a comma separated list of value used to filter the files that  are downloaded config: The config for which the packager is running (it is only one config) featureList: A comma separated list of features to package  featurePaths: A comma separated list of paths where features and plugins are  located. An entry must point to one level up above the "features" and "plugins"  directory (example eclipse)  (collBase) zipBase: The directory from which the zip will be built (collPlace) rootZipDirectory: The directory that will be used as a root in the  zip. All the files to be zipped must be under this directory. A typical configuration of those variables is:   zipBase=.   rootZipDirectory=eclipse  zipArgs: Extra arguments that can be passed to the zip command unzipArgs: Extra arguments that can be passed to the unzip command     Builder ======= mapVersionTag: Version of the map files used buildDirectory: The directory in which the build will happen  (collBase) zipBase: The directory from which the zip will be built (collPlace) rootZipDirectory: The directory that will be used as a root in the  zip. All the files to be zipped must be under this directory.  configs: an ampersand separated list of config (each component of a config is  separated by a comma)  bootClasspath: The path to a rt.jar javacFailOnError: The value that will be used as a parameter to the failonerror  property of the javac ant task javacDebugInfo: The value that will be used as a parameter to the debuginfo  property of the javac ant task javacVerbose: The value that will be used as a parameter to the verbose  property of the javac ant task   zipArgs: Extra arguments that can be passed to the zip command unzipArgs: Extra arguments that can be passed to the unzip command  baseLocation: An installation of eclipse to compile against baseOs: The Os of the eclipse installed in baseLocation baseWs: The ws of the eclipse installed in baseLocation baseArch: The arch of the eclipse installed in baseLocation   Eclipse specific vars --------------------- buildLabel: buildId:	also these vars are now used to in some scripts, they should be  replaced by more generic names buildType:  timestamp noMail

title: PDE build creates jars with corrupt signatures / Java Web Start not possible
desc: Build ID: M20071023-1652  Steps To Reproduce: In Eclipse v3.2, it was possible to configure build.properties to sign the resultant jars.  In Eclipse v3.3, this feature results in jar file corruption:  jarsigner: java.lang.SecurityException: Invalid signature file digest for Manifest main attributes  The effect of this is that Java Web Start (which requires signed jars) is completely dead in the water on Eclipse v3.3.  Attempts to manually sign the jars to repair the signatures don't work, there seems no effective workaround for this problem.  More information:

title: For grouped configurations, root files are gathered in arbitrary order
desc: When groupConfigurations=true, the assemble script executes gather.bin.parts in arbitrary order. The effect is that it is impossible to control what root files end up in the archive. For instance, a top-level feature's root files may get overwritten by an included feature's root files. This doesn't seem to be a problem for the Eclipse build as it uses a separate feature for root files, but it would still be nice to have this working.  The problem seems to be in AssembleScriptGenerator.generateMainTarget(): ... if (groupConfigs) { 	Collection allPlugins = new HashSet(); 	Collection allFeatures = new HashSet(); 	Collection features = new HashSet(); 	Collection rootFiles = new HashSet(); 	for (Iterator allConfigs = getConfigInfos().iterator(); allConfigs.hasNext();) { 		Collection[] configInfo = getConfigInfos((Config) allConfigs.next()); 		allPlugins.addAll(configInfo[0]); 		allFeatures.addAll(configInfo[1]); 		features.addAll(configInfo[2]); 		rootFiles.addAll(configInfo[3]); 	} 	basicGenerateAssembleConfigFileTargetCall(new Config("group","group","group") , allPlugins, allFeatures, features, rootFiles); ...  Because HashSet is used to collect features/plugins/root providers from all configs, the relative ordering gets lost. Using LinkedHashSet instead preserves this ordering and results in the correct assemble script.

title: NPE on manifest.getMainAttributes().getValue(key).equals(value))
desc: Build ID: M20070212-1330  Steps To Reproduce: I am unable to build pde using maven-pde-plugin When i try it manually i found a bug inside of ManifestModifier class private void changeValue(String key, String value) { 		if (manifest.getMainAttributes().getValue(key).equals(value)) 			return; 		contentChanged = true; 		manifest.getMainAttributes().put(new Attributes.Name(key), value); 	}  Suppose you have manifest:  Manifest-Version: 1.0 Class-Path:  then it fail on npe at code manifest.getMainAttributes().getValue(key) - which returns  NULL and therefore is not populated manifest generated by pde build.  Later i have also problem to export plugin by UI wizard directly in eclipse.   BTW: why if you debug pde launch using AntRunner application you add -pdelaunch which cause not to proceced well buildfile target params?    More information:

title: Support compiling against orbit style non-binary bundles
desc: Orbit bundles are typically checked into cvs with .class files and their build.properties files just contain a bin.includes property.  If the orbit bundles are included in their non-binary format, then the generated classpath for bundles depending on them incorrectly contains /@dot.  In this case the .class were pre-existing at the root of the bundle.  The proposal is, when compiling against bundles that have a '.' on the Bundle-Classpath but don't have a corresponding source.. property then instead of generating a ".../bundle/@dot" entry, we should generate a ".../bundle/" entry instead.

title: Default setting for PDE build should be 3.0
desc: The out of the box settings for pde build are still targetting 2.1. This is ok when used from PDE UI, by when used in releng mode, people have to set -DbuildingOsgi=true.

title: qualifier is not replaced in the plugin.xml for the NONE case
PDE should support building against nested JARs
desc: For some reason that I do not understand, the fact that Mylar exports several apache packages creates compile errors in my plugins (can't resolve org.apache) when Mylar is installed.  To see the problem, import this team project set: https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/attachment.cgi?id=50181  The PDE reports no errors for the manifests, but the classes that import anything org.apache give compile errors. If I run "Validate Plugin Set" in the launch configuration's dialog, it is ok, but the launch fails due to the same compilation errors.

title: [build] Nested Features
desc: There has been interest expressed in having nested features. Dean please comment.

title: Adding pre / post steps
desc: In the new build mechanism,  only a limited number of pre and post steps are  provided. Those steps should be generalized to all the steps of the build  process.

title: Use the new Eclipse-BundleShape header
desc: See bug 157562.  PDE-Build should use the Eclispe-BundleShape header when it is available to avoid the guessing game for directory vs jar'ed bundles.

title: [doc] improve version qualifier documentation
desc: Build ID: I20071213-1700  Steps To Reproduce: 1. create a feature project such as com.abc.test, using version: 1.0.0.qualifier 2. add in the build.properties   forceContextQualifier=200801101234 3. export the project as a deployable features 4. the exported feature's file has a name with a build timestamp instead of expected 20081101234.  More information:

title: [installer] Wrong config.ini for installer on Linux
desc: The config.ini file for the p2 installer download on Linux has the win32 SWT fragment listed. Presumably the Mac installer has the same problem.  Andrew N, can you confirm again that the correct answer is to list all SWT fragments in my config.ini?

title: PDE can't resolve / build projects anymore
desc: I can't compile my workspace anymore with I20210204-2320, I have lot of PDE can't resolve bundle XYZ errors and I see multiple errors in the log like  Java Model Exception: Java Model Status [org.eclipse.pde does not exist] 	at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.core.JavaElement.newNotPresentException(JavaElement.java:573) 	at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.core.JavaModelManager.getPerProjectInfoCheckExistence(JavaModelManager.java:2525) 	at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.core.JavaProject.getPerProjectInfo(JavaProject.java:2382) 	at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.core.JavaProject.getRawClasspath(JavaProject.java:2411) 	at org.eclipse.jdt.launching.JavaRuntime.getVMInstall(JavaRuntime.java:418) 	at org.eclipse.pde.internal.core.MinimalState.loadWorkspaceBundleManifest(MinimalState.java:122) 	at org.eclipse.pde.internal.core.MinimalState.addBundle(MinimalState.java:97) 	at org.eclipse.pde.internal.core.PluginModelManager.addWorkspaceBundleToState(PluginModelManager.java:760) 	at org.eclipse.pde.internal.core.PluginModelManager.initializeTable(PluginModelManager.java:621) 	at org.eclipse.pde.internal.core.PluginModelManager.targetReloaded(PluginModelManager.java:522) 	at org.eclipse.pde.internal.core.RequiredPluginsInitializer.lambda$0(RequiredPluginsInitializer.java:33) 	at org.eclipse.core.runtime.jobs.Job$2.run(Job.java:187) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.jobs.Worker.run(Worker.java:63).  I20210202-1840 works. I suspect this is a regression from bug 569905.  The code in org.eclipse.pde.internal.core.MinimalState.loadWorkspaceBundleManifest(File, IResource) should check if the bundle project is a Java project before trying to get JRE from it.  I believe I have a patch (can't verify because my platform can't compile & debug right now).

title: Product build may not be setting permissions on launcher
desc: The custom build.xml for the executable feature performs a chmod on ${launcherName} to set permissions for the product's executable.  However, by inspection, launcherName is set to the name of the product exe, not the name of the launcher in the executable feature.  The executable will be renamed at a later point in the build.  The result is that this chmod in the build script is probably not doing anything.  As well, I am not sure that the renaming code in the branding iron properly preserves permissions.

title: [Doc] Docs are wrong about root.permissions properties
desc: The docs http://help.eclipse.org/help33/index.jsp?topic=/org.eclipse.pde.doc.user/reference/pde_feature_generating_build.htm  are wrong about the format of the root.permissions and root.link properties when a config is specified.  The actual format, as parsed by Utils.generatePermissions is "root." + configInfix + '.' + permissions + '.' <value> "root." + configInfix + '.' + link

title: Signing does not support keypass
desc: Signing is done using Ant's signjar task. We do not currently specify a keypass, I suspect this is the cause of bug 196755.

title: State should be populated with all EE profiles
desc: Currently PDE build resolves the state using a dictionary per configuration.  Each of these dictionaries specifies the largest EE profile available.  This causes a potential mismatch between the profile used at state resolution time and the actual profile used in the compilation, which can lead to compile errors.  Tom has suggested that we should create N + M dictionaries, N = configurations (os,ws,arch) and M = profiles.  All profiles are then represented in the state and none of the configurations specify a profile.

title: NPE int AntScript.printCopyTask
desc: When processing the "source.*" properties, pde.build filters out entries that don't exist on disk.  This results in a FileSet array with some number of null entries at the end.  This array is then passed to AntScript.printCopyTask which does not handle these null entries and throws an NPE.  A quick scan shows that AntScript.printMoveTask and AntScript.printDeleteTask are also vulnerable to null entries in the fileset array.

title: Export should create category
desc: The metadata generated for an update site does not contain categories. This should be easily fixed by passing to the generator the location of the site.xml. See for example the launch configuration called "p2-izer update site".

title: Repository created from PDE export should be compressed
desc: The repositories created by PDE Build should be compressed (See the -compress option of the generator). Note though that we don't want to change the compression mode of the repositories we exporting into if they were already existing before.

title: eclipse.buildScript cannot resolve dropins/ dependencies
desc: We have a few plugins that we use for internal tests. They are crappy and terribly coded (legacy from more than 5 years). We've been building using a custom Ant script that invokes eclipse.buildScript directly:  <eclipse.buildScript elements="${type}@${id}" buildDirectory="${buildDirectory}" configInfo="${configs}" baseLocation="${baseLocation}" buildingOSGi="${buildingOSGi}" archivesFormat="${archivesFormat}" recursiveGeneration="true" />  Now, with a p2 enabled driver, this is not working, despite having changed the code to extract our plugins correctly into the new dropins folder  Log snippet:  [java] [eclipse.buildScript] Bundle org.eclipse.emf.databinding.edit: [java] [eclipse.buildScript] Missing required plug-in org.eclipse.core.runtime_[3.4.0,4.0.0). [java] [eclipse.buildScript] Missing required plug-in org.eclipse.emf.databinding_[1.0.0,2.0.0). [java] [eclipse.buildScript] Missing required plug-in org.eclipse.emf.edit_[2.4.0,3.0.0). ...  It seems like the eclipse.buildScript task cannot resolve the dependencies of plugins in the dropin folder  Pascal asked that this issue be opened as a bug against both PDE UI and PDE Build.

title: Launcher not executable when archivesFormat is set to tar
desc: Build ID: M20080221-1800  Steps To Reproduce: 1. Create a headless build of an RCP product 2. Specify launcher name in product file 3. Set archivesFormat=linux,gtk,x86 - tar in build.properties  When the tar files is unpacked the launch binary does not have executable permission on Linux.  More information: We've had this problem for a long time with our headless build, but didn't really know where to look. When I tried the example from http://rcpquickstart.wordpress.com/2007/06/06/getting-started-with-pde-build/  it worked when archivesFormat is antZip but not when it's tar. And changing archivesFormat in our build had the same result.

title: .product file format change
desc: <configIni use="default">       <solaris>/rcp/configs/solaris/config.ini</solaris>       <windows>/rcp/configs/win32/config.ini</windows>    </configIni>

title: Source features have invalid discovery sites
desc: Most of our source features have invalid discovery site URLs:  <discovery url="%updateSiteName" label="http://download.eclipse.org/eclipse/updates/3.4"/>  Note the "url" and the "label" are reversed. Don't ask me why, but my theory is that this is caused by a bug in org.eclipse.pde.internal.build.site.compatibility.FeatureParser#processDiscoverySite, which looks like this:  result.addDiscoverySite(attributes.getValue("url"), attributes.getValue("label"));   However, the addDiscoverySite method looks like this:  public void addDiscoverySite(String label, String url) { ... }  Note it is passing the attributes in reverse order. I suspect this causes it to reverse the "url" and "update" attributes from the feature that source is being generated for.

title: per feature individualSourceBundles
desc: We're using 3.4M7 in order to build individual source bundles but the individualSourceBundles property seems to be ignored. We always receive the old form of a single source plugin with a contribution to the org.eclipse.pde.core.source extension point. We'd prefer the new form where the source bundle has no dependency on PDE.  We looked at http://wiki.eclipse.org/PDEBuild/Individual_Source_Bundles#individualSourceBundles but it just doesn't seem to work for us.  Our build.properties of the SDK feature looks like:   bin.includes = feature.xml   individualSourceBundles = true   generate.feature@ch.rtc.jfw.source = ch.rtc.jfw  The SDK feature.xml looks like: <feature       id="com.foo.jfw.sdk"       label="SDK"       version="1.0.0.qualifier"       provider-name="foo.com">     ...     <includes          id="com.foo.jfw"          version="0.0.0"/>     <includes          id="com.foo.jfw.source"          version="0.0.0"/>  </feature>

title: Bad ${baseLocation} value
desc: Build ID: I20080502-0100  Steps To Reproduce: (Using a mac) 1.Create a feature. 2.Add a plug-in that is not in your workspace (e.g. org.eclipse.jdt.core). 3.Export the feature.    More information: Observe the following error information provided during step 3. Notice the ${baseLocation} in the path. These exact steps work on windows.  Problems during export   /Volumes/KINGSTON 1/Code9/workspaces/p2/MacFeatureTest/package.MacFeatureTest.macosx.carbon.x86.xml:80: Warning: Could not find file /Volumes/KINGSTON 1/Code9/workspaces/p2/MacFeatureTest/${baseLocation}/plugins/org.eclipse.jdt.core_3.4.0.v_858.jar to copy.   Warning: Could not find file /Volumes/KINGSTON 1/Code9/workspaces/p2/MacFeatureTest/${baseLocation}/plugins/org.eclipse.jdt.core_3.4.0.v_858.jar to copy.   /Volumes/KINGSTON 1/Code9/workspaces/p2/MacFeatureTest/package.MacFeatureTest.macosx.carbon.x86.xml:80: Warning: Could not find file /Volumes/KINGSTON 1/Code9/workspaces/p2/MacFeatureTest/${baseLocation}/plugins/org.eclipse.jdt.core_3.4.0.v_858.jar to copy.   Warning: Could not find file /Volumes/KINGSTON 1/Code9/workspaces/p2/MacFeatureTest/${baseLocation}/plugins/org.eclipse.jdt.core_3.4.0.v_858.jar to copy.

title: Export plugins fails for Orbit bundles
desc: To recreate: 1)Import the equinox jetty project set from http://www.eclipse.org/equinox/server/downloads/jettyhttp-anon.psf 2)Select org.eclipse.equinox.http.jetty and org.mortbay.jetty and export them as plugins You should see the following error message pop up: "Errors occurred during the operation.  A zip file containing the build logs has been generated..." Inside the logs you will see that the org.eclipse.equinox.http.jetty bundle could not resolve any of the jetty classes.  I have opened this as a bug against PDE build because this operation works perfectly in Eclipse 3.4, but I couldn't find the relevent bug for the fix and I am using 3.3.  One interesting thing I found is that if I compile org.mortbay.jetty against a different Execution Environment (for instance by move J2SE1.4 below the others), then the export completes correctly--despite the fact I have not set up any custom Execution Environments (aka my only installed JDK is sun 1.5) but I don't understand why.

title: "Clean" of freshly checked-out org.eclipse.pde.build project fails
desc: when the workspaceBinaries target is called, an error is thrown because the lib/ folder doesn't exist yet   Buildfile: E:\Workspaces\eclipse_head\org.eclipse.pde.build\localbuild.xml  workspaceBinaries:          [jar] Building jar: E:\Workspaces\eclipse_head\org.eclipse.pde.build\lib\pdebuild-ant.jar  BUILD FAILED E:\Workspaces\eclipse_head\org.eclipse.pde.build\localbuild.xml:27: Problem creating jar: E:\Workspaces\eclipse_head\org.eclipse.pde.build\lib\pdebuild-ant.jar (Le chemin d'accès spécifié est introuvable) (and the archive is probably corrupt but I could not delete it)  Total time: 1 second

title: config.ini generated by headless build not working
desc: Build ID: I20080502-0100 This is using 3.4m7 for the IDE and target platform. When I export our product from the IDE it launches fine but when built from the headless build it does not launch.  There is a difference between the config.ini files generated by the export vs. the headless build.  If we drop the IDE exported config.ini into our version created by the headless build the headless build version works fine.  The difference between the config.ini: Exported from IDE (Working): osgi.bundles=org.eclipse.equinox.common@2:start,org.eclipse.update.configurator@3:start,org.eclipse.core.runtime@start Headless build (Not working): osgi.bundles=org.eclipse.core.runtime@2:start,org.eclipse.update.configurator@3:start  Also if I remove the org.eclipse.update.configurator plugin from our product file the headless build version now works but of course specifies all the bundles.  Could this be related to Bug#229194 ?

title: NPE when exporting product containing a license feature
desc: Created attachment 236615 [details] Test projects  Using Eclipse SDK 4.3.1 and 4.4.0 I20131015-0800  1. Import the attached projects 2. Open the myproduct.product file 3. Export the product  Error dialog comes up with message 'Export product has encountered a problem'  In the error log, the call stack ends with  Caused by: java.lang.NullPointerException 	at java.lang.AbstractStringBuilder.replace(AbstractStringBuilder.java:797) 	at java.lang.StringBuffer.replace(StringBuffer.java:387) 	at org.eclipse.pde.internal.build.tasks.LicenseReplaceTask$Feature.replace(LicenseReplaceTask.java:79) 	at org.eclipse.pde.internal.build.tasks.LicenseReplaceTask.execute(LicenseReplaceTask.java:303) 	at org.apache.tools.ant.UnknownElement.execute(UnknownElement.java:292) 	at sun.reflect.GeneratedMethodAccessor121.invoke(Unknown Source) 	at sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:43) 	at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:606) 	at org.apache.tools.ant.dispatch.DispatchUtils.execute(DispatchUtils.java:106) 	... 60 more

title: headless product build loses product eclipse.ini args on mac
desc: In mac product builds, the product branding is losing the eclipse.ini args coming out of the .product file.  They are getting overwriten by the eclipse.ini in the org.eclipse.equinox.executable feature.  This is causing bug 233159

title: Run-time libraries exported through more than 2 plugins not in classpath
desc: The operation "Create feature JAR" generates build.xml's in plugins directories with missing runtime libraries which are reexported through more than 2 plugins.  EXAMPLE:    samplePluginA  	lib/a.jar (exported)      samplePluginB (depends on samplePluginA, dep. reexported) 	lib/b.jar (exported)      samplePluginC (depends on samplePluginB, dep. reexported)     samplePluginD (depends on samplePluginC, dep. reexported)     sampleFeature (contains plugins A,B,C,D)  The action "Create Feature JAR" generates build.xml in pluginD with the following contents:  	<target name="samplePluginD.jar" depends="init"  unless="samplePluginD.jar"> 		<property name="destdir"  value="${temp.folder}/samplePluginD.jar.bin"/> 		<delete dir="${temp.folder}/samplePluginD.jar.bin"/> 		<mkdir dir="${temp.folder}/samplePluginD.jar.bin"/> 		<!-- compile the source code --> 		<javac destdir="${temp.folder}/samplePluginD.jar.bin"  failonerror="false" verbose="true" debug="on" includeAntRuntime="no"  bootclasspath="${bootclasspath}"  classpath="../samplePluginC/samplePluginC.jar;../samplePluginB/lib/b.jar;../../p lugins/org.eclipse.core.runtime_2.0.0/bin;../samplePluginB/bin;../samplePluginC/ bin;../../plugins/org.eclipse.core.boot_2.0.0/bin;../../plugins/org.eclipse.core .runtime_2.0.0/runtime.jar;../../plugins/org.eclipse.core.boot_2.0.0/boot.jar;.. /samplePluginB/samplePluginB.jar"> 			<src path="src/"/> 		</javac> 		<!-- copy necessary resources --> 		<copy todir="${temp.folder}/samplePluginD.jar.bin"> 			<fileset dir="src/" excludes="**/*.java"/> 		</copy> 		<mkdir dir="${build.result.folder}"/> 		<jar jarfile="${build.result.folder}/samplePluginD.jar"  basedir="${temp.folder}/samplePluginD.jar.bin"/> 		<delete dir="${temp.folder}/samplePluginD.jar.bin"/> 	</target> 	 I can find "../samplePluginB/lib/b.jar" in classpath, which is good,  but "../samplePluginA/lib/a.jar" which I would expect to be there is missing.  The whole example is attached.

title: pde.build is not converted to API tools yet
desc: Created attachment 102707 [details] Proposed fix  These bundles are not converted to API tools yet.

title: PDE: callOnEmptyDelta for PDE builders breaks small deltas with many projects
desc: The fix for 527016 set all PDE builders to run even on empty deltas to avoid the computation of delta trees for large deltas.  For workspaces with many projects (~750 in our case) this is a major performance issue, as commented on 527016 as well.  At least for us the small delta use case (a manual change to a file) is the vast majority of deltas. Large deltas happen when rebasing (etc.), which is acceptable (IMHO) to take a little longer. Small deltas must be as fast as possible.  Reverting https://git.eclipse.org/r/#/c/111258/ locally immediately returns our Eclipse to a working state (i.e. autobuild after changing a single file takes <1 second vs. >30 seconds).

title: Error building update site with missing optional prerequisite
desc: Build ID: Build id: I20080612-2000  Steps To Reproduce: This is a problem found in the non-p2 driver.  1. Create an update site project 2. Add feature org.eclipse.platform to the project 3. Run the Build action 4. The following error message is displayed. Problems during export   Unable to find feature: org.eclipse.equinox.p2.user.ui. This makes it impossible to patch the feature org.eclipse.platform through the update site. Feature org.eclipse.equinox.p2.user.ui should be removed since non-p2 driver doesn't have it   More information:

title: Example RCP Product Build with p2
desc: Provide an example build setup to build an p2-ized rcp product.

title: PDE headless build fails for config "win32, win32, x86_64"
desc: The headless build via the ANT files provided in org.eclipse.pde.build/scripts/productBuild/productBuild.xml fail if the target config is Windows 64 bit ( -Dconfig= "win32, win32, x86_64" )  -------------------------------------------      [java] Target "assemble.org.eclipse.pde.build.container.feature.win32.win32.x86_64" does not exist in the project " Build specific targets and properties". -------------------------------------------   It seems that the org.eclipse.pde.build/scripts/productBuild/allElements.xml misses following block for the now with Eclipse 3.4 supported Windows 64 platform: -----------------------  <target name="assemble.org.eclipse.pde.build.container.feature.win32.win32.x86_64">  		<ant antfile="${assembleScriptName}" dir="${buildDirectory}">			  			<property name="archiveName" value="${archiveNamePrefix}-win32.win32.x86_64.zip"/> 		</ant>   	</target> -----------------------

title: PDE Build not generating RCP launcher branding icons
desc: Build ID: I200080609-1311  Steps To Reproduce: 1. Create an RCP application with custom launcher icons 2. Perform a headless build (i.e. one where ${launcherIcons} is not set 3. The custom icons will not be applied.   More information: In org.eclipse.pde.build.  On line 389 of AbstractScriptGenerator the method loadProduct returns a product file of  new ProductFile(f.getAbsolutePath(), null)  i.e, no OS is specified and so the getIcons method of the ProductFile will return an empty string array.  This product file is later used by AssembleConfigScriptGenerator in computeIconsList() where it does a productFile.getIcons expecting some results and when it doesn't find any it simply returns "${launcherIcons}" which is then all that is inserted into the generated eclipse.brand call in the assemble.*.xml files like this:  <eclipse.brand   root="${eclipse.base}/win32.win32.x86/${collectingFolder}"   icons="${launcherIcons}"   name="${launcherName}"   os="${os}"        />  If I write a little unit test that contructs a new ProductFile from my RCP applications .product, it will correctly pass my icon lists back so long as I have listed an OS in the constructor.  However if I pass null in for the contructor as the AssembleConfigScriptGenerator does I get back an empty array.  Seems to me like a pretty clear bug in PDE that will affect anyone trying to build branded RCP applications.   Is anyone able to confirm that this is indeed the problem?  In the meatime I'll work on a patch.

title: Launcher icon branding does not handle Win32 x64 launcher .exe
desc: Build ID: I20080609-1311  Steps To Reproduce: 1. Create an RCP application with a .product file 2. Specify a windows icon of the correct format to brand launcher with 3. Attempt to perform an Export using the Export product wizard or a headless PDE build to export a win32.x86_64 version of the RCP application  A Null Pointer Exception will be thrown with very little other information in the UI.   More information: Using IconExe isolated in a unit test, the following stack trace will be returned when attempting to swap the icons of a win32_x86_64 PE file.  java.lang.NullPointerException   at org.eclipse.pde.internal.swt.tools.IconExe.unloadIcons(IconExe.java:139)   at org.eclipse.pde.internal.swt.tools.IconExe.main(IconExe.java:73) ...  Looks like the PE file format has changed for x64 executables on Windows.  The new file format is called PE32+  (see http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/magazine/cc300794.aspx)  There is a magic bit that we can check.  The IMAGE_OPTIONAL_HEADER.Magic is set to 0x20b instead of 0x10b on a x64 .exe file.  In the very short term we might want to throw a better error and exit IconExe gracefully in the case of encountering a x64 .exe rather than simply returning null from IconExe.getIcons which results in the null pointer exception during branding.  The branding process could then also skip x64 executables rather than falling over completely leaving the end user to find their own way to brand the launcher but allowing all other platforms (including win32_x86) to go through unscathed.  In the meatime, I'll look into a patch that will give x64 support to IconExe which is obviously the better long term solution.  Many thanks,  Martin.

title: Parallel compilation
desc: Assuming JDT's batch compiler and ant adapter support it, once bug 212467 is addressed, it shouldn't be too large a change to use the ant parallel task to compile bundles in parallel.  Considering the bundles in a dependency tree, where each "tier" of the tree depends only on bundles in a higher tier, then bundles on a given tier could be compiled in parallel.

title: Allow custom execution environments
desc: See bug 238802. If UI allows custom execution environments coming from .ee files, then Build would likely need to support the same.

title: Unable to generate source feature if older version already present in installed base
desc: I have a scenario in which I need to regenerate a source feature from newly built plugins. An older version of the same feature is present in the installed base. After generating the source feature, BuildDirector keeps finding the version in the installed base rather than the newly generated one. It appears that this is because newly generated source features are appended to BuildTimeSite's feature reference list. One possible fix would be to insert generated source features at the top of the list rather than appending them.

title: Old-style source plugin does not include sources of all plugins from the corresponding feature
desc: I realize that this is more of an enhancement request than a bug...  I'm building a new version of a feature where only a few plugins have actually changed (since the base version). When generating the source feature (with the old-style source plugin), I would like to include sources from all plugins in that feature, even those that were not rebuilt but are picked up from the base. The previous (base) version of the source plugin already contains these sources.  The new style (one source bundle per bundle) does support this in that the source feature will automatically pick up the old versions if a new source bundle wasn't generated (which happens when you don't build the plugin but package the base version of it).

title: Support embedding repository information in released bundles
desc: This request is somehow cross-component and not PDE only, so I'm adding few people on CC for initial discussion.  When getting a bug report that should be simple to fix, I'm often trying to find a way how the reporter could try fix the issue himself and come up with a patch. The two biggest obstacles explaining what he needs to do, are   (1) How to obtain the correct sources, and   (2) How to create a patch (preferably against HEAD).  Given that the reporter apparently has some version of Eclipse up and running, he can easily import bundles from his running Eclipse into a workspace. If he has SDK installed, he can even import with source. While having the correct source for the actual runtime is great to debug, such imported bundles often don't build properly; plus, it's hard to find the correct bundle in the CVS or SVN Repository that matches the imported source.  I propose that     (1) Released binary bundles get Repository information added to their       Manifest:       Repository type, root, module  and maptag -- basically exactly the       information that currently is in the Mapfile.    (2) Importing bundles into the Workspace gets an additional 4th Option,       "Import with Source from Repository" which uses the known Repository       type, root, module and maptag in order to import from that Repository.  Now in most cases, it should be possible to build the bundle and much easier to create a patch. Plus, after patching against the released Maptag first, the submitter can even merge the patch onto HEAD himself just by doing Team > Switch to another branch or version.  I'd suspect that this enhancement makes it easier to get community fixes for simple things, and take some unnecessary workload off committers.  I'm actually assigning this request PDE-build first, assuming that once the Repository information is in the bundles, the 2nd step of leveraging it for the import could be a separate bug. If there is some OSGi / Equinox work needed to specify official markup for the Repository info in the Manifest, that might also be tracked with a separate depends-on bug.

title: [plan] Update PDE Build to adopt p2 publisher
desc: The publisher will soon make it into the builds.  At that time PDE Build should be updated to use the new publisher function.  I have created a "publisher_start" branch and put in there the changes required for this adoption.  Note that the changes may span several bundles.  you can get all changes related to the publisher using the publisher_start.psf contained in the org.eclipse.equinox.p2.publisher project.  In the case of PDE build the changes are mostly in the ant tasks related to the publisher.

title: Generated source feature inherits wrong platform filter
desc: When a source feature is generated based on a feature with a platform filter (e.g., ws="win32"), the generated source feature's platform filter is incorrect (e.g., ws="win32" arch="win32").

title: Replace versions in .product file
desc: Build ID: 3.4  Steps To Reproduce: 1. Create a product, define it's version as 1.0.0.qualifier in the .product file 2. Export the product using pde build 3. Note that the qualifier does not get translated   More information: here is the product line from my installer.product:  <product name="%productName" id="com.windriver.p2.installer.ui.product" application="com.windriver.p2.installer.ui.application" version="1.0.0.qualifier" useFeatures="false">  Here is a conversation from p2-dev that lead to this bugzilla: 1.) My question: Ciao Guys :) Would you be able to help me with the following problem please? The overall issue I'm having is a failing update-ProvisioningPlan. The workaround I'm using right now seems to prove my theory below, but I'd like you guys to confirm before I create a bugzilla.  Using 3.4 I'm exporting a product into a p2 repository, using qualifiers in the bundle versions to generate more recent versions whenever a build is finished. Now, when trying to update myself during the initial run of my product the Query looking for updates does find them correctly but the ProvisioningPlan never returns "isOK". Looking at content.xml I found out that the group, generated from the product, has the version "1.0.0" just like my product-definition indicates. The inclusion rules of that group are very strict so that updates are only possible for the entire group, which is fine in this scenario so I went ahead and changed the version of the product to '1.0.0.qualifier'. However, looking at the repository the qualifier never got translated and was put as-is into content.xml.   Long story short, my release-script replaces "qualifier" with a real qualifier now and things start to work... There is two solutions I can see here: - Change the group definitions to have a wider VersionRange so that individual plug-ins may be updated or - Allow for qualifiers in the product version to support updating the product along with the changed bundle.  Maybe I'm not seeing the obvious solution here, please advise !:)   2.) Response from Pascal: Hi Helmut,  This is a well-known problem. Please open a bug against PDE Build. PaScaL

title: org.eclipse.jdt.source is missing a subdirectory for org.junit_3.7.0
desc: build 20020517  org.eclipse.jdt.source is missing a subdirectory for org.junit_3.7.0  I suspect the problem may stem from org.eclipse.jdt.source's feature.xml referencing plugin="org.junit" version=3.7" (i.e., 2-part version number).

title: building a plugin JAR should first create the destination folder
desc: build 20020528  When building a plugin JAR, if the destination folder does not exist, an error  occurs and a not-so-helpful message is logged to the console. Consider fixing  for 2.0.

title: Generating build.xml hard codes ECLIPSE_HOME
desc: On windows machine A, eclipse is installed on D:\eclipse2.0. On windows machine B, eclipse is installed on C:\eclipse.  If I generate build.xml on machine A, the path D:\eclipse2.0 is hard coded in  the classpath entry for all Eclipse dependent plug-ins.  If I then try to build using the saved build.xml on machine B, the build fails  as Eclipse is installed in a different place.  In a previous build of Eclipse 2.0, I am pretty sure ${eclipse_home} was used,  rather than the hard coded path.

title: PDE build doesn't handle dropins directory for referenced features
desc: The pde build code does not recursively look into the dropins directory of the base location when searching for features.  In the case of Linux, the baseLocation is /usr/lib/eclipse.  Under that there are plugins/features which are required for the base platform.  The JDT has been split out under the /usr/lib/eclipse/dropins/jdt and a /usr/lib/eclipse/dropins/sdk directory has been created as well to hold various features (e.g. pde build itself).   The test testBug206679 in org.eclipse.pde.build.tests: SourceTests.java creates a feature that references the feature: org.eclipse.jdt  This test fails under Linux without major kludges because the org.eclipse.jdt feature is found under /usr/lib/eclipse/dropins/jdt/features and pde build is not prepared to find it.  The code in BuildTimeSiteFactory:BuildTimeSite.createSite() uses the installedBaseLocation and finds feature files via Util.findFiles.  It passes the installedBaseLocation and the default folder: "features".  This only finds the features directly in the features subfolder of the baseLocation (in our case /usr/lib/eclipse).  The code needs to recurse down to the dropins subdirectory and the features directories found below.

title: PDE-BUILD missing , in directory.txt file produces array index out of bounds exception
desc: Probably need it to through a build exception with a useful message like "Error  reading directory.txt".  You could probably even spew the first part of the  thing you are parsing which would likely contain the plugin name.

title: Unused variables in BuildScriptGeneratorTask
desc: There are some unused variables in this task. They should be removed.

title: filteredDependencyCheck misses source features
desc: When using filteredDependencyCheck on a build that includes generated source features, the filter is throwing exceptions on the missing to-be-generated source feature.  It should ignore these missing features.  As well, plug-ins can be added to the source feature via the generate property, these should be included in the set of reachable plugins.

title: filteredDependencyCheck missing specified plugin versions
desc: When including binary features in the build, requested versions to include in the state have a specific version.  A specific version is incorrectly being excluded from the state.  Fix is to use [0.0.0, 0.0.0) as the bound on the sorted subset, and have ReachablePlugin account for inclusion of the maximum when sorting.

title: 36 tests fail in pde.build.tests after ant update
desc: Since the update to ant 1.10.1 (bug 499717), pde.build.tests has 36 fails n Windows. http://download.eclipse.org/eclipse/downloads/drops4/I20170428-0830/testResults.php  The most tests fail with similar error:  \C:\shared_hudson\workspace\ep47I-unit-win32\workarea\I20170428-0830\eclipse-testing\test-eclipse\eclipse\plugins\org.eclipse.pde.build_3.9.200.v20170326-1136\scripts\\build.xml is not an absolute path   I have a patch.

title: Remove org.eclipse.pde.build.examples.rcp.cloud.releng from master
desc: Project points to CVS and seems outdated/ unused.  Last update was 4 years ago.

title: Use highest versioned feature instead of first found
desc: Currently when looking for a feature without a version specified, we use the first one we find with a matching id.  We should instead consider all known features with that id and return the highest version.

title: filteredDependencyCheck doesn't work with required features
desc: When filteredDependencyCheck is turned on and one of the included feature requires another feature using a match rule other than perfect, then the build fails when trying to add plugins for this requirement.

title: BuildScriptGenerator should give more details in error message
desc: Build ID: I20080617-2000  I have a build failure with output of the following kind:  [java] [eclipse.buildScript] Problem occurred while considering plugin: OTDebug Plug-in. [java] [eclipse.buildScript] Bundle org.objectteams.otdt.tests: [java] [eclipse.buildScript]       Missing required plug-in org.objectteams.otdt.debug_0.0.0.  In a log file of ~11MB this was the *only* hint at what went wrong. Only by running the headless build in the IDE I could debug it to the point to find that I simply had an error in file pluginVersions.properties, which read   org.objectteams.otdt.debug,1.2.2=1.2.2.200809030046 where it should say   org.objectteams.otdt.debug,1.2.2=200809030046  Given that debugging just a single phase out of a several hours build/test process is not at all trivial I would appreciate more information in the error message.   In this particular case this is where information is lost:  StateBuilder.createBundleDescription(StateImpl, Dictionary, String) line: 79 catches an IllegalArgumentException("invalid format") without recording the fact that this occurred while parsing a bundle version  -> please use s.t. like    new BundleException("Illegal bundle version '"+version+"': "+ex.getMessage())  PDEState.addBundle(Dictionary, File) line: 89 catches the BundleException and logs it to an AntLogAdapter, but there the exception contained in the Status is simply ignored (only three specific exception types are logged).  Why not catch and log any Throwable?  Here is the relevant part of the stack:         StateBuilder.createBundleDescription(StateImpl, Dictionary, String) line: 79         StateObjectFactoryImpl.createBundleDescription(State, Dictionary, String, long) line: 32         PDEState.addBundle(Dictionary, File) line: 89         PDEState.addBundle(File) line: 226         PDEState.addBundles(Collection) line: 380         BuildTimeSite.getRegistry() line: 103         BuildDirector.computeElements(BuildTimeFeature) line: 94         BuildDirector.generateChildrenScripts(BuildTimeFeature) line: 229         BuildDirector.generate(BuildTimeFeature, boolean) line: 175         BuildDirector.generateIncludedFeatureBuildFile(BuildTimeFeature) line: 213         BuildDirector.generate(BuildTimeFeature, boolean) line: 173         BuildDirector.generate(BuildTimeFeature) line: 168         BuildScriptGenerator.generateFeatures(List) line: 215         BuildScriptGenerator.generate() line: 102         BuildScriptGeneratorTask.run() line: 91         BuildScriptGeneratorTask.execute() line: 79         ...

title: Problem with mis-matched feature versions
desc: Ultimately, this appears to be bug 208143 surfacing again.  The test org.eclipse.pde.build.tests SourceTests#testBug206679_247198 is intermittently failing.  The cause is outlined below:  The following is based on build I20080917-0100:  org.eclipse.help feature is including a different version of org.eclipse.rcp that what exists in the build:  help is:    1.1.0.r20080805-7r7zEM1EIoZsadfz0Jrcz-D9E_d5 help wants: 3.5.0.v20080911-9B9rEvNElF3-509c4YQE621B rcp is :    3.5.0.v20080911-9B9rEvNElF3-509c4ZQF8z-yB                                                ^^^^^^  Looking at build I20080916-200: help is: 1.1.0.r20080805-7r7zEM1EIoZsadfz0Jrcz-D9E_d5 rcp is:  3.5.0.v20080911-9B9rEvNElF3-509c4YQE621B   I suspect that the following is occuring: The contents of rcp change from build 0916-200 to 0917-0100, causing the version to increment from E621B to F8z-yB.  The contents of help do not change, and in the automatic suffix generation, the change in rcp is not significant enough to surface after length truncation.  We are left with 2 different versions of help with the same version but different contents.  The artifact repo used in the build contains the old help artifacts (?) which end up getting used when creating the zips.

title: Incorrect classpath given folder shaped bundles with .classes in folders
desc: Given a binary bundle shaped as a folder and with .class files on disk instead of being jared:  org.foo_1.0.0/META-INF/MANIFEST.MF              /org/.../*.class              /plugin.xml   PDE/Build is generating an incorrect classpath for bundles that depend on this.  They are getting a classpath entry: ..../org.foo_1.0.0/@dot when it should just be ..../org.foo_1.0.0/  The @dot is correct only when the org.foo bundle is not binary and is being compiled.

title: PDE build archivesFormat antTar doesn't correctly set Linux permissions due to wrong line in TarFileSet.java
desc: Created attachment 273129 [details] Fix at TarFileSet.java  If archivesFormat property is set to linux,gtk,x86_64-antTar, permissions are not set correctly in tar.gz file even if set correctly with root.linux.gtk.x86_64.permissions.755 property (e.g. jre/bin/java). This is caused by TarFileSet constructor is not passing permission parameter to parent constructor. See solution in attached patch.

title: Incorrect classpath given folder shaped bundles with .classes in folders
desc: Cloned for 3.4.2  +++ This bug was initially created as a clone of Bug #248767 +++  Given a binary bundle shaped as a folder and with .class files on disk instead of being jared:  org.foo_1.0.0/META-INF/MANIFEST.MF              /org/.../*.class              /plugin.xml   PDE/Build is generating an incorrect classpath for bundles that depend on this.  They are getting a classpath entry: ..../org.foo_1.0.0/@dot when it should just be ..../org.foo_1.0.0/  The @dot is correct only when the org.foo bundle is not binary and is being compiled.

title: [plan] Fetch using p2
desc: PDE/Build should support using p2 to fetch required content for a build.  This should probably take the form of a mirroring operation as opposed to an install operation.  The advantage of a mirror would be that the metadata would then be available for the build and it would not need to be regenerated.  This should be implemented through the existing fetch extension point.  A map file entry would include: metadat repo url, artifact repo url, required IU, IU version. Perhaps also some options around whether to fetch the transitive closure of required IUs.

title: generate metadata during gather.bin.parts
desc: gather.bin.parts should support 2 modes of operation: 1) gathering for metadata generation and p2 as the packager, and 2) gathering for old style packaging.  This is relatively straightforward, except for the following considerations:  Bundles: The final shape of bundles is currently determined by the containing feature.  We will need to consider the Eclipse-BundleShape header (bug 217005).  gather.bin.parts will still be called through delegation through the features, feature should be able to override the shape of included bundles.    **** Can Features override bundle shape via a patch IU ???  This would simplify things here a little, the bundle IU just gets whatever shape the bundle says in its header, the feature can require a patch IU that changes it.   Features: Rootfiles IU generation should occur at this point.  One thing to work out is what this looks like for features that have an empty bin.includes, that is, features that contribute rootfiles but not an actual feature jar.

title: Invalid config.ini for feature based .products not including a configurator
desc: If a product does not include either org.eclipse.equinox.simpleconfigurator, or org.eclipse.update.configurator, then the pattern is to place all bundles on the osgi.bundles list.  This is broken in the case of feature based .products.  In this case we need to list out the bundles from the assemblydata instead of the plugin list from the .product file.

title: Invalid config.ini for feature based .products not including a configurator
desc: Consider in 3.4.2  +++ This bug was initially created as a clone of Bug #249410 +++  If a product does not include either org.eclipse.equinox.simpleconfigurator, or org.eclipse.update.configurator, then the pattern is to place all bundles on the osgi.bundles list.  This is broken in the case of feature based .products.  In this case we need to list out the bundles from the assemblydata instead of the plugin list from the .product file.

title: Allow PDE UI to better reuse QualifierReplacer code
desc: Created attachment 114114 [details] Change to QualifierReplacer  Working on bug 222945 I am using the QualifierReplacer to determine what the exported plug-insfeature's new version will be.  I also need to get a version for installableunit patches that includes the date.  PDE UI uses QualifierReplacement in a couple places, but actually duplicates the getDate() functionality.  Since we are already using QualifierReplacer, it makes more sense to reuse the code.  The attached patch makes getDate() public and adds some comments.  Once that change is made I can clean up the UI side.

title: remove dependency on update.core
desc: PDE/Build still has a dependency on update.core for the jarProcessor.  This should be changed to use org.eclipse.equinox.p2.jarprocessor

title: Incorrect character ordering in feature qualifier
desc: When comparing version numbers to determine which one is greater, Eclipse does a simple string compare when looking at the qualifier part of the version number.  (See org.osgi.framework.Version.compareTo() in plugin org.eclipse.osgi.)  In that ordering, an underscore is in between the capital letters and the lower case letters, i.e. 'Z' < '_' < 'a'.  But when creating the feature qualifier suffix (that hash-like string at the end of a feature's version number), the underscore character is treated as if it were between the digits and the capital letters, i.e. '9' < '_' < 'A'.  (See org.eclipse.pde.internal.build.Utils.BASE_64_ENCODING and how it is used in plugin org.eclipse.pde.build.)  This bug can result in feature version numbers that go backwards when plugin version numbers are increased correctly.  That can result in the update manager refusing to install the newer build of a feature because it thinks the newer build has a lower version than what is already installed.  As a specific example, someone at our company changed a plugin version number from 7.2.0.v20081013 to 7.2.0.v20081014.  When that happened, the feature version number went from 7.2.0.v20080908-7E2-9oA55S7D9_ to 7.2.0.v20080908-7E2-9oA55S7D9A.

title: compile error in org.eclipse.pde.build.tests_1.1.0.N20081017-2000
desc: Created attachment 115502 [details] patch  In P2TestCase.assertTouchpoint we are calling: iu.getTouchpointData()[0].getInstructions(phase) and assuming the result is a String. TouchpointData.getInstructions(phase) now returns a TouchpointInstruction. To get at the underlying text we need to call getBody().

title: generated gather.sources is broken
desc: Currently the generated build.xml has the following: <target name="gather.sources">    <antcall target="children">       <param name="destination.temp.folder" value="${feature.temp.folder}/plugins/null/src"/>       <param name="target" value="gather.sources"/>    </antcall> </target>  The "null" comes from FeatureBuildScriptGenerator#sourceFeatureFullNameVersioned never being initialized

title: Wrong bundle version selected on export (NPE)
desc: Given a state with multiple versions of a bundle where all versions resolve (non-singleton), product config.ini generation can choose a different version of the bundle than what was selected for the build.  This results in an NPE in ShapeAdvisor#getUnpackClause, as well as an incorrect config.ini if bundles.info is being used.

title: Wrong bundle version selected on export (NPE)
desc: +++ This bug was initially created as a clone of Bug #252246 +++  Given a state with multiple versions of a bundle where all versions resolve (non-singleton), product config.ini generation can choose a different version of the bundle than what was selected for the build.  This results in an NPE in ShapeAdvisor#getUnpackClause, as well as an incorrect config.ini if bundles.info is being used.

title: build script generator fails to resolve older plugin
desc: Build ID: M20080911-1700  When running a build in headless mode, I observed the case that a feature's build.xml was generated with an empty all.plugins target. The (single) plugin that should have been mentioned here also exists in the platform running the build, where (accidentally in this case) the source version was less than the one from the build platform. After fixing the version number, everything went fine. Should mention that the feature.xml specifies the exact plugin version.  I am wondering whether this implies that pde build will not be able to use a newer eclipse to build a maintenance release with lesser version numbers?  At first sight this issue reminded me of bug 234178, but this impression might be completely wrong.  Given that the target's start and end tags where written correctly and looking at FeatureBuildScriptGenerator#generateAllPluginsTarget() the contained loop neither produced any result nor threw an exception. I had to stop analysing there because I couldn't easily see how to run a headless build in the debugger. Can the script generator(s) be invoked separately using eclipse command line arguments?  Wait: what's in getSite(false).getRegistry().getSortedBundles()? Is that all available versions or only the newest version of each bundle? In the latter case Utils.extractPlugins() might have a good reason not to find an older version as given in "plugins"?  Would that be by intention?

title: org.eclipse.pde.internal.build.Policy class not used
desc: The Plicy class does not appear to be referenced from anywhere in PDE/Build.  Should look at removing it.

title: Condition & ConditionTask not used
desc: org.eclipse.pde.internal.build.ant.Condition & ConditionTask don't seem to be used anywhere.    Look at removing them.

title: p2.director fails to create product following product build with multiple configs
desc: Created attachment 117076 [details] build log and scripts  Branching from a discussion in bug 237537, using 3.5M3 as the basebuilder with deltapack available as a pluginPath element, a product build for Galileo works if only one configs entry is specified in build.properties.  However, if multiple configs are entered (e.g. configs=linux,gtk,ppc & macosx,carbon,x86), the build fails at the execution of the director to create the product.  Attached are the build scripts and log file from the execution of this build on build.eclipse.org.  It fails much the same on my Mac, where there is a long delay when installing plugins, followed by a timeout exception and corrupt archive errors.  I suspect the failure is due to multiple updates of the local /repo for each product config during the normal product build.  When specifying a single config, the build passes on both my machine and build.eclipse.org and the p2-enabled product launches fine.

title: [doc] generate.p2.metadata must be unset, not set to false
desc: Setting the generate.p2.metadata property to false, my headless PDE build continuoes to generate p2.generator ant calls into the assemble scripts. Only by removing the generate.p2.metadata property from the build file, this seems to stop. It thus seems, if the value of the property is not regarded and only its existence is checked.   This holds for Eclispe 3.4.1 as well as 3.5M3.

title: packaging fails if archivePrefix different from collectingFolder
desc: Created attachment 118276 [details] generated package xml file  I started with these 2 values: archiveNamePrefix=e4-resources archivePrefix=eclipse  and get an error while running the packager for binary content: java.lang.RuntimeException: Source directory is invalid: /opt/public/cbi/eclipse.build/I20081119-1045/tmp/e4-resources.  The console says that PDE does most of its work in e4-resources:  jarIng_NoManifest:       [jar] Building jar: /opt/public/cbi/eclipse.build/I20081119-1045/tmp/e4-resources/features/org.eclipse.e4.resources.feature_3.105.0.v20081119-3--7EX9d8mJH_25_hUllni12A22.jar       [jar] Building jar: /opt/public/cbi/eclipse.build/I20081119-1045/tmp/e4-resources/features/org.eclipse.e4.resources.feature_3.105.0.v20081119-3--7EX9d8mJH_25_hUllni12A22.jar  but then the packages switches to:  main:     [mkdir] Created dir: /opt/public/cbi/eclipse.build/I20081119-1045/tmp      [copy] Copying 1 file to /opt/public/cbi/eclipse.build/I20081119-1045/tmp/eclipse/plugins      [copy] Copying 1 file to /opt/public/cbi/eclipse.build/I20081119-1045/tmp/eclipse/plugins   The packages is looking for information in ${eclipse.base} but has copied the plugins into ${assemblyTempDir}/${pluginArchivePrefix}  PW

title: permit cvs and svn checkouts to be silent
desc: I've tried setting quiet, reallyquiet, and cvs.quiet, and I still get reams of console out for cvs (and svn) checkouts. Can there be a global variable in build.properties (or a better place, if you can suggest one) which can be set to:  * verbose (more output, if there is such a thing) * normal (current setting) * quiet (minimal output) * reallyquiet (no output)  Or if that's overkill, then at least please support a new reallyquiet / silent mode.  See also bug 255991.

title: java.util.jar.Manifest can lose the last attribute
desc: Created attachment 118915 [details] MANIFEST.MF before the build (from CVS)  This bundle has an entry with: Bundle-RequiredExecutionEnvironment: J2SE-1.4  in its MANIFEST.MF file.  Once the build is complete, it is gone.  Here is the MANIFEST.MF before the build (see attachment 1 [details]) directly from CVS.  Here is the MANIFEST.MF file after the build N20081126-2000 is complete. See next attachment.  As you can see the two entries: Import-Package: com.ibm.icu.text Bundle-RequiredExecutionEnvironment: J2SE-1.4 are gone. Setting as critical as there is loss of data in the build process.  I could not insert the two files directly in the comment. It would be too big.

title: .api_description generation should be moved to the build.xml file
desc: Right now we generate the file inside the custom assembly file. This means it is done very late in the build process. We would like to get that file on a project export and the easiest way to get this is to include the ant task call inside the build.xml. The new target to include is: <target name="apitools.files.generation" if="<condition>"> 	<apitooling.apigeneration 			projectName="${project.name}" 			targetFolder="${target.folder}" 			projectLocation="${project.location}" /> </target>  where <condition> is replaced with a property that is only set when the api tools bundles are on the ant classpath.  Then the target should be called with: <antcall target="apitools.files.generation"> 			<param name="project.name" value="${bundleId}_${bundleVersion}"/> 			<param name="project.location" value="${basedir}"/> 			<param name="target.folder" value="${destination.temp.folder}/org.eclipse.jdt.core_3.5.0.200812031150"/> 		</antcall>  where ${destination.temp.folder}/org.eclipse.jdt.core_3.5.0.200812031150 is changed each time the build.xml file is generated. I don't know the way it would work for customed build.xml file (SWT has such files).  Note that you need to latest code from api tools if you want to try this out. I cannot release that code as long as we don't move to the latest Api Tools bundles in the build.

title: source bundles are not generated in unique locations at build time
desc: I recently tried to change the help feature to use a new version of org.eclipse.equinox.http.jetty (bug 248793) .  The source bundle wasn't generated for the 2.0.0 version of org.eclipse.equinox.http.jetty, but was generated for the 1.1.0 version.  We determined that this was because the source feature is generated in the org.eclipse.equinox.http.jetty.source directory in both cases.    The source directories should be unique so that source bundles with the same name but different versions can be generated within the same build.

title: Avoid copy of workspace class files during plug-in export
desc: As a follow up to bug 101241, we should investigate whether it is possible to avoid copying class files from the workspace to a temporary location where they are packaged into bundles. The time it takes to copy large amounts of class files negates the win of avoiding compilation.

title: Change PDE Build (tests) to use p2 metadata interfaces
desc: Created attachment 121189 [details] Changes PDE Build (tests) to use p2 metadata interfaces  With bug# 256359 we have changed p2 metadata to use interfaces.  This breaks a few things with PDE.

title: allow app spec to be excluded from product builds
desc: Currently, for product-based PDE builds, an application and product extension must be specified for completing a PDE product build.   For some use cases (e.g. creating a servletbridge-based equinox server) no application is needed, and so it should be possible to exclude the app and product specs from product-based builds.  This enhancement request is related to bug #259763, becase bug #259763 is also requesting excluding something (launchers) that for some use cases should be possible to exclude from PDE build.  However, this enhancement should be independent from bug #259763, so that all combinations are possible (i.e. require both [current], include app spec but not launchers, include launchers but not app spec, exclude both).

title: [p2] Generate appropriate feature rootfile IUs
desc: Currently pde.build collects all rootfiles together and provides them to p2 to generate one rootfile IU for a product.  There is no real support for rootfiles outside the context of a product.  We want a give feature to have associated with it a rootfile IU that contributes the files associated with that feature.  Then a product includes some set of feature that pull in rootfile IUs instead of having just one big product rootfile iu.  The org.eclipse.equinox.executable is a particularly interesting case of this.  It will be nice to have individual artifacts for each platform that contain only the launcher.  This should help simply the mechanisms for building products. (bug 260066).  This bug is raised on pde.build instead of p2, and it requires build time, pre-packaging knowledge of build's behaviour and build.properties formats.

title: Export Fails from self hosted workspace with API tooling
desc: Exporting from a self hosted workspace may fail when exporting a feature/product that includes bundles from the host workspace.  The failure is: C:\Dev\Platform\Workspaces\PROV\org.eclipse.ant.core\build.xml:327: The location C:\dev\test\rcp/eclipse/plugins/org.eclipse.ant.core_3.2.100.200901091558/bin specified in the binary argument does not exist  Which is coming from API Tooling.

title: PDE export sliently fails when there is an extra manifest
desc: Created attachment 122205 [details] sample plug-in and feature  To reproduce import the attached projects.  Test 1) Use the Export -> Deployable features menu item to export the feature.  While there is no indication that the export didn't work, in fact it failed. The generated manifest.mf file is wrong   Also the eclipse process is keeping a lock of the generated plug-in jar. This indicates that where the jar file is opened, the close of it is not in a finally block (which it should be).   Test 2) Use the Export -> Deployable plug-ins and fragments menu item to export the plug-in.   Similar to test 1, the generated manifest is wrong.  This problem also exists in 35M4.  I hope you can fix this. It took me better than half a day to track down this problem. (The problem is that there is a second manifest inside of the java source folder).

title: filteredDependencyCheck doesn't handle require plugin properly
desc: When filtering the state and a feature requires a plugin with a matching rule, an incorrect version range is generated resulting in the required plugins no being added to the state.

title: IdReplaceTask fails if no space immediately after <feature
desc: I have an example, where an update site ends up with features that are still using ".qualifier" in the artifacts and therefore trying to install a feature doesn't work as the corresponding jar (.....qualifier.jar) doesn't exist. I can work with Andrew to investigate this issue.  The api tools update site is corrupted and nothing can be installed from it anymore.
