title: [build] Java 1.4 assertions fail when ran in IDE.
desc: If the a plugin uses assertions, is installed into the Eclipse plugins  directory and ran from the Eclipse plugins directory, it throws an exception  and the log file shows:      !SESSION Jul 19, 2002 11:31:17.233 ----------------------------------------- ----     java.version=1.4.1-beta     java.vendor=Sun Microsystems Inc.     BootLoader constants: OS=win32, ARCH=x86, WS=win32, NL=en_GB     Command-line arguments: -os win32 -ws win32 -arch x86 -data  h:/projects/Etish -install file:Q:/opt/eclipse/R2.0/eclipse/     !ENTRY org.eclipse.ui 4 4 Jul 19, 2002 11:31:17.233     !MESSAGE Unhandled exception caught in event loop.     !ENTRY org.eclipse.ui 4 0 Jul 19, 2002 11:31:17.248     !MESSAGE Unresolved compilation problem:       Syntax error on keyword "false"; "=", "*=", "/=", "%=", "+=", "- =", "<<=", ">>=", ">>>=", "&=", "^=", "|=" expected  This is true whether it is ran directly within the IDE or if a new Eclipse is  launched via Run, as long as the launch definition specifies that the plugin is  to be ran from the "External Plug-ins".  If, on the otherhand, the launch is set up to use the plugin from  the "Workspace Plug-ins" list, all goes fine.  When reproducing, it is necessary to using a Java 1.4 environment. My testing  was done with Sun Java 1.4.1 Beta, but I have had similar behaviour with Sun  Java 1.4.0_01. Make certain that the Eclipse preference for compliance is set  to 1.4 and that the launch configuration has assertions enabled.  To repoduce this simply create a new plugin Project based on the Hello World  plugin. Modify SampleAction.run() to have an assert as such:      public void run(IAction action) {         MessageDialog.openInformation(window.getShell(), "Hello Plug- in", "Hello, Eclipse world");          assert false : "FooBar";     }  Now run it locally as if you are testing the plugin and the assertion should be  trigger and reported with the Reason being FooBar. Now create a plugin jar file  and install the plugin into the Eclipse plugins directory. Relaunch Eclipse so  the new plugin is read in; there should now be a new menu item to run Hello  World. When the plugin is activate you will see that rather than the clean  report of the assertion there is now an exception as I noted above. Now create  a new launch definition and select to use Hello.jar from the "External Plug- ins" list and make sure it is deselected from the "Workspace Plug-ins" list.  Run the plugin and test Hello in the new Eclipse as above. The behaviour is the  same.

title: [build] Task for feature/plugins version verification
desc: Since many people forget to change the plug-in version both in feature and  plug-in descriptors (looking at the latest problems with builds) it would be  helpful to provide a new Ant task (through the pde.build plug-in) for a quick  check if the versions are correct. This task could be called after the fetch  task and report all the problems with versions between features, plugins and  fragments.  If deciding to implement it there is some existing code that could be useful.  Talk to releng and ask them for the code they use to populate the update test  site.

title: Run-time Workbench not usable
desc: "Run as run-time workbench" launches a new workbench, but the OS  process does not get mouse events... I can see another workbench  window, but I cannot bring it to the front.  No additional Eclipse icon  shows up on the Dock, but an additional "java" process is running, as  evidenced by Process Viewer.  I'm running Mac OS X 10.1.5.  I have not tried this on Jaguar.

title: [features] build should support conditionals
desc: see bug 27052  Features will now include support for conditional <includes>, <requires> and  <plugin> elements.  The build mechanism should run in a context of particular  OS, WS and ARCH settings.    This primarily means that the build should use the tuple values in deciding  what features/plugins/fragments are to be built.  Once this is decided, the  build can continue much as it does now as we will only build one configuration  at a time.

title: [features] build should fill in version numbers
desc: Currently the build input feature.xml files have version numbers for the  included/required features and plugins.  This makes the biuld somewhat fragile  as these entries need to be updated as the real version numbers change.  To  simplify this the build should be updated to allow the version attributes of   <includes>, <requires> and <plugin> to be "0.0.0".  If such a value is encountered, the build mechanism will fill  in the version number extracted from the plugin/feature that it built.    The input feature.xml file must NOT be altered in any way.  Rather, the  modification is done to the feature.xml which appears in the build output.

title: [features] build features anywhere
desc: Features no longer need to be in a project by themselves.  A feature is  wherever the feature.xml file is.  Users will point to a feature.xml and  say "build"  Note that this has ramifications for the fetch phase.  Currently build assumes  that the location is a project and thne just fetchs the whole project.  We need  to ensure that the location specification is general enough to handle spec'ing   a folder in a project and that this content is placed locally in an  appropriately named dir for the rest of the build to process.  the .map files may be affected.

title: Build script generators assume the target location
desc: Build script generators in PDE Build assume that the desired target location  for generated build script is the same as the mainifest file of the object  (feature, plugin etc.) for which the script is created. This blocks the new  work in PDE where we want to generate scripts and run them in the temp. space  outside the workspace (without creating any new resources).   We propose two new methods in AbstractBuildScriptGenerator:  /**  * Returns the path to the target directory for the new script.  */ String getScriptTargetLocation();  /**  * Sets the target path of the new script. All segments of the new  * path must exist.If not set, or if the location is invalid,  * the script will use the default location which depends on   * the nature of the generator.  * @param targetPath the non-default target location of the script  */ void setScriptTargetLocation(String targetPath);

title: Too many build entries proposed to the user
desc: In eclipse, when the user wants to build a project first he selects the  plugin.xml file and asks for the generation of the build.xml. The result of  this operation is a big build.xml file which contains too many targets that are  useless.  We need a way to either filter them in the UI or to create specific build.xml  file.

title: Assemble file generation
desc: The assembly requires the releng people to write specific ant targets that  lists all the plugins and features that goes in EVERY platform. The necessity of theses targets is due to the fact that we compile all the  platforms (macos, win, linux,...) at once, and then need to sort out all the  elements that has been compiled to put them into the appropriate zip files.  This is painfull to do and obviously not scalable with the nested feature  feature.  Since this problem depends on the platform we build, a nice solution would be  (when we will integrate the conditions into the feature.xml) to generate the  targets previously mentioned as long as we build the build.xml files.  Note that instead of generating the targets we may generate files.

title: Gathering bin parts
desc: With the recursive features, the gather.bin.parts (which extract files from a zip in order to build the sdk) is done several times. This results in a longer time to build all the platform.  This should be changed so this operation is only done once.

title: [build] new entry for build.properties
desc: Currently we have a mechanism to add extra jar entries to the classpath when compiling. (jars.extra.classpath)  We should enable this to be on a per libary basis rather than added to the classpath for all libraries which are compiled within the plug-in.  Ideally this would also be mimiced in Eclipse and JDT would allow multiple classpaths per project.  See also bug 20488.

title: Generic version numbers and feature parsing
desc: In order to generate the build.xml file, we are planning on using the  functionnalities of the SiteManager. This will make our life easier,  our code smaller, and we will be able to take advantage of the cache provided.  So because at build time the features contain generic numbers (0.0.0),  the parser and also all the methods returning pluginEntries and features included should be verified, so they reflect the expected behavior of this generic value, i.e. return the available version.

title: Removing the all.fragment target from build.xml file
desc: The all.fragment target created in the build.xml file was wrong for the  compilation purpose, and on a more general point of view, it does not bring any value... Because, in the new implementation this target is no longer used, does anybody  mind if I get rid of it?

title: builds should generate extension point doc from extension point schema
desc: After M4, PDE will hand over extension point schemas to component owners. Extension point schemas contain all the information in the current extension  point HTML doc pages.  What we need to happen is this: - component owners will delete their existing extension point HTML doc files - component owners will instead maintain their extension point schemas - the build process will regenerate extension point HTML doc pages from  extension point schemas  This PR is for that last item. There is a utility for generating the HTML doc  page from the extension point schema (Dejan has details). This utility needs  to be hooked in to the build process somewhere.  This item is needed for M4.

title: Enhancements to directory.txt
desc: We would like to be able to specify in the directory.txt file, which directory  the plugin/fragment/feature lives in. Currently we require the names to be the  same.  For instance, on the server we have a project with the following structure: /a /a/b /a/b/foo-feature  And the directory.txt could contain an entry like: feature@com.foo=v101,:pserver:anon@foo.com:/home/cvs,,/a/b/foo-feature

title: FeatureBuildScriptGenerator does not order the fragments correctly for compilation
desc: The order fragments get compiled should be changed. Indeed they must be added directly after their plugin.

title: source features and plugins generation
desc: Although the source features seem to be the same, some information are  differents. For example:    - The feature.properties file contains the name of the feature.   - The feature.xml contains the update site.   - The feature.xml lists some doc plugins.  For the first problem, a solution could be to modify the file. For the second problem, the value could be the one indicated in the 'binary'  feature For the third problem, no idea yet.

title: Please take a look on Bug #29056
desc: I've been told to report you to, since Plugin Developer is the first instance of resolving such problem. He should be guided to by PDE.  Thanks  Henning

title: Compiling non-platform specific code using SWT
desc: There is a problem in compiling non-platform specific code (for example GEF)  that requires SWT (which is platform dependent)  Indeed, swt.jar is not provided by the swt plugin but by fragments, and in the  fragments the usage of a variable (representing the current window system) is  made to dertermine where to get the jar.  For example org.eclipse.swt.win32_2.1.0/ws/${ws}/swt.jar  The problem comes when we want to compile code that does not require any  specific ws setting, since the ws value will not be set, and the swt will not  be found.

title: Improving the creation of the build time construction
desc: At build time, a Site is being used representing both the code to compile and  the code to compile against (installed base).  Because the code to compile against never change, whereas the code to compile  might evolve (dynamic creation of feature for example), it might be interesting  to provide a system of cache to avoid parsing again the installed base.

title: do HEAD substitution in map files
desc: Should be able to tell fetch to change the versions in the map files to HEAD to  accomodate nightly builds.

title: combine configurations.txt and build.properties
desc: configurations.txt is a rather uninteresting file.  Especially all on its own.   We should combine that file with the build.properties and work out a format for  specing multiple configs in one property.  For example, in build.properties  configurations=win32,win32,x86&linux,motif,x86&...  Use the & to separate the configs.  This makes the code a little more  compilicated but the current story is hard to explain especially when there is  a build.property identifying the location of the config file and we have to  pass that location into the various generators.

title: Feature assembler / packager
desc: The current builder allows to build zips from a feature with very little effort.  This builder mechanism supports the building with compilation but it does not  handle (or with many customization of existing scripts) the creation of derived  zips.  What we are calling derived zips is for example the various drops that are  created in same time an eclipse sdk is built (for example the platform runtime  binary, the jdt runtime binary,...), or products that are built from the  assembly of eclipse and of other features (for example wsdd). All or most of these derived zips consist in a simple repackaging of existing  things.  Because of this last property and the pain that represents the hand crafting of  such scripts, we decided to create an assembler / packager which goal is to  create assemble scripts.   The parameters for this assembler are a list of paths (directories or zips)  configurations and a feature to build.  The result is as many zip files as configurations containing the plugins and  features referenced by the feature passed in parameter.

title: Request for two new targets in build.xml
desc: PDE would like to request two new simple targets that should be included by  default in the build.xml generated, so that we could use them for the export  wizards: Requested target #1: would behave exactly like a zip.plugin target, except that  it does not package source in the zip file. Request target #2: would behave exactly like zip.distribution, except that it  DOES include source code in the zip file.

title: Backport the changes of 2.1 stream into local repository
desc: The changes made into the classpath computation, the new targets for wassim,  and the computation of the compilation order must be ported back into the local  repository for the ingoing dev of features

title: Would like to have control over javac options when creating build.xml files
desc: The default settings for javac are great for a single user working at his  desktop.  The PDE even does an exceptional job at combining option files to  make the build.xml scripts to construct the deliverable artefacts.  I am  however having some problems getting the generated XML exactly how I like it.   Specifically within the javac task I want to set the failonerror to true.  <target name="example.jar" depends="init"> <property name="destdir" value="${temp.folder}/example.jar.bin"/> 	<delete dir="${temp.folder}/example.jar.bin"/> 	<mkdir dir="${temp.folder}/example.jar.bin"/> 	<!-- compile the source code --> 	<javac destdir="${temp.folder}/example.jar.bin" failonerror="false"  verbose="true" debug="on" includeAntRuntime="no"  bootclasspath="${bootclasspath}" classpath="F:/eclipse/plugins/ ..... .jar"> 		<src path="java/"/> 	</javac> 	.... 	.... 	</target>  This is what gets automatically generated by the PDE when I select 'create  plugin jars'.  We work in a team setting and have a separate box perform the  builds nightly by running the generated build.xml files.  If each user remember  to go in and fix the failonerror=true then everything is fine.  Every time the  project structure is slightly modified, the simplest way to correct the XML is  to simply re-generate it and the setting ends up back as false. All flags should use some kind of variable subsitution including the  classpath.  This is the one I found the most bizzare.  The .classpath file uses  variables, but when build.xml is created, all of the variables are resolved  into hard paths.  This doesn't work when using a central machine for building  that does not have a developer there to generate the build.xml script.

title: Why does build.update.jar delete the temp folder?
desc: If something goes wrong when running target 'build.update.jar', there is no way  for us to see the *.bin.log files because that target deletes the temp folder  before it finishes. Same with running zip.plugin.  Why is 'build.update.jar' eager to delete the temp folder? Would it not be better to let the 'clean' target take care of the deletion, so  that we could have the option to see what went wrong during the build if we  wanted to?

title: Need descriptions for targets in build.xml
desc: The build.xml file contains "public" targets which will appear to the user in  the "Run Ant..." wizard. We need to add descriptive text comments to these  targets.

title: [build] Add #debug to Policy class
desc: - add the following method to Policy. (copied from other Core Policy classes) - convert all System.out.println debug statements to use this method /** * Print a debug message to the console. If the given boolean is * true then pre-pend the message with the current date. */ public static void debug(boolean includeDate, String message) { if (includeDate) message = new Date(System.currentTimeMillis()).toString() + " - "+ message; //$NON-NLS-1$ System.out.println(message); }

title: [CBI] 12 Build test failures in CBI builds
desc: http://download.eclipse.org/eclipse/downloads/drops4cbibased/I20130219-0811/testresults/html/org.eclipse.pde.build.tests_linux.gtk.x86_6.0.html#PDEBuildTestSuite  Some are related to the removal of source bundles for branding bundles (Bug 400733).  Others are probably related to problems with the p2 plug-ins.

title: Need more javac options in build.xml files
desc: The javac options added for bug 32177 is a good start, however 3 more options  should also be supported. 1:  source{1.3|1.4} - This option is manditory as the compiler will not accept  code with assertions without 1.4 being specified as the source release. 2:  debuglevel{lines|vars|source} - It would be nice to be able to specify  which debug info is included. 3:  target{1.1|1.2|1.3|1.4} - This is useful especially if you are compiliing  with 1.4 and need it to run on eariler versions as the default target for 1.4  will create a class version that is incompatible with eariler version of the  jvm.

title: bin.includes does not support $os$ variable types
desc: bin.includes does not autorise the presence of $os$ variables:   the value is not expanded and any jar that might have been created into os/ ${os} directory is not included.  To get the jar included, it requires the user to know how the variable gets  expanded (os/${os}) which might be problematic if we later decide to change the  schema the variables expands to. Moreover it seems to be inconsistent to require the user to know about this  expansion since he only ever manipulates $os$ (for example in  source.$os$/foo.jar).

title: Adding a description to the refresh target
desc: In order ot make the refresh target more visible to the user, it could be  interesting to add a description to the refresh target. This can easily be made available for 2.1, without danger.

title: Optimized gathering
desc: In the initial versions of the scripts, we were creating several useless  feature.zips. The step that create those should be removed.

title: all.children target contains duplicates
desc: Build: 2.1 1. Create a Hello, world plug-in project 'com.example.xyz' 2. Create any template plug-in project 'com.example.abc.xyz' 3. Create a new feature project 'com.example.feature' which includes the two  plug-ins above. 4. Right-click on com.example.feature/feature.xml and select 'Create Ant Build  File' 5. Open the generated com.example.feature/build.xml and look at the  all.children target. It contains duplicate ant calls: <target name="all.plugins" depends="init">   <ant antfile="build.xml" dir="../com.example.abc.xyz/" target="${target}"/>   <ant antfile="build.xml" dir="../com.example.xyz/" target="${target}"/>   <ant antfile="build.xml" dir="../com.example.abc.xyz/" target="${target}"/>   <ant antfile="build.xml" dir="../com.example.xyz/" target="${target}"/> </target>

title: [build] why does gather.logs create a *.log.zip file?
desc: It would be great if the gather.logs target for features simply copied the  compile logs into a destination much like the gather.bin.parts target instead  of calling zip.logs.

title: The *.jar.bin folder is included in the zip file
desc: Please consider for 3.0 M1  Using the latest pde.build from HEAD. 1. Create a "Hello, world" plug-in (com.example.abc) 2. Right-click on its plugin.xml and select 'Create Ant build file'. 3. Run the 'zip.plugin' target in the generated build.xml The com.example.abc_1.0.0.zip file created surprisingly contains the *.class  files in addition to the expected files.  The problem is that the *.jar.bin folder is not being deleted in the 'abc.jar'  target. The 'abc.jar' target should end with the following statement: <delete dir="${temp.folder}/abc.jar.bin"/>

title: SourceTests#testBug206679_247198 due to removal of "requires features" dependencies from JDT feature
desc: N20131026-1500.  SourceTests#testBug206679_247198 fails, saying  Processing inclusion from feature org.eclipse.jdt: Bundle org.eclipse.jdt_3.10.0.N20131026-1500 failed to resolve.: Missing required plug-in org.eclipse.ui.intro_[3.2.0,4.0.0). Missing required plug-in org.eclipse.ui.cheatsheets_[3.2.0,4.0.0).  /opt/users/hudsonbuild/workspace/ep4-unit-lin64/workarea/N20131026-1500/eclipse-testing/test-eclipse/eclipse/plugins/org.eclipse.pde.build_3.9.0.N20131026-1500/scripts/genericTargets.xml:111: Processing inclusion from feature org.eclipse.jdt: Bundle org.eclipse.jdt_3.10.0.N20131026-1500 failed to resolve.: Missing required plug-in org.eclipse.ui.intro_[3.2.0,4.0.0). Missing required plug-in org.eclipse.ui.cheatsheets_[3.2.0,4.0.0).   I verified that the failure is because we removed the following feature import from the JDT feature:     <requires>       <import feature="org.eclipse.platform" version="4.3.0" match="greaterOrEqual"/>    </requires>  However, ui.intro and ui.cheatsheet *are* directly required by the 'org.eclipse.jdt' plug-in, which is part of the JDT feature. According to  https://wiki.eclipse.org/Version_Numbering#To_require_features_or_to_require_bundles this should be OK, hence I suspect a bug in either the test itself or how PDE Build computes the dependencies.

title: We should not have empty performance targets
desc: See bug 442455 for more detail, but it is confusing (at best) for us to some tests marked as having performance tests, when they really don't.   From what I could see, the bundles below have an empty performance target. Would appreciate either removing the empty targets, or "comment them out" so they are not detected by the CBI-tool (and test framework) that mark them as "performance tests".     eclipse.pde.build/org.eclipse.pde.build.tests eclipse.pde.ui/ds/org.eclipse.pde.ds.tests

title: PDE feature does not require JDT feature
desc:
PDE feature does not require JDT feature. If you start with a base platform and install PDE feature, you get a portion of JDT installed since individual PDE bundles depend on various JDT bundles. This in turns causes a PDE Build malfunction that's exposed by the JDT compiler change in Neon M3 (Bug 478427).  Repro:  1. Create the build driver install by starting with Neon M3 platform and installing only org.eclipse.pde.feature.group on top of it.  2. Create a target install using platform, org.eclipse.jdt.feature.group plus any other features you might need.  3. Build a simple hello world plugin using PDE build driver from #1 against #2 target.  The build will fail similarly to this:  [java] @dot:      [java]     [mkdir] Created dir: d:\WS\40	runk
eon\plugins\oracle.eclipse.tools.webtier.trinidad.ui\@dot      [java]     [javac] Compiling 3 source files to d:\WS\40	runk
eon\plugins\oracle.eclipse.tools.webtier.trinidad.ui\@dot      [java]     [javac] Unable to load annotation processing manager org.eclipse.jdt.internal.compiler.apt.dispatch.BatchAnnotationProcessorManager from classpath.      [java]     [javac]       [java]     [javac] Compilation failed. Compiler errors are available in d:\WS\40	runk
eon\plugins\oracle.eclipse.tools.webtier.trinidad.ui/@dot.log      [java]       [java] BUILD FAILED  Now modify #1 by installing org.eclipse.jdt.feature.group and re-run step #3. The build will succeed now.

title: Need more arguments in pdecore generated scripts (1GJZV22)
desc: Users need to be able to spec the parameter for Javac etc.  The message below does not identify this praticular problem but does highlight a usecase.  "Eric Simpson" <esimpson@ca.ibm.com> wrote in message news:3B9D31DB.FE54D84F@ca.ibm.com... >  > When I build my component using Ant the class files are the same as > those generated in the PDE which, to me, means that they are debuggable > by default.  How can I specify in my component build that I want > non-debuggable? >  > The "javac" task will check for the "debug" and "optimize" attributes > but I think this is on the actual task which is specified in the PDE's > template.xml.  Setting a "debug" property to "off" and "optimize" to > "on" in my component's build script did not cause any change. >  > How is this done in regular Ant projects? >  > Thanks, > Eric >   NOTES:

title: Need to allow plug-ins to contribute custom build.xml
desc: In order to allow a greater freedom for building plug-ins, we need to allow them to contribute custom build.xml files. The build.xml file has to be in the plug-in root folder and the following entry has to be added to the build.properties file:  custom=yes

title: Brittle code on InitTemplate task
desc: The InitTemplate task uses a code pattern that the platform does not recommend  ISVs to use. It gets the URL for the template.xml file on the install  directory and calls getFile() on it. If the install location is not available  through the file system, this code will not work. We should change it to something more flexible.

title: change request for build.manifest
desc: See attached emails:  To:	Vlad Klicnik/Toronto/IBM@IBMCA cc:	  Subject:	Re: build manifest   Vlad, I believe that this would be a feature request to make of PDE Core. I verified with DJ that it is indeed PDE Core that creates this file and  not Releng. He knows of your request but you might want to send him mail or log a PR  just so it doesn't get lost.  /brian      klicnik@ca.ibm.com 12/14/01 12:56 PM            To:     Brian_Young@oti.com         cc:          Subject:        build manifest   Brian, I have just "discovered" (thanks to JW) the build.manifest you are  writing out and I would like to use it for self-hosting using the install/  update support ... it contains 99% of the information I was struggling to  get somehow.   The other 1% is a change request ....   Could you write out the build designation as a property so I can read it.  Currently it is written as a comment and the Java properties support  strips this off. I would like the 3 parts of the designator written out as  3 separate properties so I don't have to rely on the format of the string.  Ie. something like   build.type=I (or N or whatever other types you support)  build.id=20011206 (or whatever format you choose to use)  build.qualifier=20011206 (I actually don't understand what the second  stamp means, but whatever format you have is OK. Assume this is used to  spin failed builds).   This would allow me to do what I need. Let me know if you can do this.

desc: Build 20020307 I got the following stack trace when terminating a process.  java.lang.NullPointerException 	at org.eclipse.pde.internal.PDEPlugin$DebugListener.handleDebugEvent(PDEPlugin.java:99) 	at org.eclipse.debug.core.DebugPlugin.fireDebugEvent(DebugPlugin.java:199) 	at org.eclipse.debug.internal.core.RuntimeProcess.fireEvent(RuntimeProcess.java:204) 	at org.eclipse.debug.internal.core.RuntimeProcess.fireTerminateEvent(RuntimeProcess.java:212) 	at org.eclipse.debug.internal.core.RuntimeProcess.terminated(RuntimeProcess.java:181) 	at org.eclipse.debug.internal.core.ProcessMonitor.monitorProcess(ProcessMonitor.java:49) 	at org.eclipse.debug.internal.core.ProcessMonitor.access$0(ProcessMonitor.java:42) 	at org.eclipse.debug.internal.core.ProcessMonitor$1.run(ProcessMonitor.java:62) 	at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:536)

title: Create Plug-in jars fails ...
desc: Create Plug-in JARs fails on my system with the following entry in  p4eclipse.jar.bin.log:  This compilation unit indirectly references the missing type  org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Shell (typically some required class file is  referencing a type outside the classpath)  Unfortunately, the project org.eclipse.swt is included in the .classpath (as  well as in plugin.xml) and the generated build.xml seems to be also ok.  Eclipse Stable 2002-03-19 (but had that error for some versions)

title: template.xml should not use ${basedir} in jar and src targets
desc: build 20020319  Instead of using ${basedir} it should use some other property like ${srcdir}  or similar.

title: Create Plug-in JARs fails
desc: Using build 20020321.  Team code downloaded in workspace.  Build path in  project properties set to relevant jar files in plugins.  e.g.  for  org.eclipse.team.core, have resources.jar , runtime.jar and xerces.jar.    Builds from project build menu or ^B but when Create Plug-in JARs menu option  selected for plugin.xml I get Cannot find plugin: org.eclipse.core.runtime.  Exactly the same steps worked with the last stable build.

title: usage options for PDE Core and Ant applications
desc: The "-?" or "-help" option for the following applications do not display  anything or result in a null point exception.:   org.eclipse.pdeCore.buildScript  org.eclipse.pdeCore.fetchScript  org.eclipse.ant.core.antRunner   I am launching this applications by using a command line like this:   java -cp startup.jar org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main -data D:\eclipse0325 \eclipse\workspace2 -application org.eclipse.ant.core.antRunner -help  AND  java -cp startup.jar org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main D:\eclipse0325 \eclipse\workspace2  -application org.eclipse.pde.core.buildScript -?  java -cp startup.jar org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main D:\eclipse0325 \eclipse\workspace2  -application org.eclipse.pde.core.fetchScript -?  Am I supplying the wrong command line options?

title: Building a plugin where the workspace does not have all projects under the same folder
desc: Newsgroups:               eclipse.tools  I'm having a difficult time creating a build.xml through the PDE to get my plugin jar file build. I have the project created outside the default workspace hierarchy under Eclipse (to allow me to reinstall Eclipse without harming my projects). I've tried modifying build.properties every way that I can, but I still get the same message in the task window, after ant runs:  cannot find plugin: org.eclipse.swt  I included this as a dependecy in the Plugin Editor, but no luck, even after having Eclipse update my classpaths for me.  I'm running the 20020321 stable build. Any advice?  Thanks, bab

title: JDTCompiler adapter should be deprecated
desc: We should investigate using the compiler adapter provided by jdt.core and  remove the one from pde.core.

title: Fragment compile path does not include plug-in
desc: build 20020328  When creating a fragment with Java code that relies on code from the plug-in,  it gets compile error because the plug-in jars are not included in the compile  path. Should be fixed.

title: build.update.jar target creates jar file not compliant with the installation/update specification
desc: STEPS: 1. Create a feature called "myfeature" with PDe wizard 2. Right click on feature.xml, and create feature.jar 3. Right click on file build.xml that is created, "run with ant" and select  the "build.update.jar" target 4. Do a "Refresh from local" for the project   NOTICE: The target build.update.jar creates a feture jar that has the following in it: install\features\myfeature\feature.xml  The 2.0 installation/update specification requires the following to be in the  jar:   feature.xml The path "install\features\myfeature\" is not needed.

title: Add refreshLocal task to build scripts if running in Eclipse
desc: PDE Core build.xml scripts should call refreshLocal if running inside Eclipse.

title: [build] build.xml should allow omitting src.zip from plugin.zip
desc: Currently plugin.zip always builds *src.zip. How to omit this is a common question from plugin writers. The problem is build.xml does not support all of the options it provides. If you try to exclude the src zip, e.g., with "-Dxmleditorsrc.zip=no" the zip won't be built but gather.sources fails because it doesn't allow the zip to be missing.

title: Improving the creation of the feature.xml file
desc: In the current implementation, the feature.xml created as a result of the  BuildScriptGenerator (currently named generated.feature.xml) is created from  scratch and so loose any comment initially contained into the feature.xml.  A solution to this could be to use the updateVersion method (or some related  code) in order to directly replace the required value into the original  feature.xml file.

title: Reference to pde.core left behind
desc: build 20020409  There is a reference to org.eclipse.pde.core left behind on IPDECoreConstants  that breaks PDE Build. It should be renamed to org.eclipse.pde.build .

title: Nesting call of build.xml
desc: The nested calls of build.xml files causes generated files for the features to  be put at the wrong place with wrong names.  This is due to the fact that ant properties are immutable throughout a all run.  To be more precise:  build.xml starts by setting 5 properties (temp folder, feature full name,  feature version,...), and then calls the next build.xml that also sets the same  5 properties (which are then ignored).

title: Assemble.xml generation misses the src.zip
desc: Assemble.xml generation misses the src.zip, this should be fixed

title: Plugins built is done in the wrong order
desc: The order in which the compilation of plugins  is made from the feature is uncorrect. It needs to take into account the prerequisite  order between those.

title: NPE in fetch task
desc: build 20020411  Everytime you run the fetch task you get a NPE.
