title: [build] Add build.property setting for files that exist in root of install
desc: Please add a method by which files that should exist in root of install can be  copied from a feature, plugin or fragment.

title: Permissions of SWT files
desc: In the new build mechanism, the permissions are set either at the plugin level  or at the feature level according to the content of the permissions.properties  file.  However this is true only for generated build.xml, and it requires us to do  modifications into the hand crafted build.xml of swt, and probably of other  projects too.

title: Cannot build plug-ins that require SWT
desc: build 20020501  Because SWT is now fragmentized, the pde build classpath computation is  broken. It happens because the SWT libraries are declared in the plug-in but  the actual JARs are placed in the fragments. It breaks the current classpath  computation. A workaround is to edit the generated build.xml file and put the location of  the correct JARs on the javac task classpath.

title: Generating build.xml for Features always require a build.properties file
desc: build 20020501  Features, plug-ins and fragments are currently required to have a  build.properties file. It should not be the case.

title: Add extra classpath information to build.properties
desc: There are cases where we need extra classpath information in order to compile  plugins. The information is used defined by the requires clause in the  plugin.xml file. The usecase is a plugin contributing Ant tasks. The org.apache.ant plugin  cannot be declared in requires but ant.jar has to be in the compile path. The  trivial solution would be to provide a custom build.xml file. As it will be  the same scenario for every plug-in contributing Ant tasks, a solution  provided by PDE Build makes sense.

title: Remove type eclipse.stripMapper
desc: The Ant type eclipse.stripMapper is not used anymore and should be removed.

title: Add zip.plugin and zip.fragment
desc: In 1.0 we used to have a target in the build.xml that would generate a zip  file with the plug-in. The structure of the file contained a root folder with  the plug-in name and its resources inside. We should add it back with the following content:  <plugin_id)_<plugin_version>.zip   <plugin_id)_<plugin_version>     plugin.xml     ...     mylib.jar     mylibsrc.zip  This would make it easier to exchange simple plug-ins without requiring all  the install/update framework.

title: build.jars should include "init" in its depend clause
desc: build 20020508  In order to get the JDT compiler adapter when running in Eclipse, it is  necessary to include "init" in the depends clause of build.jars. Should also  investigate putting init in all other targets depends clause.

title: Property version in feature build.xml has to be renamed to feature.version
desc: build 20020508  Currently the version property in feature build.xml files and plugin build.xml  files have the same name "version". It causes a problem when building a  feature and all its children because the property is set in the feature  build.xml but cannot be overwritten in the plugin build.xml. So, all plugins  get the same version. A big mess...

title: Remove external zip functionality
desc: Currently it is possible to specify an external zip program to be used in  genereated build.xml files instead of the zip Ant task. It was implemented  because the releng Team needed that functionality. At the time only as little  as necessary was implemented in order to solve their problem so the  functionality is very limited. The Releng Team does not use that anymore so it has been around and untested  for a while. Given it is *very* limited in use, not very well tested and people can write  their own custom build scripts, the sugestion is to remove the functionality  from PDE Build.

title: Backport the description naming change of 2.1 into 2.2
desc: The target description of generated build.xml is now filled for the "public"  target.

title: Wrong zipfile name in a feature's zip.folder target
desc: Build: I-20030218 In the "zip.folder" target of a feature's build.xml,  <zip zipFile="${zipname}" .../>  should instead read <zip zipFile="${feature.destination}/${zipname}" .../>

title: introduce src/ subdirectory in plug-ins for source code zips
desc: (not sure whether this is pde.build or releng script)  When source code zips for a feature are extracted into a separate source code plug-in, there should all be under a directory named "src".   I.e., structure should look like:  <plug-in root>/   src/     id_version/        libsrc.zip     id_version/        libsrc.zip

title: Wrong build file generated when $os$ variables are specified
desc: The build file generated for a plugin or a fragment which uses $os$, $ws$, etc.  in its library name is bogus.  Indeed the variables are not expanded and so instead results in the creation of  folders called $os.  The solution consists in replacing carefully the appearance of those values  into the build.xml.  Here is an example of a bogus target:  <target name="$os$/win32.jar" depends="init" unless="$os$/win32.jar"  description="Create jar: $os$/win32.jar.">   <property name="destdir" value="${temp.folder}/$os$/win32.jar.bin"/>   <delete dir="${temp.folder}/$os$/win32.jar.bin"/>   <mkdir dir="${temp.folder}/$os$/win32.jar.bin"/>   ... </target>

title: Support for other repository
desc: The fetch script generator used in the builder should be able to handle several  repositories to fetch from.  Jeff proposed the following solutions: - build and skip the fetch step so assume that everything required has been  fetched by some other means - replace the entire fetch portion in the customtargets.xml - make the fetch generator pluggable so support different repos and update the  map file format to put different values for the repo-specific slots.  The  generator would then generate script content depending on the repo involved.  The last one seems to be the most clean.

title: [doc] Need to describe how to ship plugins as jars
desc: I want to export a library plugin as a jar without nested jars.  If I use the normal convention of bin and src sub-dirs within the project, this seems impossible.  The only way I could get this to work is if the project root is also source and output root.  However, it is then difficult to eclude or include .java src files at will in the exported plugin.  Since NOT nesting jars is more efficient for jar-ed plugins, there should be better support for creating such.  Some things which would be rather easy in plain ant build.xml are simply impossible using the PDE.  For example, file patterns for what to include in the output plugin jar.  Also, the ability to add a subtree of project dir with a different path prefix within the resulting plugin jar  Potential problems / issues:  1) a way to use separate source and output dirs within a project while still supporting the creation of a plugin jar without nested jars.  Currently I cannot seem to avoid "bin/com/..../foo.class" as the path within the plugin jar. 2) This might be implemented by allowing bin (or other) includes to specify a custom prefix path within the output jar. 3) Allow ant-style (and/or regex) filtering for build includes.  Maybe I want everything in a subtree to wind up in the output, EXCEPT for a few file patterns 4) Make more of this the default.  I seems that it would be good to have new plugin projects default to generating OSGi style manifests and setting the necessary options to NOT create nested jars.

title: For Win32 icon branding, PDE headless product build expects plugins folders to match bundle ids, while PDE UI export does not
desc: Build ID: M20060921-0945  Steps To Reproduce: 1. Create a Hello RCP plugin  A using a Hello RCP wizard 2. Create another plugin B (like an non java plugin) and copy the icons from plugin A to this plugin. Adjust the build.properties of this plugin to include the copied icon folder. 3. Rename the plugin project B such that the folder project name is different from the bundle symbolic name 4. create a product conf file for plugin a, adda name, product id (create new product id),select the right application, and update the launcher tab such that the launcher icon for win32 comes from the plugin.b icons folder  5. export product using the PDE ui. verify that the launcher icon has been proerply customized. (ie is greenish looking)  6. setup a simepl pde build envt for that product (see attached releng using a properly patched buildProduc.xml script and sample build.properties). The built product icon is still the standard eclipse icon, not the greensish customized icon.  The workaround is simple: the plugin b projectname and folder should match the bundle id. However this can be confusing at times, since when the export is triggered rom the UI, the lookup is done properly . Both the PDE UI export AND the PDE healess build should have the same behavior.  More information: I am attching a zip with sample projects that reproduce the problem

title: Compile from build.xml fails, need compiler error output
desc: 2.1RC2, Linux/Motif using Sun JDK 1.4.0  In my plug-in project, I right-click on the plugin.xml and select "create Ant build file". I run Ant on the created build.xml and choose the target that builds the plug-in's JAR file (not the default one). This target runs javac and the following output appears in the Console view:         [javac] done 82/82 : /project/cubranic/workspace/foo/src/bar/Bla.java        [javac] 82 units compiled        [javac] Compiled 12219 lines in 3856 ms (3168.8 lines/s)        [javac] 146 .class files generated        [javac] Compile failed; see the compiler error output for details.  There are no compile errors in the Task window when I compile from the IDE and the plugin runs fine.  Two questions: where can I find the compiler output so that I can start tracking down why the Ant compile failed? And is it possible to avoid the compile in the first place, when I have my classes already build in bin directory?

title: Error reporting on the absence of boot and runtime
desc: When generating a build script, if boot or runtime is missing, an NPE is  reported. This should be captured and report the appropriate message.

title: Provide a utility that extracts a repo in simili runnable form
desc: In order to address build issues, we need to have a utility mostly targeted at PDE Build, that will take a repo and create a format that can be compiled against.

title: [log] Better handling of errors on state build
desc: If something goes wrong while building the state (for example a bogus version number or a typo in the manifest), the build fails and some exceptions are log.  However this is not great because nothing is clearly indicated to the user regarding the plugin that caused the failure. See for example bug #68047.

title: Create new fetch factory for p2 IUs
desc: We need to create a new fetch factory for p2 IUs so we can have a map file entry that points to an IU and it will be retrieved from a p2 repository and can be part of the build.

title: Features/plugins from target are not exposed
desc: in i0118  If I have a feature in my target I cannot use the feature editor to add it to  the includes list (does not show up in the Add... list).  This is problematic  for people trying to construct and then export feature structures.

title: [patch] Follow-up: consolidate copies of ProductFile and BrandingIron
desc: Some of the consolidation between p2 and pde.build could not be applied due to the upcoming simulateous release. The bundle org.eclipse.equinox.p2.publisher.eclipse contains the consolidated versions of ProductFile and BrandingIron, but pde.build does not use them yet. (Consolidated means that they contain all functionality required by p2 and pde.build).  We should complete the consolidation early in 3.8: - Delete the copies of ProductFile and BrandingIron in org.eclipse.pde.build - Adapt the pde.build code to use the equivalent classes from p2  These steps are the inverse of commit https://github.com/jglander/eclipse-publisher-refactoring/commit/8ded64286183c4f50ebb993d0fd5ffcae57d3944

title: Test failures due to expired keystore
desc: The certificate is also expired in the 3.7.x branch so it will have to be regenerated.  +++ This bug was initially created as a clone of Bug #363720 +++  There are test failures in the latest builds because the keystore in the tests has expired. I'll generate a new one.

title: Support to build/ package multiple platforms at once.
desc: It could good to support the buildling and packaging of multiple platforms at once. For example I want one zip including all the necessary plugins for windows and linux.

title: Delta pack is not generated properly with pde build from N20050310-0010
desc: If I use the pde build from N20050310-0010 in org.eclipse.releng.basebuilder to run a test build building the delta fails with the following message  Build N20050310-1339 (Timestamp: 200503101339):  The following error occurred while executing this line: /builds/N/eclipseInternalBuildTools/all.xml:99: The following error occurred while executing this line: /builds/N/org.eclipse.releng.basebuilder/plugins/org.eclipse.pde.build_3.1.0/scripts/build.xml:24: The following error occurred while executing this line: /builds/N/org.eclipse.releng.basebuilder/plugins/org.eclipse.pde.build_3.1.0/scripts/build.xml:88: The following error occurred while executing this line: /builds/N/org.eclipse.releng.eclipsebuilder/rcp.deltapack/customTargets.xml:9: The following error occurred while executing this line: /builds/N/org.eclipse.releng.basebuilder/plugins/org.eclipse.pde.build_3.1.0/scripts/genericTargets.xml:132: The following error occurred while executing this line: /builds/N/src/assemble.org.eclipse.launchers.all.xml:4: The following error occurred while executing this line: /builds/N/org.eclipse.releng.eclipsebuilder/rcp.deltapack/customTargets.xml:25: The following error occurred while executing this line: /builds/N/org.eclipse.releng.eclipsebuilder/rcp.deltapack/customTargets.xml:31: The following error occurred while executing this line: /builds/N/org.eclipse.releng.basebuilder/plugins/org.eclipse.pde.build_3.1.0/scripts/package.xml:60: The following error occurred while executing this line: /builds/N/org.eclipse.releng.basebuilder/plugins/org.eclipse.pde.build_3.1.0/scripts/package.xml:42: org.eclipse.core.runtime.CoreException: Unable to find plug-in: org.eclipse.platform.source.linux.gtk.ppc_3.1.0. Please check the error log for more details.  The problem is that the generated package.all.xml generates assemble scripts for all architectures.  The delta pack should only include the following architectures as listed in the  org.eclipse.releng.eclipsebuilder/rcp.deltapack/scripts/packager.properties  config=win32, win32, x86 & \     linux, gtk, x86 & \ 	linux, gtk, x86_64 & \ 	linux, motif, x86 & \ 	solaris, motif, sparc & \ 	solaris, gtk, sparc & \ 	aix, motif, ppc & \ 	hpux, motif, PA_RISC & \ 	macosx, carbon, ppc  In our customTargets.xml for our sdk builds, we include several assemble scripts  that are created but not called.  For example  <target name="assemble.org.eclipse.sdk.hpux.motif.ia64" /> <target name="assemble.org.eclipse.sdk.linux.gtk.ppc64" /> <target name="assemble.org.eclipse.sdk.linux.gtk.ppc" /> <target name="assemble.org.eclipse.sdk.linux.gtk.ia64" />  <target name="assemble.org.eclipse.sdk.aix.motif.ppc"> 	<property name="archiveName" value="eclipse-SDK-${buildId}-aix-motif.tar.gz"/>	 	<antcall target="assemble" /> </target>  This is allows us to include assemble scripts in source builds for people who are compiling eclipse on platforms that we do not have access to.    I'll attach the package.all.xml for reference.

title: tarargs should be before -cvf in AssembleConfigScript generator
desc: The value of tarargs should be before -cvf in the AssembleConfig ScriptGenerator This is because if -cvf needs to have an archiveName immediately after it.  This is an error on my part, I gave the wrong answer to your question when you implemented it.   I'll attach a patch.

title: generated unzipper.xml does not work correctly (-x /features)
desc: I am using the PDE packaging tool. If I have specified a platform specific zip in all.maps, this zip is unzipped  twice, once into tempdirectory/eclipse and once into  tempdirectory/win32.win32.x86/eclipse. This unzip is performed using ANT's exec function to call an unzip executable  on the path. The unzip is called in the (generated) unzipper.xml When the unzip into the win32.win32.x86 directory is called, it is to extract  the platform specific files for packaging, so it uses  <arg line="-x /features/* /plugins/*"/> unfortunately, the zip in question looks like this: features/com.ibm.a_1.0.0/feature.xml (no leading slashes) so nothing gets excluded. in fact the build output notes this (although it took me a couple runs to  notice the problem) [pack-test/package/exec]    [exec] caution: excluded filename not  matched: /features/*  In and of itself this would not be a huge problem, but in combination with  https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=100460 it means that everything gets packaged.  all plugins and all features (which  come from a zip flagged as platform specific), since the generated package  script zips **/**  With this combination of defects, the packager loses its ability to choose  which features to package.

title: Source plug-in generation fails with pre-built plug-ins in baseLocation
desc: The generation of the platform.source plug-in fails when I try building with pre-built jars in the baseLocation (i.e. com.ibm.icu).  The generated build.xml script for platform.source fails on the following:  <ant antfile="build.xml" dir="../../baseLocation/plugins/com.ibm.icu_3.4.2.jar" target="gather.sources">                         <property name="destination.temp.folder" value="${basedir}/src"/> </ant>  Here is the error message: /builds/eclipsebuilder/src/plugins/org.eclipse.platform.source/build.xml:119: Basedir /builds/eclipsebuilder/src/baseLocation/plugins/com.ibm.icu_3.4.2.jar is not a directory

title: version of pde.build.tests in 3.7.x stream needs to be incremented
desc: From build M20111212-1000  The version "1.1.100.R37x_v20111117" of plugin "org.eclipse.pde.build.tests" in feature (id: "org.eclipse.sdk.tests";version: "3.7.0.r37x_v20111117-9IANGMyFlf1aGo4neGy5rW-cBNQU"; is lower than its version "1.1.100.v20110512-1320" in feature (id: "org.eclipse.sdk.tests";version: "3.6.0.v20110503-9IABGJNFmYz-5yDIHEXJjabfw7R5";

title: Export of product based on feature fails on optional includes
desc: The export of a product based on a feature fails if that feature contains an optionally included feature when it is not present, i.e.     <includes          id="org.eclipse.platform.launchers"          version="0.0.0"          optional="true"/>

title: Write access problems with multi platform delta pack installed
desc: Hi,  we have installed Eclipse 3.1.1/3.1.2 both in a Sun Solaris8 and RedHat Enterprise Linux 3.0 environemnt. When exporting a product (like the simple wizard created RCP examples) via the product export wizard this seems to work as long as the rcp delta pack has not been installed. As soon as this is installed, the export tries to write into the eclipse installation.  Error Message (in a window):  Problems during export:  Could not write  /opt/eclipse/features/org.eclipse.platform.launchers_3.1.2//build.xml  In order to offer eclipse to a larger audience of users, we have installed it under root privileges on a file system which is read only for the users (just as we do with all sorts of compilers and other tools). We try the product export under standard user privileges.  So we would like to know how exactly to install eclipse in a multi-user environemnt. If this turns out to be a bug, is there a workaround, that does not require us to install eclipse (or parts like the launchers and plugins) in the user accounts.  Thanks in advance  Frank-Oliver Malisch

title: Export of product to solaris produces corrupt executable file
desc: I'm running into trouble when trying to export an RCP application on SPARC Solaris 8.   That's what I do: New Plug-In Project ->RCP checkbox enabled ->choose Hello RCP New Product Configuration for this Project use eclipse Product Export Wizard ->Export Destination is a Directory, compiler options are both 5.0  ->Export for multiple Platforms->Checkbox solaris(motif/sparc) enabled   The export on the Solaris8 platform completed without an error-message. But when I try to run the program the behavior is as follows:  $ ./eclipse ./eclipse: Exec format error. Binary file not executable.  $ file eclipse eclipse:        data  Obviously the executable created during the export is not a valid SPARC binary.  I use Eclipse 3.1.2 with eclipse.buildId=I20050401-1645 eclipse-RCP-3.1.2-delta-pack  I use Eclipse3.1.2 on SPARC Solaris as well as under RedHat Enterprise Linux 3.0 (x86) The behavior when exporting an application for the SPARC Solaris platform is identical on both platforms.  Any help would be apreciated.

title: [doc] Packager template files are missing
desc: I thought we has template files for the packager however they don't seem to be in the template folder of 3.2, nor in of 3.1. In any case it would be good to have some for 3.2.

title: Generated jnlp files should filter resources on architecture
desc: 3.2M6  The generated jnlp files have lines like the following:  <resources os="Linux">   <jar href="plugins/org.eclipse.gtk.linux.x86"/>   <jar href="plugins/org.eclipse.gtk.linux.ppc"/> </resources>  However when jws tries to download the files on a x86 linux box, the operation fails because the ppc fragment is not on the server.  In fact, here the second "jar" should be in a resources section of its own where arch is also specified: <resources os="Linux" arch="PowerPC"/>  Since we are at it, we should check if the resources tag has a window system attribute and if not we should enter a bug report against sun.

title: [doc] Provide an example of an RCP app build
desc: It would be good to find a way to provide people with an example of a small RCP app build. Maybe should we add an example in the example SDK.

title: Need to make a link inside Eclipse.app bundle
desc: In order to fix bug#53260, we need to create a link as follows:  platform-launcher   bin     carbon        macosx          ppc            Eclipse.app               Contents                   MacOS                      eclipse                   Resources                      Splash.app                         Contents                           MacOS -> ../../../MacOS  After CVS checkout the directory "....../Eclipse.app/Contents/Resources/Splash.app/Contents" exists already. We only need the link "MacOS" pointing to "../../../MacOS".

title: Add .ignore files for bin folders of example projects
build.properties bootclasspath default too restrictive
desc: The default value of the property "bootclasspath" is set to only rt.jar. This restricts all plugins to building only against rt.jar.  If bootclasspath was commented out, then PDE Build would generate a build.xml for each plugin and builds up the classpath to include all accessible libraries in the JRE.  Basically our IDE build had no problem building. When we switched to the headless build, we couldn't figure out why we had all these undefined errors against the JAVA libraries. We tracked it down to "bootclasspath" being set to only rt.jar. If bootclasspath is defined when PDE Build is generating the plugins' build.xml files, it skips the automatic generation of bootclasspath.

title: Category generation is not done when building an update site
desc: When using the "build site" command to build an update site from within the IDE, the resulting content.jar does not have categories.

title: Please build the localbuild.xml as part of an incremental build too
desc: It's hard to get this and downstream projects error free without that.  I current have setup tasks to make these changes automatically, but that leaves the Git repository dirty which isn't ideal.

title: Fix files that have ended up with CRLF in the git repository
desc: This is related to   https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=550585  Here only the files EGit complained about being dirty at that time were fixed.  Now I have a tool that fixes all text files containing CRLF so I will apply that to PDE's Git repositories to fix all the issues via Gerrit.

title: RCP: Can't Export an Eclipse product when Eclipse for Commiters install path contains space
desc: I can't Export an Eclipse product when Eclipse for Commiters install path contains space.  Steps to reproduce: - fresh Oxygen.2 installed in "C:\eclipse\eclipse dev" or "/opt/ecli pse" - fresh workspace - Create new Plug-in Project - Select yes on Would you lite to create a rich client application - Select Eclipse 4 RCP application - Finish - Open .product file - Export an Eclipse product  Failed to export  Problem is this line http://git.eclipse.org/c/pde/eclipse.pde.build.git/tree/org.eclipse.pde.build/src/org/eclipse/pde/internal/build/properties/PDEProperties.java?id=853d53ec6d5413b5811e3627ee41bed49c912416#n54 which may be replaced by  result = (URIUtil.toFile(URIUtil.toURI(FileLocator.toFileURL(foundEntry)))).getAbsolutePath();  Console log error: !ENTRY org.eclipse.pde.build 4 3 2018-03-19 20:03:29.738 !MESSAGE Illegal character in path at index 14: file:/opt/ecli pse/plugins/org.eclipse.pde.build_3.9.300.v20170515-0912/./ !STACK 0 java.net.URISyntaxException: Illegal character in path at index 14: file:/opt/ecli pse/plugins/org.eclipse.pde.build_3.9.300.v20170515-0912/./ 	at java.net.URI$Parser.fail(URI.java:2848) 	at java.net.URI$Parser.checkChars(URI.java:3021) 	at java.net.URI$Parser.parseHierarchical(URI.java:3105) 	at java.net.URI$Parser.parse(URI.java:3053) 	at java.net.URI.<init>(URI.java:588) 	at java.net.URL.toURI(URL.java:946) 	at org.eclipse.pde.internal.build.properties.PDEProperties.getAntPropertyValue(PDEProperties.java:54) 	at org.eclipse.ant.core.Property.getValue(Property.java:123) 	at org.eclipse.ant.core.Property.getValue(Property.java:86) 	at org.eclipse.pde.internal.core.exports.FeatureExportOperation.createAntBuildProperties(FeatureExportOperation.java:436) 	at org.eclipse.pde.internal.core.exports.ProductExportOperation.createAntBuildProperties(ProductExportOperation.java:316) 	at org.eclipse.pde.internal.core.exports.FeatureExportOperation.doExport(FeatureExportOperation.java:251) 	at org.eclipse.pde.internal.core.exports.ProductExportOperation.run(ProductExportOperation.java:106) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.jobs.Worker.run(Worker.java:56)

title: [build] Build fails with generated feature build.xml target "zip.logs"
desc: I get a "Build Exception" when trying to invoke this target. The log file could  not be found.  It is not possible to collect log files from a feature or plugin build. It  seems that there is a logical error in all generated build.xml. I even don't  know if logfiles where created during the build.

title: Cannot easily use javac
desc: 920  I would like to use javac instead of the eclipse provided compiler to build my  plugin jars.  However, I am encountering two problems:  1. I must remove the setting of the build.compiler preference: <property name="build.compiler"  value="org.eclipse.jdt.core.JDTCompilerAdapter"/>  2. the javac adaptor behaves differently on the bootclasspath attribute than  JDTCompilerAdaptor, so I must delete bootclasspath="${bootclasspath}" from the  javac task.  1. I expect the javac adaptor and the jdt adaptor to be interchangeable.  2. I would like to be able to change from using javac adaptor to jdt adaptor  without changing every script (can we pass in properties for this?)

title: [build] PDE Build only supports building 'in-place'
desc: PDE Build Ant scripts have a hard-coded dependency on building plug-ins,  fragments and features 'in-place'. In other words, they expect that targets to  build are in a raw of directories, that each plugin/fragment/feature directory  contains a script and that source code is also in these directories.  When build is to be used in the workspace, this causes problems.  All the generated libraries and build artifacts are created in development  projects, immediately causing Team to create 'Not in version control' info  tasks.  PDE team tried to modify the way scripts are created by adding support for  alternative build script location. However, we now realize that it was just the  tip of the iceberg :-). The generated scripts themselves make assumptions about  their position and position of child scripts (in case of features) relative to  themselves.  Ideally, scripts would be configurable so that they would be able to accept non- default locations. For example, in our Update Site builder, we have a separate  Update Site project that has a folder devoted to building artifacts. We wanted  to create scripts there, run them indirectly (so that temp.folder is created  there as well) and redirect plugin and feature output into the  dedicated 'plugins' and 'features' folder in the site. At the moment, we cannot  because feature scripts make assumptions about the locations of the plugin  scripts, and plugin scripts think they are in plugin root directories.  Conclusion: plugin and feature Ant scripts should be configurable so that it is  possible to place build scripts and run them outside of the plugin/feature  directories. The goal is to only reference plugins and features and redirect  all the generated files and folders elsewhere.

title: Checking the version numbers of the required elements
desc: When a feature is compiled against an existing version of eclipse (or other  features), it might be interested to check that the elements listed in the  <requires> section are corresponding (with the matching rule) to the one found  into the version we are compiling against.

title: Compiling against an installed version of eclipse does not support links
desc: The new pde build mecanism allows to compile against an installed version of  eclipse.  This can be improved in handling the sites that are referenced into the links  directory. The implementation of this feature will avoid people to copy their features and  plugins of the referenced site when they want to build against those.

title: Improving the compilation against multiple versions of the same plugin
desc: Currently, we are not sure that we can correctly build a product where the  same plugin is required with two different version numbers...  For example xerces 4.0.5 can be required by plugin A and plugin B may require 4.0.7 and this is still a correct fact.

title: Using ant zip in the assemble scripts
desc: Since the new version of Ant (1.5.2) seems to be able to preserve the  permissions of files when zipping and unzipping, it might be interesting (for a  sake of portability, and also speed) to use this instead of the zip command.  It needs to be checked that it handles all the links correctly.  Note that the copy command might have updated to, and could be used to.

title: Building and assembling of plugins / features
desc: The new build mechanism is feature driven to build and assemble. This results in difficulties when someone want to ship a product which is only  a set of plugins and is not driven by a feature.  This limitation should be alleviated to enable people to build and assemble  anything that they want to "ship" together.

title: Source code location
desc: The new build structure always bundle the source into a source plugin. Although this does not cause any problem, it could be interesting to have an  option to specify that the source should be included directly near by the bin.

title: More flexibility building a plugin/fragment
desc: With the new build mechanism, the flexibility in adding custom steps is only  provided at the level of the build.xml which is to big grain.  It could be interesting to provide a support for customTargets at the plugin  level.   Because you do not want to have to write empty customTargets, a good solution  seems to provide in the build.properties a customTargets property. If the property is false, no call the customTargets are done, otherwise calls  to a customTarget provided by the user are done.  If we go a step further, the customTargets is indeed a "replacement" for the  property custom.

title: Ensure composability of targets
desc: The generated build.xml provides a lot of targets. We should ensure that all the targets work properly together allowing people to  compose them.

title: [build] more flexibility in setting buildLabel
desc: Currently buildLabel is being used as both a place to assemble eclipse drops  as well as collect the resulting zip files.  It would be nice to have a  separate assembling/working directory to run the assemble scripts.

title: [Packager] Support for the packaging of side application
desc: Since Eclipse recommand that applications should be provided in a separate  directory structure (with eclipse as a base), the packager should propose  support for this.  Here is an example of such a structure, MyBigApp comes with an regular eclipse  and "anApp" and "anApp2".  MyBigApp   eclipse/         .config/ 	.eclipseproduct     	cpl-v10.html 	eclipse.exe 	features/ 	plugins/                   	install.ini 	links/ 	        com.ibm.rcp.link      		com.ibm.application1.link 		         	com.ibm.application2.link    anApp/ 	eclipse/ 	        .eclipseextension  	        features/ 	        plugins/    anApp2/ 	eclipse/ 	        features/ 		plugins/

title: gather.bin.parts does not gather everything
desc: Exporting plug-ins fail using the pde.build R_3_0_ early acess and the  compatible pde.ui v20030602_newpdebuild.  If you create a hello world plug-in and try to export it, the library xyz.jar  does not get packaged.  That is because the line indicated below (or an  equivalent line) does not get generated by the new pde.build.  In 2.1, the gather.bin.parts target used to contain the line: <copy file="${build.result.folder}/xyz.jar" todir="${destination.temp.folder}/ ${full.name}"/>  Post-2.1, the line above is missing, and only libraries in ${basedir} are  gathered.  Keep in mind when you generate the scrips that $build.result.folder and  $plugin.destination can have values other than $basedir, and do not make the  assumption about their values.

title: Can't export features
desc: PDE build: v20030623   PDE ui: branch R_3_0_newbuild  1. Create two hello world plug-in projects. 2. Create a feature project (com.example.feature) that contains the two plug- ins in 1. 3. Try to export the feature as zip with source.  You will get an error  complaining about some weird path name.  The error is due to the fact that the script generated prepends ${basedir} to  paths all over the place, particularly in targets zip.distribution,  build.update.jar, zip.sources.  Every path that contains $feature.temp.folder  is prepended by $basedir/.   So when we pass an absolute path as a value for  $feature.temp.folder as we do during export, the script chokes when $basedir/  is prepended to such an absolute path.  The script generated should not assume that $feature.temp.folder is a path  relative path to $basedir.  $feature.temp.folder can be any absolute path.

title: compiled jars missing debug information
desc: Despite setting the Ant property javacDebugInfo=true, the compiled jars are  missing debug information.  Not sure if the debuglevel attribute needs to be  set explicitly in Ant 1.5.  Olivier is testing the jdt core Ant adapter to  ensure it is doing the right thing when debug=true is set.

title: Generated feature's build.xml needs to restore feature.destination variable
desc: pde build: R_3_0_early_access   pde ui: R_3_0_newbuild  When the build.xml for a feature is generated, ${basedir} is used all over the  place (targets: build.update.jar, clean, zip.distribution, zip.sources,  zip.logs), making the assumption that everything is happening at the feature's  root location in the workspace. A feature's build.xml needs to restore the ${feature.destination} variable  that was available in 2.1, and is equivalent to ${plugin.destination} that is  still available in plug-ins' build.xml scripts.   Substituting ${feature.destination} for ${basedir} would make the build  scripts flexible enough for exporting features to be possible.

title: plugin.xml-created ant file has dependencies to jarfiles, build.result.folder missing in classpath
desc: Ciao,   when creating an ant file from a plugin(.xml), some variables are introduced.   I changed temp.folder and build.result.folder to gain performance with the  CM-System. The problem is that in the plugin several jars are built and when  jarfile b.jar is compiled (needs a.jar), it won't find a.jar in the classpath  since the classpath-entry in build.xml simply says "...:a.jar:...", which has  been built in "${build.result.folder}/a.jar". The fix would be to add  ${build.result.folder}/ to the local jar file entries in the classpath

title: retrieve.xml hard codes tags specified in directory.txt
desc: The retrieve.xml should use a property called "tag" instead of hard coded  values for tags taken from the directory.txt.  The problem is that if in nightly builds the tag property value is set to HEAD  and the HEAD content of a feature.xml differs from that specified in the tag  in the directory.txt, the resulting fetch*.xml script may not be correct.  For  example, if the HEAD stream contents of a feature include an extra plugin,  then an entry for the new plugin is not contained in the fetch script.

title: SWT source not shipped with Linux-GTK
desc: Build 20030703 and 20030710  It looks like the SWT source isn't being shipped with the Linux-GTK builds.

title: build.update.jar does not keep logs
desc: Build: I-20030715 In the case of errors during the execution of the build.update.jar target of a  build.xml, no *.bin.log files are kept in a temp folder for the user to  inspect. Execution of this target should behave like build.jars, where log files are  generated and kept for the user to inspect, should anything go wrong.

title: [publisher] product publisher cannot find config.ini file
desc: This might not be a problem in head, but rather only a problem in Bug #260066, But I thought I would open it to track the issue.  It would seem that the publisher has the following logic regarding looking up config.ini files.  If the file location is absolute, no problem.   If the file location is relative, it looks relative to the .product file.  However, default PDE tooling doesn't do either of these things.  Default PDE tooling sets the config.ini file relative to the workspace root.    Currently we don't properly find the file

title: Add category file support to FeaturesAndBundlesTask
desc: To support categories, we need to add support for category files in PDE Build.  In particular, we need to add a flag to the FeaturesAndBundlesTask.

title: Product with no version fails to export
desc: A product file that does not specify a version currently fails to export with metadata.  Director error message is something like: Software being installed: org.eclipse.equinox.p2.reconciler.dropins.product 0.0.0 Missing requirement for filter (& (osgi.ws=win32) (osgi.os=win32) (osgi.arch=x86)): org.eclipse.equinox.p2.reconciler.dropins.product 0.0.0 requires 'org.eclipse.equinox.p2.reconciler.dropins.product_root.win32.win32.x86 [0.0.0]' but it could not be found!

title: [publisher] eclipse.publish.featuresAndBundles compression option does not work
desc: I use 		  <eclipse.publish.featuresAndBundles  			artifactrepository="${p2.artifact.repo}"  			artifactrepositoryname="${p2.artifact.repo.name}" 			metadatarepository="${p2.metadata.repo}"  			metadatarepositoryname="${p2.metadata.repo.name}" 			site="file:${siteXmlLocation}" 			categoryVersion="${p2.category.version}" 			compress="${p2.compress}" />  in the postBuild callback to push a version for my category into the P2 repo generated by the PDE build. The build itself creates compressed (jar-ed) metadata (when I leave out this call) and uses the property ${p2.compress} as well.  I also verified that ${p2.compress} is set to true right before the eclipse.publish.featuresAndBundles call, but afterwards I end up with uncompressed content.xml & artifacts.xml instead of content.jar & artifacs.jar

title: build should not fail if there are no rootfiles to zip in assembly phase
desc: The build fails when there is no entry "root=" for a component.  The failure  appears related to a target that is generated that tries to gather files from  a non-existent directory ANY.ANY.ANY.

title: root files zipped up in wrong location when collBase and collPlace are the same
desc: When building GEF components, the root files are zipped into a different  archive\location than where the plugins and features are zipped when collBase  and collPlace have the same value, ie. "."    - <exec executable="zip" dir="${basedir}/${buildLabel}/${collBase}">   <arg line="-r -q ${zipargs} ${archiveName}" />    <arg line="${collPlace}/features/org.eclipse.gef.source_2.1.1" />    </exec> - <exec executable="zip" dir="${basedir}/${buildLabel}/${collBase}">   <arg line="-r -q ${zipargs} ${archiveName}" />    <arg line="${collPlace}/features/org.eclipse.gef.sdk_2.1.1" />    <arg line="${collPlace}/features/org.eclipse.gef_2.1.1" />    </exec> - <exec executable="zip" dir="${feature.base}/ANY.ANY.ANY/${collBase}">   <arg line="-r -q ${zipargs} ../../${archiveName} ." />    </exec>

title: eclipse ant adapter should not hard-code the compiler warning
desc: Using the new compilerarg nested element of a javac task, it is possible to provide compiler specific argument on javac task. There is no need anymore to hard-code the warnings inside the eclipse javac ant adapter. They could be passed as a compilerarg element. Here is an example: ... <property name="build.compiler" value="org.eclipse.jdt.core.JDTCompilerAdapter"/> .... <javac srcdir="${root}" destdir="${destdir}" nowarn="on" deprecation="off" source="1.3" debug="off" verbose="on">     <classpath>       <pathelement location="${basedir}/../org.eclipse.jdt.core/bin"/>     </classpath>     <compilerarg compiler="org.eclipse.jdt.core.JDTCompilerAdapter" line="-warn:indirectStatic"/> </javac>  Of course compilerarg elements need to be consistent with other javac task settings. The compilerarg are used only if the compiler name correspond to the compiler option of the javac task or the build.compiler property if no compiler is set. This allows compiler specific options to be set and the same script to be used by simply changing the build.compiler property.

title: default setting for javacTarget property should be 1.2
desc: With the move to 1.4 level jdk's for Eclipse builds, the javacTarget value  should be set to 1.2 cf. 1.1 in the generated build.xml scripts to coincide  with the default javac 1.4 compiler settings.

title: Test failures in I20180301-2000
desc: In today's build http://download.eclipse.org/eclipse/downloads/drops4/I20180301-2000/testresults/html/org.eclipse.pde.build.tests_ep48I-unit-cen64-gtk2_linux.gtk.x86_64_8.0.html  there are md5 mismatches.

title: [Doc] referencing a non existing property
desc: In the doc jars.build.order should be jars.compile.order

title: Fragments' JAR files are not independent within the same feature
desc: I have a feature with several fragments. As all the fragments are NLS plugins, I decided to call its JAR file: nls.jar All the fragments have the same JAR name.  When I export the feature with the wizard all fragments have the nls.jar file from the last fragment within the feature. So the workaround is to name each JAR file of each fragment within the same feature with different names; for example nls1.jar, nls2.jar..... then it works.  Althought the workaround is really easy, I understand at deployment time each fragment or plugin should be independent. For example, all of them have a file called fragment.xml and this one is not overwritten by the last one. The same should happen with the JAR file.  I understand this is a bug.

title: Option to build equinox drops
desc: If Equinox is moving further, the builder will have to provide a flag to  support building of bundles, so both legacy plugins and new plugins can be built

title: Provide an option to run native2ascii on plugin build
desc: When developing internationalized plug-ins it is useful to use native2ascii on  the file, but we should still use the native encoding on the source file.   Perhaps it is possible to add an option in the build.properties to run  native2ascii.  Also, add an option which source language to use, or to use the  workspace default encoding.

title: API to set the build.properties file name, and to set the build.xml file name
desc: The Update component needs two new APIs on the build script generator: 1. a setter to set the name of the properties file to be read.  Currently, the  assumption is that the file is called build.properties.  We would like the  script to execute on a file name of our choosing.  2. a setter on the name of the build script to be generated.  Currently, the  assumption is that the script is called build.xml.  Again, we would like the  liberty to give the file a name of our choosing.

title: Building a fragment that has requires fail
desc: Building a fragment that has a requirement that is not part of the fragmented  plugin may cause the fragment compilation to fail.  Example org.eclipse.core.runtime   requires: xerces, boot  org.eclipse.core.runtime.fragment   requires: org.eclipse.other.stuffs  org.eclipse.other.stuffs  In this case, runtime.fragment is being built before other.stuffs, and to does  not compile.

title: Packager should provide mechanism for ordering unzip/untar
desc: The packager should provide a mechanism where the order in which files are  unzipped can be controlled in the case where files can be overwritten.

title: packager should not fail if optional nested features are not present
desc: The packager currently fails if an optional nested feature is not on the  filesystem.  It would be ideal if the optional feature were only packaged if  present.

title: Exporting feature containing white spaces in the folder name is not working
desc: Build 20031007, 20030930  1) create plugin project (with view) 2) create feature project containing the earlier created plugin project 3) choose export deployable feature -> see atatched screen shot -> same behavior when trying to generate ant build file for that feature

title: plugin building does not take into account linked folder
desc: Take for instance a plugin project, which is using libraries from a linked folder (defined as a directory "commonlibs" in the root of the plugin project). The build.xml and classpath are generated just fine and the project compiles. However, multiple problems appear : - when running a workbench with the plugin in question Eclipse seems to have lost track of all jars referenced from the linked folder. Only jars really existing into the project are visible. - as expected, the generated Ant task does not seem to understand where the commonlibs plugin is pointing. I was expecting a replacement of the linked folder name with the real path, then the creation of a "commonlibs" directory containing the referenced jars in order to include it in the plugin archive. Thus, usage of linked folders proves un-useable for PDE build process. Workbench running correctly would be a bare minimum, and a custom Ant script could eventually fix the second issue.

title: Export plugins fails when "Include source code" enabled
desc: I20031023  File>Export>Deployable plug-ins and fragments>Next Selected org.eclipse.ant.core Selected "a directory structure" Selected "Include source code" Set destination Finish  Always get an error dialog (which is pretty hard to read...I will attach).  The part of the error I can read is that it is attempting to copy the  source .zip but it does not exist (from line 105 for the ant core build file  in the target gather.sources)

title: Method getBuildingOSGi should be 'isBuildingOSGi'
desc: The newly added method 'getBuildingOSGi' in class AbstractScriptGenerator  should be 'isBuildingOSGi()' according to commonly used Java naming  conventions for boolean getters.

title: Example plug-in missing source code
desc: eclipse-examples-3.0M4-win32.zip doesn't seem to include the source code for  the org.eclipse.swt.examples.ole.win32_3.0.0 plug-in.

title: feature.xml from a generate.feature not very readable
desc: This is minor, but the feature.xml for a source feature that is generated from a generate.feature@... in a build.properties file is not very readable. It strings the line out or puts new line breaks in the strangest places. It just doesn't look good.  I've attached an examle that gets created from this.

title: Improvement of the classpath definition for the <javac> element.
desc: Hi PDE Team  This is a small enhancement request that is related to the lisibility of the  generated build.xml and specialy the classpath définition in the <javac>  element. So instead of having a very very long line of jars concatenated to  form the "classpath" attribute, it would be much more easy for those interested  in mofifiying the classpath or simply checking what's wrong with the  compilation, to use the <path> </path> constructor provided by Ant as in:  <path id="kdtui.jar.path"> <pathelement location="D:/eclipse/plugins/com.legacyj.cdt.ui_4.0.0/cdt.jar"/> <pathelement location="D:/eclipse/plugins/org.eclipse.core.boot_3.0.0/bin"/> <pathelement  location="D:/eclipse/plugins/org.eclipse.core.boot_3.0.0/boot.jar"/> <pathelement location="...."/> </path>  <javac destdir="${temp.folder}/kdtui.jar.bin" failonerror="${javacFailOnError}"  verbose="${javacVerbose}" debug="${javacDebugInfo}" includeAntRuntime="no"  bootclasspath="${bootclasspath}" source="${javacSource}"  target="${javacTarget}">	     <src path="src/"/>     <classpath refid="kdtui.jar.path"/> </javac>   I think it would help in finding "missing" external jars!!  Regards

title: Improve error message when the platform.doc.isv is missing
desc: For now, when the platform.doc.isv is missing (due for example to incorrect  fetching) an NPE is raised on source feature generation. This needs to be fixed to provide an error message.

title: Need to improve support for bundle building
desc: So far, equinox has been able to build with an equinox aware version of pde- build.  However, as equinox usage of "import" package is growing, new support needs to  be put in place to compile bundles in the right order as well as creating the  right compile path.  The first occurence of this problem occured trying to compile the configurator.  Indeed, this bundle needs to be compiled after runtime.osgi and before  runtime.compatibility (a fragment of runtime.osgi).

title: NPE during plugin export
desc: Using I200311192030 I right clicked on plugin.xml, selected Export, selected  one plug-in, deployable zip file, include source, specified a filename, and  pressed Finish. Eclipse switched to the Progress view which said 'ERROR: PDE  Export: An internal error occurred during: "PDE Export"'. The .log file is  copied below.  !ENTRY org.eclipse.core.runtime 4 2 Nov 20, 2003 10:20:59.839 !MESSAGE An internal error occurred during: "PDE Export". !STACK 0 java.lang.NullPointerException 	at java.io.File.<init>(Unknown Source) 	at  org.eclipse.pde.internal.build.builder.ModelBuildScriptGenerator.filterNonExist ingSourceFolders(ModelBuildScriptGenerator.java:705) 	at  org.eclipse.pde.internal.build.builder.ModelBuildScriptGenerator.generateSRCTar get(ModelBuildScriptGenerator.java:677) 	at  org.eclipse.pde.internal.build.builder.ModelBuildScriptGenerator.generateBuildJ arsTarget(ModelBuildScriptGenerator.java:579) 	at  org.eclipse.pde.internal.build.builder.ModelBuildScriptGenerator.generateBuildS cript(ModelBuildScriptGenerator.java:148) 	at  org.eclipse.pde.internal.build.builder.ModelBuildScriptGenerator.generate (ModelBuildScriptGenerator.java:110) 	at  org.eclipse.pde.internal.ui.wizards.exports.PluginExportJob.makeScript (PluginExportJob.java:148) 	at org.eclipse.pde.internal.ui.wizards.exports.PluginExportJob.doExport (PluginExportJob.java:96) 	at org.eclipse.pde.internal.ui.wizards.exports.BaseExportJob.doExports (BaseExportJob.java:179) 	at org.eclipse.pde.internal.ui.wizards.exports.BaseExportJob.run (BaseExportJob.java:133) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.jobs.Worker.run(Worker.java:62)   build.properties says:  source.sds.jar = src/ bin.includes = plugin.xml,\                about.html,\                icons/,\                audio/,\                sds.jar   I think I see the problem, I don't actually have a src/ directory (I call mine  Source/Java). After fixing build.properties to the following, the export  completed without error:  bin.includes = plugin.xml,\                about.html,\                icons/,\                audio/,\                sds.jar source.sds.jar = Source/Java/ output.sds.jar = build/ src.includes = Source/Java/

title: The builder needs to do the plugin.xml munging
desc: To be consistent with the runtime that transforms plugin.xml of 2.1 plugins on  the fly, PDE Build need to support implement the same behavior.

title: Cannot build without optional plug-ins present
desc: I'm a developer of the plugin X which requires a set of other plugins (A, B,  C). The set contains "optional" plugins which may not be present in my  environment or may have a different version from the one stated in plugin.xml.  E.g. Below is the part of plugin.xml file for plugin X:    <requires>       <import plugin="A"/>       <import plugin="B" optional="true" version="2.0.4" match="compatible"/>       <import plugin="C" optional="true" version="3.10" match="compatible"/>    </requires>  where Plugin C is not on my system presently,  Plugin B is on my system but has a different (compatible) version   If one of the above conditions true, "Export... | Deployable plugins and  fragments" dialog fails with error "Cannot find plugin: B".   This problem blocks us from a very importance use-case. If there is a  workaround please advise.

title: Building feature fails, with empty logs.zip
desc: I have a feature with two plugins. When I export the feature, I get an error message saying the build failed and the output will be placed in logs.zip.  logs.zip is empty.  I build the plugins individually, and in one of them, I find the .jar files produced are different.  The "bad" one is missing three anonymous inner classes (all based are Listeners, if it matters).  There is one non-anonymous inner class that IS there.  I'll try to attach a .ZIP file of the projects.

title: Problem building features
desc: From bug 49593:  1)  Create plugin "a", and feature "aFeature" that contains a. 1b)  Add Class A to a.  2)  Create plugin "b", and feature "bFeature" that contains b. 2b)  Add dependency from b to a. 2c)  Add Class B that extends A, in plugin b.  3)  Select plugin.xml for plugin b and generate an ANT build file.  Run ANT on  the file.  It should work fine.  4)  Select feature.xml for feature bFeature and generate ANT build file.   Notice it also generates a new build.xml in plugin b.  Run ANT on the file in  plugin b.  It fails: "[javac] Compile failed; see the compiler error output for details." If you compare the different build.xml files generated in plugin b you'll  notice that the one that works includes ../a/bin on the classpath while the  failed one does not.  I'm guessing that it expects that plugin a has already  been built.  I don't want to have to make aFeature an included feature of  bFeature, because these really aren't nested features, this is just a  dependency.  5)  After generating the build files from feature.xml, select the build.xml  file in bFeature, and select Run Ant... .  In the ANT dialog, select the  tasks,  in this order:  clean, build.jars, zip.distribution, refresh.  Finish.  In the  console, you will see this error: "[eclipse.refreshLocal] Project  ${bFeature_1.0.0} does not exist and cannot be refreshed.".  6)  Also as part of 5, it took me a while to realize that the zip.distribution  task would only zip, but not build.  I'd like a one click task,  like "build.distribution", but both builds and packages.  Also, I would expect  that to be the default more often than the current default, build.update.jar.

title: (POSSIBLY) BROKEN: eclipse-2.1+ / runtime workbench / antrunner
desc: I have in the past (Eclipse 2.0) used the PDE to develop custom Ant  tasks and test them with a runtime workbench by providing as the  application name 'org.eclipse.ant.core.antRunner'. I noticed with  Eclipse 2.1 (and 2.1.1 and 3.0M6) that this seems to be broken.  When starting the runtime workbench apparently Ant is complaining about  "unknown argument: -pdelaunch". I verified this by providing the  parameters -debug and -verbose which shows Ant is starting. When issuing  (manually) the same commandline as the PDE/Runtime workbench uses, and  removing the option -pdelaunch, Ant complains about the '-dev bin' option.  I suppose previously these options were swallowed by the platform  launcher and not passed on  to Ant. Any ideas, suggestions etc will be appreciated. If I am doing something  wrong here, please let me know. At this moment I strongly assume this is a bug.  Thanks in advance, Fitzgerald Krudde.

title: Plugins source in M6 causes problems
desc: When I move to M6, my plugin code wont compile - it gives wierd errors. When I  roll back to M5, everything's fine.   I am following Erich Gamma's recommendation in Contribution to Eclipse, and  importing source of all plugins into the workspace. If only binaries of other plugins are imported, things work fine (after adding  OSGi in the build path). But if source is imported, it is a mess- OSGi does not  seem to be included.   You can reproduce this by trying the following codebase: server: cvs.sourceforge.net module: org.syncshare.server user: anonymous password: (blank) type: pserver  Regards, Somik

title: Build order of fragments in generated build.xml incorrect
export plugin requires boot to be present
desc: To export a plugin you seem to have to have boot loaded/available otherwise you  get a dialog saying the system cannot find org.eclipse.core.boot.  I am running M7, targetting M7 and have org.eclipse.osgi* and  org.eclipse.core.runtime* as source in my workspace.  I try to export any of  these and get the above result.

title: export as deployable is too slow
desc: I don;t know what it is doing but I select three relatively small projects  (osgi, runtime and runtime.compatibility) and export as deployable plugins and  it take about a minute on my 2GHz laptop.  I know that this is using PDE Build  technology but I don't think that it would take that long to compile/jar these  files.  Then again, perhaps this use path is different somehow and does extra  work...

title: Automatic build of feature fails
desc: The automatic build of a feature fails when plugins are kept in the root of a  CVS repository as opposed to in a hierarchy.  here's the fix: Index: src/org/eclipse/pde/internal/build/FetchScriptGenerator.java =================================================================== RCS  file: /home/eclipse/org.eclipse.pde.build/src/org/eclipse/pde/internal/build/Fe tchScriptGenerator.java,v retrieving revision 1.26 diff -u -b -B -r1.26 FetchScriptGenerator.java --- src/org/eclipse/pde/internal/build/FetchScriptGenerator.java	26 Nov  2003 14:06:52 -0000	1.26 +++ src/org/eclipse/pde/internal/build/FetchScriptGenerator.java	2 Mar  2004 19:19:03 -0000 @@ -332,7 +332,7 @@  					moduleFeatureProperties = new Path (path).append(PROPERTIES_FILE);  				} else {  					moduleFeatureFile = new Path (elementName).append(DEFAULT_FEATURE_FILENAME_DESCRIPTOR); -					moduleFeatureProperties = new Path (path).append(PROPERTIES_FILE); +					moduleFeatureProperties = new Path (elementName).append(PROPERTIES_FILE);  				}    				if (password != null)

title: Packager failing on os, ws, arch specific fragments in feature.xml
desc: In FeatureBuildScriptGenerator::computeElements(boolean fragments), the  following line causes an exception later on when the feature.xml contains os,  ws arch specific fragments and when these fragments are not on the file system.  IPluginEntry[] pluginList = feature.getRawPluginEntries();  The pluginList should be a filtered list depending on the config spec passed  to the packager.

title: generated fetch script incorrect for org.eclipse.swt.gtk64 fragment
desc: The generated org.eclipse.plagform feature fetch script only fetches the  fragment.xml for the org.eclipse.swt.gtk64 fragment.  <ant antfile="../fetch_org.eclipse.platform.xml"  dir="${buildDirectory}/plugins" target="getFromCVS"> <property name="tag" value="HEAD"/> <property name="destination" value="org.eclipse.swt.gtk64"/> <property name="quiet" value="${quiet}"/> <property name="cvsRoot"  value=":pserver:anonymous@dev.eclipse.org:/home/eclipse"/> <property name="package" value="org.eclipse.swt.gtk64/fragment.xml"/> <property name="fileToCheck"  value="${buildDirectory}/plugins/org.eclipse.swt.gtk64/fragment.xml"/> </ant>

title: Fragments cause build classpath errors
desc: I am using the headless pde build toolto build a plugin. This plugin requires another plugin (require statement in plugin.xml) which is  also being built. The plugin that it requires has a fragment (nl1 frag, containing single jar) When the pde builder generates the build.xml, it creates a task for building  the jar in the original plugin. The classpath that is specified in that task includes jars in both the required  plugin and the fragment. Unfortunately, the classpath looks for all of the jars in both the fragment and  the require plugin. i.e. plugin1 requires plugin2 plugin2 has a corresponding fragment, fragment2 plugin2 contains 1.jar, 2.jar, 3.jar fragment2 contains nl1.jar classpath is then: ...,plugin2/1.jar,plugin2/2.jar,plugin2/3.jar,fragment2/nl1.jar,fragment2/1.jar, fragment2/2.jar,fragment2/3.jar Unfortunately, I rely on several plugins which have many jars and have nl1  fragments, so this adds several hundred non-existant jars to the compile path. Build then explodes on windows due to length of classpath/command.

title: Build of a feature hangs eclipse with auto refresh on
desc: If I have Auto refresh enabled, and I choose to build.jars for a feature, the build process hangs (console terminate does not work), and eclipse will also hang on exit, needing a kill of the java process.  I also notice alot of output about LinuxFAM updates in the console of the ant process - which is probably not intended.  If I try and force pde build in a different jre, the build fails since the eclipse stuff it needs is not available (should it be?)  If I disable auto refresh, restart eclipse, it all seems to work fine.  This is with build 200403251200 on linux fedora core1

title: Error when building plug-ins as Update JARs
desc: Latest from HEAD for pde.build, pde.core and pde.ui  Create two Hello, World plug-ins.  Try to export both of them as Update JARs in the same operation. A CoreException is thrown. This is the only scenario that is failing now.  Everything else works like a  charm.  I will attach the error dialog.

title: Call to <concat> requires fixlastline attribute setting to "yes"
desc: The call to <concat> in the preBuild target in the build.xml file in the  scripts directory requires an explicit fixlastline attribute setting to "yes"  (default sets this to "no")to prevent entries in the directory.txt from being  munged due to .map files without eol characters a the end of the last line.

title: [plan item] Improve PDE build
desc: PDE Build is fundamental to how the Eclipse Platform releases are produced. It is also increasingly being  used by other Eclipse projects and in the wider community. Potential improvements to PDE build include  parallel cross-building, incremental building of plug-ins, increased integration with the workspace model,  and support for additional repository providers. [PDE]

title: Side effect after export
desc: The builder is making use of static variables for controling some aspects of the generation such as the output format. This is bad and as the bad effect that given that pde ui does not set back those values to the default one, the scripts that are manually generated might be bogus.

title: [plan] Invest in PDE Build and Release Engineering
desc: We will address issues related to the reproducibility of our builds, and make it easier for others to make use of our build techology. [PDE, Rel. Eng.]

title: Update site builder no longer able to build feature
desc: Build 20040413  An update site which used to build fine with 20040407 no longer build with  latest integration build.  This is the Cheetah update site available on snz1f server. Details available on  demand.  Basically, it is now diagnosing build problems, and supply logs for it (now);  but basically these should not have occurred. Using 20040407 I succeed to build  the update site without any problem.

title: [plan] PDE Build and Export enhancements
desc: We will support export and install of workspace bundles into the running host; enhance product definition with start levels and license information and support creation from OSGi launch configurations; honor the dropins folder when building and resolving plug-in and feature dependencies; support parallel compilation of bundles, incremental building, features with cyclic dependencies, exporting existing class files from the workspace, and exporting individual source bundles. We will leverage p2 function for fetch, publish and packaging build phases. [PDE]

title: Can't export a feature due to temp location not found
desc: I20040413 This was working in earlier versions but now when I try to export my feature,  which includes one plug-in, by clicking on the Export... button in the feature  editor I get an error. I select Deploy as a single deployable ZIP file, give  it a filename on my desktop, and click Finish. The status bar says it is  Building Plug-ins for a few moments and then I get an error dialog (see the  screen shot). I check the drive and there is plenty of space there, no  permission problems, and I've played around with build.properties and various  things on the plugin but can't get it to work.  The one unusual thing about the plug-in is that it is a simple plug-in project  containing jar files only and no source code.  When I try to use this feature in an update site and rebuild the site I get  the exact same error. That was actually what I tried first before trying to  localize the problem through export.

title: PDE ignores names of generated features
desc: I have the following build.properties in my build.properties:  generate.feature@org.eclipse.cdt.sdk.source = org.eclipse.cdt generate.feature@org.eclipse.cdt.make.bananas = org.eclipse.cdt.make  and the following includes in my feature.xml:     <includes          id="org.eclipse.cdt.sdk.source"          version="2.0.0"          name="%featureName"/>     <includes          id="org.eclipse.cdt.make.bananas"          version="2.0.0"          name="%featureName"/>  PDE ignores the names I chose and creates features org.eclipse.cdt.source and org.eclipse.cdt.make.source.  My problem arises because I already have an org.eclipse.cdt.source that I'm using for something else.

title: Problems with warnings logged by pde-build
desc: Build: I-20040313  When generating the build scripts, pde-build builds and resolves a state. The unsatisfied constraints for the unresolved bundles are then logged as  warnings.  There are several problems with these logs:  1. Every unsatisfied constraint is logged as top-level first-class entry in  the log.   2. The messages printed for each warning are not very informative.  For  example, here is what you will see when a pre-req is missing: "The following inter-bundle dependencies have not been satisfied: Bundle:  org.eclipse.update.ui name: org.eclipse.help.base - version: null"  3. The message printed contain the word 'bundle' which would confuse the user  who rightly thinks he's dealing with plug-ins and fragments.  To address #1, all the warnings must be merged into a single multistatus since  they are all coming from the same event/operation.  To address #2 and #3, the type of VersionConstraint must be determined (i.e.  PackageSpecification, BundleSpecification, etc.) so that a meaningful message  can be output.  This message would of course contain familiar words like "plug- in" and "fragment" as necessary.  For consistency with the warnings that PDE/UI outputs upon unsatisfied  constraints, please refer to the class TargetPlatformRegistryLoader in the  org.eclipse.pde.core plug-in.  The code that merges all the warnings into one  multistatus is there.  Also, the code that determines the message to be output  is also there.  The latter might look very familiar as it is (almost)  identical to the one in the osgi plug-in ;-)  It would also be good and consistent if the messages that pde-build outputs  are identical to the one that pde-ui outputs.  So please refer to the  pderesource.properties file in the org.eclipse.pde.internal.core package of  the pde.core plug-in.

title: PDE build scripts - OSGI jar files missing from the classpath
desc: Trying the 200404201300 build, the PDE build scripts do not properly generate  the build.xml files for plugins. The OSGI jar files are missing from the  classpath, at least with the CDT plugins. I heard recently that the OSGI files  no longer have plugin.xml files. Not sure if this affects the PDE build  scripts.  Surprisingly, when I use the PDE menu item to create the ant file, the jars  files are included properly.

title: [rcp-app-export] The assemble script from the packager must support several folders
desc: In order to support scenarios 1 and 2 of building rcp applications, the script generator of the packager must support several the assembly from different folders which is not the case today. The current implementation requires all the plugins to be located in the same folder below an eclipse/ folder.

title: Cannot neither export nor create ant build script for 2.1.x plug-in
desc: I20040422  Have a 2.1.x workspace (PDE target platform set to C:\eclipse\drops\R2.1.2, no plug-ins checked). Load org.eclipse.jdt.ui tagged R2_1_2 from repository.  I need to create a patch for a customer but it does not work: - export plug-in using PDE fails     Message: Cannot find element org.eclipse.jdt.ui_2.1.2 - creating ant build file fails     Message: Cannot find element org.eclipse.jdt.ui  See attached errors that got written to .log, nothing in Console  Workaround: 1. create build.xml in my 3.0 workspace using 3.0 plug-in 2. fix the build.xml manually since structure changed 3. move it to 2.1 workspace 4. run it  Note: I have a valid plugin.xml and a valid build.properties (at least they were good enough to be shipped with 2.1.2) hence it is unclear why org.eclipse.jdt.ui cannot be found.

title: Problem exporting a plugin with dot on the classpath
desc: In the context of the export wizard, the generated scripts for a plugin which has dot on the classpath fails.

title: Specifying absolute path in build.properties
desc: The build.properties of features can only refer to root files with a relative path. This could be improved to support absolute path (note that this would be dangereous if used in automated build).

title: Compiler warnings in build log files
desc: build i0504-0800  The following warning is in the compiler build logs needs to be resolved before 3.0 ships.   ---------- 1. WARNING in /builds/I/src/plugins/org.eclipse.pde.build/src/org/eclipse/pde/internal/build/site/PDEState.java (at line 88) 	} finally { 			return result; 		} 	          ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ finally block does not complete normally ---------- 1 problem (1 warning)

title: Cannot export plugin that need to compile against plugin already built
desc: This happens on the I20040428 and I20040505.  I'm not sure when it started  happening.  If I try to export the following projects as deployable plugins I  get compile errors in a log.zip  org.eclipse.core.runtime org.eclipse.core.runtime.compatibility org.eclipse.osgi org.eclipse.osgi.services org.eclipse.osgi.util  Here are the steps to reproduce:  1. Extract the above projects from HEAD into a workspace. 2. Select all the 5 projects and bring up the export wizard. 3. Select Deployable plugins and fragments, click next. 4. Select a destination zip, click finish.  The three osgi projects appear to compile and build fine but the runtime  project does not seem to compile.  I get a logs.zip with compile errors.  I  will attach the log.zip file.

title: feature version numbers not auto qualified
desc: you cannot add .qualifier to the version number in a feature.xml and have PDE  build update it based on the the context (or anything else for that matter)

title: version substitution too agressive
desc: I have a plugin.xml that looks like...  <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <?eclipse version="3.0"?> <plugin> ...  in the build.properties I put qualifier=context  in the output plugin.xml I get <?xml version="1.1.0.20040506" encoding="UTF-8"?> <?eclipse version="3.0"?> <plugin>   Note the changed version=... in the <?xml> line

title: Build error based on update url definition
desc: The UI will let me add two update URLs.  I know it does not make sense, but I  guess I wanted to see what would happen at install/service time.  Did not get  that far.  If this is in a feature referenced by a site:    <url>       <update label="JS Team"  url="http://jumpstart.raleigh.ibm.com/UpdateSite"/>       <update label="Local JS Site" url="file:E:/Eclipse-3.0/Install- Extras/UpdateSite"/>       <discovery label="JS Team"  url="http://jumpstart.raleigh.ibm.com/UpdateSite"/>    </url>  The site build will fail.  The build says compilation error and that I should  look in the logs directory for why.  There is no logs directory.  It was only  by hunt/peck/inference that I removed my duplicate update URL and found out  that this was the real problem.  Need log content if you say it exists. Need the pde feature.xml editor to block multiple update URLs is not supported -  or the site build to accept them if they are....

title: Lots of "File not read" messages on export plugin
desc: I200405111200  When I export a plugin (org.eclipse.ant.ui but I get messages for any plugin I  try), I get lots of error log message. The export seems to be successful.  Example message: File not read: C:\darins\debugger\20040511 \eclipse\plugins\org.eclipse.jdt.core_3.0.0\build.properties.

title: Plugins sometimes brocken after export
desc: Hi,  I know that what now follows will sound quite annoying but I tested itas painstaking as I could and my spare time allows.  I use eclipse m8 and for the demonstration emf is needed (I used 0408)  The problem is that the attached plugins both run well in runtime  environment.  after export > deploy the plugins with pde, the plugins in work.zip will run after installing them to a fresh installed eclipse. the plugins in fail.zip will fail with NoClassDefFoundError.  both plugins contain the same code except using other plugin names and packagename (fail.zip has longer names). Also all other artifacts like plugin.xml or .project differ only that way.  the code of the plugins is complete emf generated. you can reproduce building the code by taking the genconf.ecore at src/model dir of one of the main plugins.  I tried this for several naming variants and it looks like the longer one fail, but I can't exactly say how long they have to be.  I also tried to vary the build option which not change the effects.  To reproduce:  1. clean eclipse (deleting .metadata in ws, deleting configuration) 2. istall working.zip (three plugins) 3. import the test project (test.zip) 4. double click simple.genconf 5. the editor pops up  6. do 1. - 4. for fail.zip 7. an error occurs (see attached .log)  Again, I know this seems to be really odd and I'm still seeking for mistakes I made,but trying to reproduce shouldn't take to much time for you following the list above.

title: deployed zips include bogus feature
desc: in i0517  I pick a plugin and say export as deployable zip.  Everything goes swimmingly.   I then unzip the zip and find that I have an empty feature in a dir called  org.eclipse.pde.container.feature_1.0.0.  I suspect that this is the feature  created by/for PDE build to run the export but it is somehow getting included  in the zip.  Note that there are commonly issues with zips and deleting files.   Not sure exactly but you have to take care to delete the actual dirs or perhaps  not even include them in the first place.  Note also that this may be related to a problem that the Update guys have seen  where this feature seems to appear spontaenously.

title: Provide a fall back for the context number
desc: When searching the context from the properties file, there is not fall back if the plugin for which the context is being looked up is not available.  It could be interesting to do so.

title: Provide default case for the packaging steps
desc: With the current solution, the packaging steps must be specified for every single plugin or feature which makes the file hard to manage. It could be good to handle a generic case.

title: Verify that the feature.xml shipped with pde build
desc: Pde build ships with a feature, and a builder. The content of the feature needs to be updated to build a correct builder, and the properties file of the builder should use the new properties.

title: Deployable Plug-in Export: The exported zip contains top-level dir with name "."
desc: E3M9: Exporting a deployable Plug-in(s), the zip file contains  structure ./plugins/<plugins>, with the "." being an extra directory in the way.  I believe that in previous versions (including E3M8) the path was  eclipse/plugins/<plugins>.

title: Cannot export plugin relying on a library already built
desc: In M9, it is not possible to export the cvsssh2 plugin without compile errors. It seems that the jar providing ssh supports can not be found.

title: Generated source feature do not have a discovery tag
generictargets.xml should have a target which builds update jars
desc: generictargets.xml should have a target which builds update jars  This will allow the build process to build update jars using pde build.

title: Excessive amount of time required to generate build.xml files
desc: The problem is the excessive time in the generation of the files build.xml  (around 10 hours).                       These are the steps in order to reproduce the problem:         1) Create a new feature project.                               2) Add plug-ins to this feature.                               3) Add the new feature to the site.xml.                        The build.xml files take more than 10h in order to be created.  This happens with the building of a specific feature under development which  has 45 plugins.  In contrast, another feature that has more than 72 plugins  takes only 10 - 15 minutes to generate the build.xml files.  Can you explain  the difference in the times it takes to generate the two features?

desc: For example try to build the coretools with . on the classpath
