title: PDE build does not allow manifest files in plugin library jars
desc: When defining the content of a runtime library PDE build could allow the  source folders of the library to contain a jar manifest file that is merged  into the generated manifest for the library jar.  Right now PDE build generates a <jar> ant command similar to the following:  <jar       jarfile="${build.result.folder}/mylib.jar"      basedir="${temp.folder}/mylib.jar.bin" />  PDE build could generate <jar> commands with filesetmanifest="merge" attribute  (by default it is set to "skip").  This would merge the content of any META- INF/MANIFEST.MF files found in the temp.folder with the manifest for the  library jar.  Perhaps this should be the default or maybe we need some kind of  option in the build.properties to specify this per library.  <jar       filesetmanifest="merge"      jarfile="${build.result.folder}/mylib.jar"      basedir="${temp.folder}/mylib.jar.bin" />

title: Error exporting plugin as deployable feature
desc: Build: I20040607  1) Checkout some plugin project from a repository 2) Export > Deployable plugins and fragments 3) Enter a zip file location in a nonexistent directory (such as  c:\foo\bar.zip). 4) Click Finish  Error occurs: Problems during export. Problem creating zip: c:\foo\bar.zip  (The system cannot find the path specified)(and the archive is probably  corrupt but I could not delete it)  Expected result: It creates the directory for me, or at least gives a more  accurate description of the problem. The "archive is probably corrupt" is a  scary error message.

title: Generated fetch script always refetch for the content of bundles
desc: The generated fetch scripts have an optimization which consists in checking if a "wellknown" file is available before doing the checkout. For plugins and features those wellknown files are plugin.xml, fragment.xml and feature.xml, however now that we have bundle manifest.mf needs to be added to this list. The "difficulty" is that the file to check is deduced from the tag in the map file.

title: PDE non externalized Strings
desc: AssembleConfigScriptGenerator.java	org.eclipse.pde.build/src- pdebuild/org/eclipse/pde/internal/build	  PDEState.java	org.eclipse.pde.build/src- pdebuild/org/eclipse/pde/internal/build/site	  BuildTimeSite.java	org.eclipse.pde.build/src- pdebuild/org/eclipse/pde/internal/build/site  LogReader.java	org.eclipse.pde.runtime/src- pdert/org/eclipse/pde/internal/runtime/logview	  ContentPage.java	org.eclipse.pde.ui/src- pdeui/org/eclipse/pde/internal/ui/wizards/plugin

title: Problems during feature export with fragment
desc: Build id: 200406111814 (3.0RC2)  The export wizard reports a problem, when trying to export a feature that contains a fragment.  To reproduce, create a new feature project (e.g. "my-swt-feature") and add org.eclipse.swt and org.eclipse.swt.win32 to feature.xml. Start export wizard. Deploy as a directory structure. Press Finish. This will result in the error dialog attached to this bug report.

title: build scripts copying source zip file in plugins contributing Ant tasks
desc: The 3.0RC2 drop contains the following duplicate source zip files:  org.eclipse.core.resouces\ant_tasks\resources-antsrc.zip org.eclipse.pde\ant_tasks\pde-antsrc.zip  The generated build script for o.e.core.resources contains the following line in the gather.bin.parts target:  <copy todir="${destination.temp.folder}/org.eclipse.core.resources_3.0.0" failonerror="true">   <fileset dir="${basedir}" includes="plugin.xml,plugin.properties,.options,about.html,*.jar,ant_tasks/*,jar"                     /> </copy>

title: Need better error messages for missing dependant plug-ins
desc: build RC2.  - following the test plan for PDE-Build - created plug-in Match1 with version 1.0.1 - created plug-in Match2 with perfect dependancy on Match1 v. 1.0.0 - expected failure  Got a dialog: "Cannot find element: Match2".  There is a good warning message in the log but the above dialog was all that the user gets.

title: Plugin export indicate errors on export whereas everything went fine
desc: RC2. MacosX. Create a new hello world plugin. Use the export wizard to export the plugin. At the end of the export a dialog is opened saying something like:   "error while building, look in the logs.zip".  If you open the log you will notice that it is empty.

title: Bug 63870 reappeared. Can't export feature with a required binary jar
desc: Bug 63879 appears to of reappeared with RC2. I have two plugins in a feature:  plugin A has only a jar already built in it plus the plugin.xml, and the build.properties. the plugin.xml has the jar as the library for the plugin.  plugin B has a requirement for plugin A, it also has source in it.   When you do an export feature, plugin B can't find the stuff in the jar in plugin A when compiling the source in plugin B.  Doing some debugging the problem is that the generated build.xml's build.jars target for plugin A doesn't do anything since there is no source to compile.  Then in plugin B for build.jars, it includes plugin A's jar from the build results. But since build.jars of plugin A didn't do anything, there is no jar in there to find.  I tried this with 6/16 driver too, and it still fails.  So you can't build a feature where one of its plugins has a binary jar instead of  source, and another plugin in the feature requires that jar.  This is a regression.  Thanks, Rich

title: gather.bin.parts misses the plugin's JAR
desc: Unless the plugin's jar is in property "bin.includes" in build.properties, it is not included in the exported plugin. This did not use to be the case in 2.1, and in any case, doesn't make much sense when build.xml already knows about the plugin's jar in the "build.jars" target.  This is a regression from bug 38943.

title: Improve the support for export of binary plugins
desc: Pde now supports export of binary plugins. However the build.xml of some targets are not empty which may cause problems (for example clean). Also the build.xml are generated into the install folder of the plugin, which may reveal to be problematic when the binary plugins are in a read only folder.

title: NPE exporting features when a fragment is missing - potential for rcp app export
desc: feature.xml can reference plugins and fragments that you don't necessarily have in your workspace. This is fine. In releng mode, although those fragments are not built they are partially fetched so that the version number can  be replaced to produce a valid feature.  This causes a problem when trying to export a feature for which plugins or fragments are missing.

title: Format the generated build.xml
desc: In build.xml for plugins, the call to the eclipse.versionReplacer task is not properly indented.

title: [doc] eclipse.fetch does not honor some of its properties
desc: Writing the doc I discovered that in some of the refactoring that has been done more than a year and a half ago caused some breakage in the eclipse.fetch task. The two main things are: - elements tag only supports one entry at a time - scriptName has been removed because the file name is automatically generated.

title: eclipse.buildScript only generates the script for the first plugin specified
desc: The 2.1 doc of eclipse.buildScript indicates that elements can take a list of elements for which the build needs to be generated.  Testing it by listing two plugins (for example plugin@org.eclipse.core.runtime and plugin@org.eclipse.osgi) I discovered that the build script for the second plugin specified on the list is not generated.  Even though this was fixed ,given that the generated script makes a strong assumption on the environment for which they have been generated (especially for their classpath), the semantics of the task needs to be redefined.

title: [doc] Ant tasks need Javadoc
desc: We need to ensure that our Ant tasks all have proper javadoc.  This includes adding the @since 3.0 tag to all new public methods, etc.

title: Version replacers should not change the file if version numbers don't need to be replaced
desc: The various version replacers should not change the file is version numbers don't need to be replaced.

title: build-site function corrupts feature.xml
desc: given a normal feature.xml, running the "build update site"  will create a feature jar containing a  corrupted feature.xml. specifically, the label attribute of the feature element is overwritten with the  version:  <feature       id="org.tigris.subversion.subclipse.osx"0.9.4"Subclipse"       version="0.9.4"       provider-name="tigris.org"       os="macosx"       ws="carbon"       arch="ppc">   should be:  <feature       id="org.tigris.subversion.subclipse.osx" label="Subclipse"       version="0.9.4"       provider-name="tigris.org"       os="macosx"       ws="carbon"       arch="ppc">

title: [doc] PDE build process broken for plugins/Need better error message
desc: Just wasted the afternoon on this...  Followed 'Automating Builds with PDE BUILD' and got stuck with  java.io.FileNotFoundException: C:\home2\test\eclipse\3.0 \plugins\org.eclipse.pde.build_3.0.0 \scripts\export\assemble.orbeon.oxfstudio.eclipse.all.xml (The system cannot  find the file specified)  Checked several time that I leaving something out, checked bugs, etc.  Finally found this http://dev.eclipse.org/newslists/news.eclipse.platform/msg24924.html  My preference would be for the PDE build to work with plugins.  However if that is not done then at least the build has to give a better error message, i.e Error: No Features to export.  ( Anything would be better than 'Your build  failed because I cannot find this file that you don't know about and that I was  supposed to generate.!'  )

title: Automated product build fails if "zipargs" is not defined in build.properties
desc: I've been using the guide to Automated product builds and found that, although it said it was successful, the process actually failed to complete.  What happens is that my resulting build (the zipfile) is created with the proper contents but remains in the "tmp" sub-folder, and the name of the zipfile is "${zipargs}.zip".  Consequently, the zipfile is never copied to the final release folder.  As it turns out, simply defining "zipargs=" in my build.properties file causes everything to start working.  But note - "zipargs=" is all lowercase.  Simply uncommenting the default "zipArgs=" in the template build.properties does not do anything.  I would think that zipargs should have a default value of "" defined at some point, internally.

title: Data in build.properties, customTargets.xml should be part of project def.
desc: One shouldn't have to create these 'extra project' files in order to  build ones projects in batch mode.

title: Automated PDE build fails on generated path containing @dot
desc: I am trying to build my plugins in an automated manner.  Adding a fragment to my build script has caused it to break.  The error message is:  gather.bin.parts:     [mkdir] Created dir: C:\_CVS\swt_root\host_code\ide\code\build_scripts\eclipse\tmp\eclipse\plugins\com.dspfactory.ctk.win32_0.0.2  BUILD FAILED C:\eclipse3.0\eclipse\plugins\org.eclipse.pde.build_3.0.0\scripts\build.xml:24: Following error occured while executing this line C:\eclipse3.0\eclipse\plugins\org.eclipse.pde.build_3.0.0\scripts\build.xml:88: Following error occured while executing this line C:\_CVS\swt_root\host_code\ide\code\build_scripts\platform_ide\customTargets.xml:24: Following error occured while executing this line C:\eclipse3.0\eclipse\plugins\org.eclipse.pde.build_3.0.0\scripts\genericTargets.xml:132: Following error occured while executing this line C:\_CVS\swt_root\host_code\ide\code\build_scripts\eclipse\assemble.com.dspfactory.skt.all.xml:4: Following error occured while executing this line C:\_CVS\swt_root\host_code\ide\code\build_scripts\platform_ide\customTargets.xml:48: Following error occured while executing this line C:\_CVS\swt_root\host_code\ide\code\build_scripts\eclipse\assemble.com.dspfactory.skt.win32.win32.x86.xml:41: Following error occured while executing this line C:\_CVS\swt_root\host_code\ide\code\build_scripts\eclipse\plugins\com.dspfactory.ctk.win32\build.xml:52: C:\_CVS\swt_root\host_code\ide\code\build_scripts\eclipse\plugins \com.dspfactory.ctk.win32\@dot not found.  This is from the "gather.bin.parts" target of my fragment I am trying to build.  The generated code in build.xml is:  	<target name="gather.bin.parts" depends="init" if="destination.temp.folder"> 		<mkdir dir="${destination.temp.folder}/com.dspfactory.ctk.win32_0.0.2"/> 		<copy todir="${destination.temp.folder}/com.dspfactory.ctk.win32_0.0.2" failonerror="true"> 			<fileset dir="${build.result.folder}/@dot" includes="**"			/> 		</copy> 		<copy todir="${destination.temp.folder}/com.dspfactory.ctk.win32_0.0.2" failonerror="true"> 			<fileset dir="${basedir}" includes="fragment.xml,META-INF/,os/,ws/,fragment.properties"			/> 		</copy> 	</target>  I don't know where the "@dot" is coming from.  My fragment is not even a Java project - so it didn't have a .classpath file.  I thought this may be the problem so I added a .classpath file with a dummy entry for src and bin paths, but the error persists.  I'm not sure where to go from here.

title: build fails with useless message when feature.xml is invalid.
desc: Due to bug https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=71039 I had a feature.xml that was well formed but not valid according to feature.dtd. ( Pbm was more than one /feature/url/update element. )    The error message ( below ) doesn't say anything about an invalid feature.xml.       [exec] BUILD FAILED      [exec] /home/dsmall/eclipse-win32- win32/plugins/org.eclipse.pde.build_3.0.0/scripts/build.xml:23: Following error  occured while executing this line      [exec] /home/dsmall/eclipse-win32- win32/plugins/org.eclipse.pde.build_3.0.0/scripts/build.xml:50: Following error  occured while executing this line       [exec] /usr/local/anthill/work4/orbeon/projects/OXF/studio2/bld/customTargets.xm l:49: Following error occured while executing this line      [exec] /home/dsmall/eclipse-win32- win32/plugins/org.eclipse.pde.build_3.0.0/scripts/genericTargets.xml:33:  org.eclipse.core.runtime.CoreException: Feature  orbeon.oxfstudio.eclipse.feature may have not been fetched correctly, check  your map files.

title: Existing manifest files can confuse confuse PDE
desc: This bug is the other side of bug #71823. PDE State should check if the manifest.mf provided contains a symbolic name. If it does not, a manifest should be generated from the XML file. If this is not done, classpath computation will be bogus and classes will not be found.

title: Problem to deploy new plugins into Windows XP.
desc: Hello there ,        I am developing some plugins on eclipse with Windows XP and Linux both  installed on system.         When I create new plugin and try to deploy it into eclipse ( by  following standard ways) on Windows XP , it doesn't respond. Same thing happened on other machines.  But same plugin folder with jar and manifest XML file , i deployed into Linux  OS , It shows result immediately. Please tell me what to do to get my plugins running on any OS.

title: PDE doesn't detect exported system packages
desc: If I have a target platform that has specific packages exported via the system  bundle (osgi.framework.systempackages), PDE doesn't seem to be able to detect  this, and will not allow me to generate a build.xml file if I am importing one  of these exported system packages.  To reproduce:  1. Modify config.ini of Eclipse to include the following additional property:         osgi.framework.systempackages=java.sql,javax.sql 2. Start the workbench and create a new plugin project named "test" -- be sure  to select to create OSGi bundle manifest. 3. Open META-INF/MANIFEST.MF and add the following line:         Import-Package: java.sql 4. Save manifest and then right click on manifest and select "PDE Tools >  Create Ant Build File"  Errors will show in the error log:  !ENTRY org.eclipse.pde.build 2 1 Aug 31, 2004 15:32:58.422 !MESSAGE Some inter-plug-in dependencies have not been satisfied. !SUBENTRY 1 test 2 2 Aug 31, 2004 15:32:58.432 !MESSAGE Unsatisfied import package java.sql_0.0.0.  !ENTRY org.eclipse.pde.build 4 8 Aug 31, 2004 15:32:58.432 !MESSAGE Unable to find element: test.   This should be detecting that the target platform is exporting java.sql as a  system package, and should be available for import into the plugin.

title: [regression?] NPE if qualifier not set
desc: 3.0.1 RC1  I have a plugin with version number 1.0.0.qualifier but the build.properties  file does not specify a qualifier.  As a result, I get the following NPE  An internal error occurred during: "PDE Export". java.lang.NullPointerException 	at java.util.Hashtable.put(Hashtable.java:545) 	at org.eclipse.pde.internal.build.site.PDEState.hasQualifier (PDEState.java:172) 	at org.eclipse.pde.internal.build.site.PDEState.addBundle (PDEState.java:119) 	at org.eclipse.pde.internal.build.site.PDEState.addBundles (PDEState.java:267) 	at org.eclipse.pde.internal.build.site.BuildTimeSite.getRegistry (BuildTimeSite.java:60) 	at  org.eclipse.pde.internal.build.builder.FeatureBuildScriptGenerator.computeElemen ts(FeatureBuildScriptGenerator.java:100) 	at  org.eclipse.pde.internal.build.builder.FeatureBuildScriptGenerator.generateChild renScripts(FeatureBuildScriptGenerator.java:714) 	at  org.eclipse.pde.internal.build.builder.FeatureBuildScriptGenerator.generate (FeatureBuildScriptGenerator.java:192) 	at org.eclipse.pde.internal.build.BuildScriptGenerator.generateFeatures (BuildScriptGenerator.java:125) 	at org.eclipse.pde.internal.build.BuildScriptGenerator.generate (BuildScriptGenerator.java:62) 	at  org.eclipse.pde.internal.ui.wizards.exports.FeatureExportJob.makeScript (FeatureExportJob.java:254) 	at org.eclipse.pde.internal.ui.wizards.exports.FeatureExportJob.doExport (FeatureExportJob.java:190) 	at org.eclipse.pde.internal.ui.wizards.exports.PluginExportJob.doExports (PluginExportJob.java:45) 	at org.eclipse.pde.internal.ui.wizards.exports.FeatureExportJob.run (FeatureExportJob.java:96) 	at org.eclipse.core.internal.jobs.Worker.run(Worker.java:66)

title: Ant build of the 'zip.distribution' target of a feature's build.xml
desc: Hi,  If you have a feature and one of your plugins is user guide/help plugin with  all TOC XML files.  Even the build.properties of the user guide/help plugin  specifies those TOC XML files to get, the build with the below command would  not get all the TOC XML files.  Only the book.xml file is gotten.  eclipse.exe -nosplash -application org.eclipse.ant.core.antRunner -buildfile  <feature's path to build.xml file> "zip.distribution"

title: Exporting of deployable feature fails on checked in build.xml
desc: If  you have build.xml files checked into source code control, doing an export  on the feature as deployable feature will fails, because it cannot write the  build.xml.  Perhaps it should warn the user?

title: @dot showing up in fragment build.xml
desc: 3.1m2  I have an SWT fragment that contains the normal swt.jar and some additional  classes as source.  These addtional clases are to be compiled into "extras.jar"  which is included in the Bundle-Classpath header of the fragment's manifest.mf.  When I generate the build.xml, the gather.bin.parts includes lines to gather  from .../@dot.  this fails as the directory does not exist.  Note that the classpath for the extras.jar <javac> task also includes an @dot  entry. This does not cause a problem (in my case) but is not actually needed.

title: remove "icu.base" from Eclipse DL site to avoid redundancy
desc: +++ This bug was initially created as a clone of Bug #395003 +++  In bug 386766 it was discussed and decided to remove "ICU base" bundles from platform build and DL page. The platform doesn't use them, other than to redistribute them, ....  = = = = =   I've discovered the above statement, in cloned bug, is not quite true, at least literally.   We have a "pde build product" that specifies to include the "icu base" bundle, presumably for reduced size, rather than the full ICU.   So, _this_ bug is to clarify if that's really needed?   If so, if it is needed, then I guess we can not remove icu.base completely, such as from our build and repo.   If not really needed, then we should remove it from /org.eclipse.pde.build.product.feature/feature.xml which is in the  eclipse.pde.build repo  To be honest, I was surprised to see this "pde build product" defined and being built. I wonder if we still really need it? Does anyone use it? (You know, I mean as an independent "product"?)   Its fine with me either way, I'm just trying to separate some chaff from the wheat.

title: We do not distribute o.e.pde.build.feature
desc: We do build it, in the sense it is part of the pom's <modules>,  but it is not included in any other feature and is not part of our repository.   It 'includes' a p2 feature: org.eclipse.equinox.p2.extras.feature Which, I suspect is included elsewhere, such as equinox sdk, if not p2 sdk.   It includes the following bundles           id="org.apache.ant"          id="org.eclipse.ant.core"          id="org.eclipse.pde.build"          id="org.eclipse.jdt.core.compiler.batch"          id="org.eclipse.jdt.core.ant.compiler.adapter"  The first, org.apache.ant is a third party jar (not built) and is included in other features.   The last two are are obviously built by JDT.  o.e.ant.core is listed as module in platform's pom (and included in the platform feature.  o.e.pde.build is in that repo's pom, but is included in pde-feature.   The feature has required some small amount of work or distraction, since it has a "forceQualifierUpdate" file, that has been updated a few times.   I suggest we stop building that feature, which leaves only two important bundles in the pde.build repo:  org.eclipse.pde.build org.eclipse.pde.build.tests  There is also a directory with examples projects, but as far as I can see we do not build them.

title: React to deltapack removal
desc: "We" need to decide what to do about me literally removing (stop building) the delta pack. See bug 470932 and the original bug 419246. I would like to do this by M6.   I am fairly sure PDE still has unit tests that assume the delta pack is "present" when they run.   I think there are basically 2 alternatives.   1. remove, or disable the tests. (Or similarly, have them conditional based on presence of "*deltapack.zip" and if not there, then do not run the tests).   2. during the "setup" of PDE's unit tests (that depend on deltapack) then PDE can create their own, in a way similar to how we tell legacy users to do it.   Advantages of '1' is that we are truly moving on and simplifying things.   The advantage of '2' is that there are still "legacy users" (apparently) that use it, so as a favor that that part of our community we could still create it and run the unit tests -- to make sure we do not break those legacy users.   There is another "hidden" advantage of '2'. It is an indirect test that the "configuration feature" exists and roughly works as intended. I happen to know one adapter that still depends on that "configuration feature" (but not the delta pack per se).    We do not use the configuration feature ourselves, and we could devise simpler tests for it -- such as only make sure it exists! -- if the PDE team would prefer to simply get rid of the delta pack tests.   If the PDE team wants to continue the tests, then I can tell you one way to create it.   At the begging of your tests run the equivalent of    ./eclipse -application org.eclipse.ant.core.antRunner -f createdeltapack.xml  Your starting point for "createdeltapack.xml" could be a copy of a file we have in our repo for "legacy users", at   http://git.eclipse.org/c/platform/eclipse.platform.releng.aggregator.git/plain/scripts/createdeltapack.xml  You would want to tweak it a little and may want to invoke it programmatically via Java, instead of through literally calling eclipse via 'exec'.   Let me know your preferences when it would be safe for me to remove it from releng.

title: Plugin export complains about problems in unrelated plugins
desc: build I20040924  - File > Export > Deployable Plugins and Fragments - check off the browser example plugin - choose to export it to a directory - press Finish  It proceeded with the export OK, but I got the following in the log:  !ENTRY org.eclipse.pde.build 2 1 Oct 05, 2004 13:46:15.214 !MESSAGE Some inter-plug-in dependencies have not been satisfied. !SUBENTRY 1 GravityServiceBinder2b 2 2 Oct 05, 2004 13:46:15.214 !MESSAGE Unsatisfied import package tutorial.example2.service_0.0.0.  See bug 75214 for more details on the above error.

title: Add support to build non-Java libraries
desc: It would be great if PDE Build could generate scripts or execute existing  scripts to compile non-Java code, based on another build.properties setting.  It may facilitate builds for folks who want to contribute new ports of eclipse.

title: "Create Ant Build File" fails with vague "unable to write script /path/build.xml"
desc: I was messing around with a PDE project (migrating to 3.1 among other things) and wanted to recreate the build.xml file.  So, I backed up my build.xml file and deleted it.  I right-clicked the plugin.xml file and selected "Create Ant Build File".  In doing this, I got an error dialog that said "Unable to write script /home/ewies/project/build.xml".  When I did "touch build.xml" to create a dummy file (to test permissions, or something), the command completed without an error, but the resulting build script was empty.  After looking at the stack trace in the error log, I saw which plugin and dove into the CVS source.  It ended up that I had the "custom" flag set in my build.properties file.  I had some custom ant commands in my project and had forgotten that the flag was set.  I deleted build.xml again and removed the flag and all worked fine.  To make a long story short, I had to do some digging around to figure out what was wrong.  A more verbose error message would be useful.  There is already an error dialog for this specific failure mode  (see the callstack below), it just needs to be more verbose -- something akin to "Could not open /path/build.xml while updating project with custom build enabled."?  Cheers, Evan   Relevant stack frames: !ENTRY org.eclipse.pde.build 4 7 Oct 05, 2004 14:55:00.925 !MESSAGE Could not write script /home/ewies/bb/utils/sif/build.xml. !STACK 0 java.io.FileNotFoundException: /home/ewies/bb/utils/sif/build.xml (No such file or directory) 	at java.io.FileInputStream.open(Native Method) 	at java.io.FileInputStream.<init>(FileInputStream.java:106) 	at org.eclipse.pde.internal.build.builder.AbstractBuildScriptGenerator.readFile(AbstractBuildScriptGenerator.java:142) 	at org.eclipse.pde.internal.build.builder.AbstractBuildScriptGenerator.updateVersion(AbstractBuildScriptGenerator.java:180) 	at org.eclipse.pde.internal.build.builder.ModelBuildScriptGenerator.updateExistingScript(ModelBuildScriptGenerator.java:893) 	at org.eclipse.pde.internal.build.builder.ModelBuildScriptGenerator.generate(ModelBuildScriptGenerator.java:125)

title: A clear example of how to generate build.xml files for a feature at command line.
desc: Hi,  Please provide a clear example of how to generate build.xml files for a  feature at command line.  There are many people who use Eclipse have encountered the below infamous  error.  org.eclipse.core.runtime.CoreException: Unable to find feature: x.y.z.  Many posts from IBM/Eclipse engineers that keep referencing to the user guide,  which is very scarcely written, and to script files that add more confusion to  the situation.  Ok, all the Eclipse-user community needs is a very simple BUT exact to the  values used in the XML file to generate build.xml files for a feature.  Consider this scenario.  In my directory C:\MyWork, I have the below directories  ("MyFeature", "Plugin#1", and "Plugin#2") and the file called  buildscripts.xml.  Please take the names as is; that is, the directory name  for "MyFeature" is "MyFeature", literally, not "my.com.feature".  MyFeature/feature.xml has the id of "my.com.feature".    MyWork     MyFeature     plugin#1     plugin#2     buildscripts.xml  buildscripts.xml has the below contents.  *Is the below correct and what needs  to be fixed to have the build.xml files generated into the above  directories, "MyFeature", "plugin#1", "plugin#2"?*  The command to run in the "MyWork" directory is:  java -cp c:\eclipse\startup.jar org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main -application  org.eclipse.ant.core.antRunner -buildfile buildscripts.xml "buildScripts"     <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <project name="my.com.project" default="buildScripts" basedir=".">        <!-- Comments:       -->        <target name="init">          <!-- Need to change on this on different platform.  The      standard Eclipse installation location is used here      for the WINDOWS XP platform.          -->      <property name="eclipse.install.dir" value="c:/eclipse"/>        </target>        <target name="buildScripts" depends="init">          <eclipse.buildScript             elements="feature@my.com.feature"             buildDirectory="${basedir}/MyFeature"             baseLocation="${eclipse.install.dir}"             buildingOSGi="true"             children="true"             recursiveGeneration="true"             devEntries="${basedir}/plugin#1/bin,${basedir}/plugin#2/bin"             configInfo="*, *, *"             pluginPath="${basedir}/plugin#1/,${basdir}/plugin#2/"         />               </target> </project>

title: Need a way to set the manifest tag of the ant jar command
desc: We need a way to set the manifest tag of the ant jar command, so that some jar can embed their own  manifest.mf.

title: Source Code locations for JAR'ed bundles
desc: When dealing with JAR'ed bundles, we need to clearly define where the source  is going to be located for PDE to be able to: 1. export plugins in this format with/without source. 2. locate and attach source to JARs when computing classpaths.  Here are some initial suggestions that came up in a recent discussion with  Jeff: 1. If the source is to be packaged inside the JAR alongide the class files,  they will appear at the root.  This way, the JAR itself can be used as the  source attachment zip.  2. If the source is shipped separately (i.e. via the pde.core.source extension  point), then the source zip will appear in the same location as it does now  but it will be called 'srczip'.  As a quick test to see what PDE/Build  currently names source zips for bundles with a '.' as a library name, the name  of the zip is '@dotsrc.zip', which is not a good name.

title: Default bootclasspath setting should not be empty in generated build.xml
desc: It would be great if the default bootclasspath settings in the generated  build.xml files could default to the jars in the ${java.home}/lib directory,  ie.  <path id="bootclasspath">     <fileset dir="${java.home}/lib">         <include name="*.jar"/>     </fileset> </path>  <property name="bootclasspath" refid="bootclasspath"/>

title: The word "includes" in the license agreement causes the idReplacer task to fail.
desc: If a feature.xml contains the word "includes" in the license agreement the eclipse.idReplacer task doesn't run property.

title: pde sample builld.properties in org.eclipse.rcpHelper has a typo in the linux.gtk path
desc: The path has an extra '.'

title: org.eclipse.pde.build/scripts/build-template.properties has a property name typo
desc: the commented out javaSource should be javacSource

title: Would like to build without checkout
desc: It would be nice to be able to do a automated pde build without the checkout step.  When a checkout is required, it means that the code you want to compile has to be checked in.  This prevents us from enforcing the rule that the CVS head must compile - for if we have to check it in before it compiles, we can't be sure that it will.  I'm fine with a task that copies stuff out of the build tree using a map file-like structure to find everything relative to some root directory and put it in a more restrictive structure like the current eclipse.fetch task does.  I tried to do this myself using standard ant tasks, but one really needs to get in and exampine the features to get the recursion that allows you to copy over all the needed bits.  I would guess that this code is already pretty much in the fetch task and could be applied to a copy rathed than a checkout.  If I get time, I'll look myself.

title: Stop generating tasks for unsupported distributions
desc: +++ This bug was initially created as a clone of Bug #503328 +++  Eclipse is not supporting carbon, ppc, wpf and etc. Let's stop pde.build from generating tasks for them to not polute build directories with such content.

title: Impossible to find bundleEntry://44/templates/plugin/plugin.xml
desc: When exporting a feature with generated source plugin, the following messsage is sometimes printed and nothing is logged. This should be improved.

title: eclipse.idReplacer vague error
desc: In WTP project, using M3 as development/build environment, we tried using the  "0.0.0" trick (in feature.xml files) so it would automatically pickup the  version from the plugin. This worked for a build or two, but then started getting an error, but little hint as to what was wrong. Exhaustive checking for obvious problems and trial and error did not reveal anything, and eventually we had to go back and simply use explicit version in feature.xml files.   This is the error message received, in workbench PDE build. A pure ANT Eclipse-like build has similar error message, but only first line.   [eclipse.idReplacer] Could not find/> [eclipse.idReplacer]       <import plugin=  This is the idReplacer task in build.xml file ... didn't seem to matter if  we used "0.0.0" technique or not.   <eclipse.idReplacer featureFilePath="${feature.base}/features/org.eclipse.jst_1.0.0/feature.xml"  selfVersion="1.0.0" featureIds="org.eclipse.wst,1.0.0," pluginIds="org.eclipse.jst.sample.web.project,1.0.0,org.eclipse.jst.server.core,1.0.0,org.eclipse.jst.server.generic.core,1.0.0,org.eclipse.jst.server.generic.modules,1.0.0,org.eclipse.jst.server.generic.ui,1.0.0,org.eclipse.jst.server.tomcat.core,1.0.0,org.eclipse.jst.server.tomcat.ui,1.0.0,org.eclipse.jst.server.ui,1.0.0,org.eclipse.jst.j2ee,1.0.0,org.eclipse.jst.j2ee.core,1.0.0,org.eclipse.jst.j2ee.ejb,1.0.0,org.eclipse.jst.ejb.ui,1.0.0,org.eclipse.jst.j2ee.jca,1.0.0,org.eclipse.jst.j2ee.jca.ui,1.0.0,org.eclipse.jst.j2ee.migration.ui,1.0.0,org.eclipse.jst.j2ee.ui,1.0.0,org.eclipse.jst.j2ee.web,1.0.0,org.eclipse.jst.j2ee.webservice,1.0.0,org.eclipse.jst.servlet.ui,1.0.0,org.eclipse.jst.j2ee.navigator.ui,1.0.0,org.eclipse.jst.jsp.core,1.0.0,org.eclipse.jst.jsp.ui,1.0.0,org.eclipse.jst.common.annotations.controller,1.0.0,org.eclipse.jst.common.annotations.core,1.0.0,org.eclipse.jst.common.annotations.ui,1.0.0,org.eclipse.jst.common.frameworks,1.0.0,org.eclipse.jst.common.navigator.java,1.0.0,org.eclipse.jst.common.frameworks.ui,1.0.0,"/>   Note for future reference, if absolutely necessary to reproduce this the key to duplicating environment is the org.eclipse.wtp.releng project, v20041212_2400.  Using "load map projects" will get the 'correct' version of projects (about 100), and then the org.eclipse.jst feature project's feature.xml file should be 'rolled back' a revision or two to get the "0.0.0" version. [This and all prereqs, etc., in PDE target, would be needed to reproduce.]

desc: Non platform specific are being built as tar.gz whereas they should be built as zip.

title: Test failures due to expired keystore
desc: There are test failures in the latest builds because the keystore in the tests has expired. I'll generate a new one.

title: Create branch for integration build
desc: As per John's msg:    http://dev.eclipse.org/mhonarc/lists/eclipse-dev/msg09291.html We need to create the branch for the integration build.

title: [o.e.pde.build] dangling extensions
desc: The BuildScriptGenerator and FetchScriptGenerator application extensions are not implemented in org.eclipse.pde.build. These should either be removed (along with the strings from IPDEBuildConstants.java) or they should be re-implemented.   The BuildScriptGeneratorApplication functionality would useful for building RPMs from plugin SDK zips so my preference is to have them re-implemented. I am currently using a very small ant script that uses the eclipse.buildScripts task to achieve the same functionality.  I will implement these two extensions if they will be committed to cvs. Alternately, I can provide a patch to remove this stuff if you decide that you do not want this functionality. Please let me know.

title: mechanism for branding launchers
desc: Now that we have the ability to brand a windows launcher, we need a unified  mechanism to brand a set of launchers with a set of icons.  Perhaps just one  launcher at a time.  This would be done during a build.  You should expect to  be given the location of the source launcher, the platform and the set of  icons.  Build should do the rest ;-)

title: Move pde.build tests to Java 8
desc: And modernize it as much as possible. Provoked by bug 528408 uncovering that pde.build also blindly casts IRequirement to IRequiredCapability. The generification makes these obvious.

title: investigate ways of packaging from windows
desc: Currently we can't package linux (and other) platforms from windows because  Java zip etc does not allow permission setting and link file creation.    This  realy hurts the product packaging story as users pretty much have to find  themselves a linux box to package from.  Need to look around and see if anyone has solved this problem.  (anything in  1.5?  Anything in newer versions of Ant?)

title: Move pde.build to Java 8
desc: Modernize the codebase too.

title: Generify BundleHelper.acquireService
Stop trying to acquire PluginConverter
desc: It's gone for good now.

title: export fails with Erro dialog: srcdir attribute must be set!
desc: When I try to export my plugin as a directory, I get an error dialog and th directory is not created. The error reads:  Problems during export Reason: c:\workspace\.metadata\.plugins\org.eclipse.pde.ui\temp\org.eclipse.pde.container.feature\build.xml: 29: The following error occurred while executing this line: c:\workspace\.metadata\.plugins\org.eclipse.pde.ui\temp\org.eclipse.pde.container.feature\build.xml: 10: The following error occurred while executing this line: c:\workspace\myplugin\build.xml:192:The following error occurred while executing this line: c:\workspace\myplugin\build.xml:48: srcdir attribute must be set!  Worse, Eclipse deletes these build.xml files after the failure, so it is hard to figure out what is happening.  I did manage to capture the file before Eclipse removed it:  <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <project name="build" default="plugin_export"> 	<target name="plugin_export"> 		<pde.exportPlugins plugins="com.sas.tools.eclipse.editor.enhancements" destination="C:\djb\eclipse-extensions\com.sas.tools.eclipse.editor.enhancements-1.0.1\eclipse" exportType="directory" exportSource="true"/> 	</target> </project>   Note: at one time, I exported a Javadoc build as javadoc.xml, then renamed it as build.xml and later found that PDE export wiped out my build.xml. I suppose this is a separate defect, but PDE export should not erase a build.xml file, but should instead create its own pde-export.xml and run with ant -buildfile pde-export.xml  Now, I am no longer able to build/export my plugin.  I get the same error when I try to export as a single zip file. desc: Related to https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=550592 there is an error because  org.eclipse.pde.internal.build.tasks is not exported but org.eclipse.pde.internal.build.tasks.TaskHelper is used by  org.eclipse.pde.internal.core.ant.TargetPlatformProvisionTask.

title: Errors in feature.xml or plugin.xml very hard to diagnose
desc: In a very large build environment, we had one developer move a feature from  version 3.0.0 to 3.0.1 Unfortunately, there was a separate feature which had a "require" statement  looking for version 3.0.0 The error messages are copied below. This was running the build in a headless mode from the command line. Because we had no mechanism to determine where the break occurred, and because  the build is not tolerant of this sort of thing, our production development  environment was down for three days. We need either a more robust build tool, or better diagnostic messages so we  can diagnose and fix this sort of problem. Alternatively a "prescreen" step would be very useful. title: support for signing plugin jars as they are built
desc: we should able to add an incremental step to the build process to sign the jars  as they are build.  Suggest adding something to the build.properties (of course) to supply the  required information.  If that information is present and signing is turned on  then sign the jars.

title: Created build.xml uses deprecated attributes for jar, zip...
desc: For jar, zip, ear and war tasks the specific naming of the destination file  attribute (*file where * is replaced by the name of the task) have all been  deprecated in favor of setting the destfile attribute.  For example zipfile attribute for zip should be replaced with destfile.

title: JNLP export support
desc: It turns out that exporting for JNLP is very much like normal exporting.   Features map pretty directly onto .jnlp files.  The config.ini and launcher  code maps on to a top level .jnlp with the appropriate content and <extension>s  for the relevant "feature" .jnlp files.  The top level jnlp has main  (startup.jar), the splash and the config.ini values in <property> elements.  The plugin jars that are built need to be signed but otherwise can live in an  update site structure (i.e., in plugins/ dirs) with the .jnlp files in the  features/ dirs next to the related features.  The top level file goes at the  root of the site next to the site.xml file.  This way the plugins on an update  site can also be deployed as JNLP resources.  So, what we need is a way of generating this structure.  There are many  possible ways but in essence there is a toggle to gen the features and/or the  JNLP structure.  Everything else could remain.  Alternatively, we could always just generate the .jnlp files for the features.   They don't cost much.  The JNLP file for the top level may be harder.  If we  have an idea of the original config.ini that would help.  Even still, it is  reasonable that for JNLP deployments the settings might be different.  Interesting direction...

title: require tarargs property similar to current zipargs property
desc: We require support for a tarargs property much like the zipargs parameter used in the current pde build.  Certain versions of solaris and aix do not support gnu tar default options but this can be overcome by specifying arguments to tar.

title: org.eclipse.launcher feature no longer included in the delta pack
desc: In I20050201-0800, the delta pack does not contain the launcher feature which is supposed to provide the exes and root files for the various platforms.

title: Build site fails with non std. directory structures
desc: Observed with m4 (but also with prior milestones).  I have a workspace with 3 plugin projects, one feature project and one site project. all projects are physically not in the workspace but at different positions on the harddrive. the layout is something like this:  +dir1   + plugin 1   + plugin 2   + feature   + site +dir2   + plugin 3  the workspace looks something like this +plugin1 +plugin2 +plugin3 +feature +site  plugin1 and plugin2 both make use of plugin3.  if i try to build the site i get classnotfound/import not found errors from the compiler for each reference to plugin3. strangely a can generate a build.xml file from the feature and build the feature with build.update.jar without getting errors. another thing that also works is placing plugin3 right beside plugin1 then i can build the site as expected.  do you have an idea what the problem is? i did some searching in the bugzilla database and found some bugs with linked sourcefolders. but this seems to be something different.

title: Remove special handling of osgi.
desc: Early in 3.0 special code has been added to handle osgi classpath. This is no longer necessary and should be removed.

title: Cannot build when the target contains jar'ed plug-ins
desc: When the target contains jar'ed plug-ins, the export of an application fails because the build.xml can not be generated in the plug-in.  Details: To build an application, pde generates build.xml files for all the plug-ins that are required. The generated build.xml are being stored in the plugin folder. When running out of jars there is no place where to put the build.xml.

title: [launcher] Need support for 48x48 32bits
desc: I20050215-2300 I've been having a devil of a time trying to get the ICO support working in the Branding screen of the Product Configuration Editor. Sometimes it works, sometimes it doesn't, sometimes it works partially. It never gives any kind of error message so I have to unpack the zip and look at what it made to see if it's right or not. Even then, I can't trust my eyes. I will attach a file that demonstrates the latest problem I've seen.

title: Product export does not set executable permissions on eclipse executable
desc: When performing a product export (using the Product Configuration) the exported product had a executable called "eclipse" which would not run until the execute permissions were turn on.  This should not be necessary.

title: Verify the validity of the builder feature
desc: Make sure that the builder feature and the scripts provided are correct

title: PDE Export gives error in jar signer if you export the same feature twice
desc: 3.1M5a File > Export > Deployable Features Select two or more features Select option to Deploy as individual JAR archives Fill in a directory Fill in an Ant script name. Click Next Turn on Signing and JNLP and fill out the fields. Click Finish. An error dialog pops up that says:  Error: Problems during export Reason: d:\workspace\org.eclipse.update.configurator-feature\assemble.org.eclipse.update.configurator.win32.win32.x86.xml:51: The following error occurred while executing this one: d:\workspace\org.eclipse.update.configurator-feature\assemble.org.eclipse.update.configurator.win32.win32.x86.xml:15: The following error occurred while executing this one: d:\workspace\org.eclipse.update.configurator-feature\assemble.org.eclipse.update.configurator.win32.win32.x86.xml:23: exec returned: 1  The files that the error referenced are deleted by the time the dialog comes up but I managed to snag a copy. The last line it's complaining about says:  		<signjar jar="${source}/${elementName}.jar" alias="${sign.alias}" keystore="${sign.keystore}" storepass="${sign.storepass}"/>   Note jarsigner is on my path (JDK1.5.0_1). The alias, keystore, and password are ok. The export works if I select only one feature but fails with two or three.

title: ${tarargs} needs a default value in generated assemble script
desc: The $(tarargs) variable in the generated assemble scripts needs a default value so that ant doesn't treat it as a literal when it is not set. This stops releng plugins from building on linux systems.

title: features don't build correctly without bin.includes
desc: using the jared_target branch...  I had the hyperbola Jface feature and tried to export.  Target was all jard  plugins.  When the build.properties does not have a bin.includes line, the  build fails part way through (as soon as it goes to get the parts from the  target) and the jface product plugin is not jar'd (it is marked as unpack=false  in the feature).  I added    bin.includes=feature.xml and everything exports fine.

title: Exporting "Deployable plugins and fragments" fails in 3.1M5a
desc: After I switched over to 3.1M5a, I am unable to export a plugin.  It fails at 100% with a dialog (the image is attached).  I am able to export the same plugin using eclipse v3.0.

title: Need to set the archive format on a per config basis
desc: When the final archive is created by pde build, its format is hardcoded in pde build which is not very flexible.

title: The jarsigner call is only executed when the jarup target is being called
desc: In pde.build, the assembler / packager is responsible to sign jars. This is being done as part of the jarup target.   The fact that the signing is part of the jaring step is problematic since pde  can not sign existing jars (jaring seems to do nothing then it is being asked  to jar a jar).

title: Ensure that plugins with . and another jar on the classpath work properly
desc: The support to build plugins with . on the classpath is working. However we need to ensure that a plugin which would have . and a jar on its  classpath can be built successfully.

title: ensure that all jars are closed by PDE State
desc: Wassim did some cleanup in his code that is a derivative from PDE build one ( https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=78526). It must be verified that all files are closed properly as well by pde state in pde build.

title: Subsequent builds of the same plugin behaves weird and wrong
desc: Using the latest pde.build, pde.core and pde.ui  SCENARIO 1  1. Create a Hello world plugin 'com.example.xyz'  2. Export the plugin into a directory (D:/Temp).  Leave the 'Package each plug- in in a JAR archive' option unchecked.  Everything will export fine.  Now for the problems.    SCENARIO 2 1. Export the same plugin into the SAME directory (D:/Temp), but this time do  check the 'Package each plug-in in a JAR archive' option. 2. You will see that the JAR is correctly created into D:/Temp/plugins, BUT... the directory created from scenario 1 has been deleted.   SCENARIO 3 Try to repeat in scenario 1 using the exact same plugin.  A flat directory  structure could never be created at this point.  For some unknown reason, a  JAR keeps getting created no matter what.

title: new method on StateObjectFactory
desc: Over this coming weekend Tom will be releasing a change to StateObjectFactory  to require a State object when creating a bundle description.  This is needed  to enable some new resolver features.  I will attach a patch which adapts to this change.  Pleaes release for the I  build next Tues. (if you like the patch that is).  PDE should continue to work  without the patch but it will not get full function out of the resolver going  forward.

title: Can't export an Eclipse product with source
desc: latest pde.core/pde.build/pde.ui from HEAD (or use the code from the upcoming  I-20050315 build).  1. Fresh workspace. 2. Create an RCP mail template. 3. Create a sample.product file based on product from 2. 4. Invoke the export wizard from the first page of the product editor. 5. Export the config as zip file.  The export will fail.  Screenshot to follow.

title: Export of product as folders leave the root files in the wrong location
desc: When exporting to a directory, the root files are not appropriately located.  They are put in a directory named "<os>.<ws>.<arch>" sibling of the eclipse  folder.

title: PDE Build does not set the plaform properties when resolving
desc: When PDE Build resolve the state of the target being built, it does not set the  platform properties (State.setPlatformProperties()) which cause bundles using  platform filters to be unresolved.

title: Investigate support for generating .api_description files for bundles that are not API tools enabled
desc: +++ This bug was initially created as a clone of Bug #330947 +++  Current the ApiFileGenerationTask will short-circuit if the bundle it is run on does not have the API tools nature. We should investigate some level of support for generating an .api_description file for bundles without the API tools nature.  The benefit of this is that a build process could make use of the other API tasks without having to explicitly modify all of the bundles to be API tools enabled.  +++  Users can set alloNonApiProject=true to run the task on   Since users often access this task using PDE Build support, we should allow this setting to be accessed through PDE Build.  We will probably need to modify ModelBuildScriptGenerator#generateAPIToolsTarget and #generateAPIToolsCall and set a default value for the property in ModelBuildScriptGenerator#generatePrologue.  We might be able to get away without a default as not setting the property is equivalent to setting it to false.

title: Export to folder must check if some root files exists
desc: The AssembleConfigScriptGenerator has been changed to move the root files to the proper folder when  exporting to a folder, however the code that do the move call does not verify there are root files to  move. This must be done to avoid errors. Note also that the delete call should not fail is nothing needs to be deleted.

title: PDE Build must set a profile when resolving
desc: With the new work going on in osgi where bundles will be able to import classes from the JRE, PDE will  have to set a JRE profile when invoking the resolver.

title: When compiling a plug-in with dot on the classpath some copy could be avoided
desc: When a plug-in with dot on the classpath is being compiled it seems that some  copy could be avoided in the task that compiles the code.

title: Corrupted features should not prevent export of plug-ins
desc: Created attachment 213710 [details] The exception stacktrace  1. Create one Plug-in project 2. Create one Feature project 3. In the feature.xml add following empty tag:    <requires>    </requires> 4. Try to export the created plug-in project as "Deployable plug-ins and fragments"  Result: Exception occurs that the created feature cannot be parsed.  My first question is: why when I am trying to export a concrete plugin, all resources from the workspace are trying to be built? And the second one is: wouldn't it be better if there is a validation of the feature.xml, saying that this is not a valid feature xml element.

title: Many PDE Build Unit test Errors on new Mac (with new JDK)
desc: After switching to the new 64 bit mac, we recently moved up to a more recent version of JDK so it would have "source" (whereas the built in one, had only JRE).   Not sure if/how long these build errors have been occuring, but noticed them in last night's 2230 N build.  http://download.eclipse.org/eclipse/downloads/drops4/N20121018-2330/testresults/html/org.eclipse.pde.build.tests_macosx.cocoa.x86_5.0.html  (and, despite the naming of the file, it really is a 64 bit machine, using 64 bit Java 7).   Many tests fail (actually error) with   /Library/Java/JavaVirtualMachines/jdk1.7.0_10.jdk/Contents/Home/Classes does not exist.   So, not sure if something is mis-configured? Or if test is just very VM specific?   Thought'd I'd share what I know.   I set JAVA_HOME env variable to  /Library/Java/JavaVirtualMachines/jdk1.7.0_10.jdk/Contents/Home/ (following previous setting) but ... I do notice that the self reported property,  java.home, is  java.home=/Library/Java/JavaVirtualMachines/jdk1.7.0_10.jdk/Contents/Home/jre  Should env. variable end with /jre ?   In either case, I don't easily see a "Classes" directory in either:   JAVA_HOME: /Library/Java/JavaVirtualMachines/jdk1.7.0_10.jdk/Contents/Home/ + /Library/Java/JavaVirtualMachines/jdk1.7.0_10.jdk/Contents/Home/jre/bin/java -version java version "1.7.0_10-ea" Java(TM) SE Runtime Environment (build 1.7.0_10-ea-b09) Java HotSpot(TM) 64-Bit Server VM (build 23.6-b03, mixed mode)  + ls -l /Library/Java/JavaVirtualMachines/jdk1.7.0_10.jdk/Contents/Home/ total 39720 -rw-rw-r--   1 root  wheel      3339 Sep 26 07:05 COPYRIGHT -rw-rw-r--   1 root  wheel        40 Sep 26 07:06 LICENSE -rw-rw-r--   1 root  wheel       114 Sep 26 07:06 README.html -rw-rw-r--   1 root  wheel    123324 Sep 25 21:04 THIRDPARTYLICENSEREADME-JAVAFX.txt -rw-rw-r--   1 root  wheel    172252 Sep 26 07:06 THIRDPARTYLICENSEREADME.txt drwxrwxr-x  43 root  wheel      1462 Sep 26 07:07 bin drwxrwxr-x   9 root  wheel       306 Sep 26 07:05 db drwxrwxr-x   9 root  wheel       306 Sep 26 07:06 include drwxrwxr-x  10 root  wheel       340 Sep 25 21:04 jre drwxrwxr-x  13 root  wheel       442 Sep 26 07:07 lib drwxrwxr-x   5 root  wheel       170 Sep 25 21:04 man -rw-rw-r--   1 root  wheel       447 Sep 26 07:06 release -rw-rw-r--   1 root  wheel  20014853 Sep 26 07:06 src.zip   + ls -l /Library/Java/JavaVirtualMachines/jdk1.7.0_10.jdk/Contents/Home/jre total 624 -rw-rw-r--   1 root  wheel    3339 Sep 26 07:06 COPYRIGHT -rw-rw-r--   1 root  wheel      40 Sep 26 07:06 LICENSE -rw-rw-r--   1 root  wheel      46 Sep 26 07:06 README -rw-rw-r--   1 root  wheel  123324 Sep 25 21:04 THIRDPARTYLICENSEREADME-JAVAFX.txt -rw-rw-r--   1 root  wheel  172252 Sep 26 07:06 THIRDPARTYLICENSEREADME.txt -rw-rw-r--   1 root  wheel     955 Sep 26 07:06 Welcome.html drwxrwxr-x  12 root  wheel     408 Sep 25 21:04 bin drwxrwxr-x  98 root  wheel    3332 Sep 25 21:04 lib

title: Compilation of the swt 32 and 64 bits simulateneously fails when building as jars
desc: In a non-jared SWT case, when a plug-in requires SWT, it gets the following  classpath: org.eclipse.swt.gtk64/${ws}/swt.jar org.eclipse.swt.win32/${ws}/swt.jar org.eclipse.swt.macosx/${ws}/swt.jar  The ${ws} is of importance since it is being set by the caller resulting in  only one entry to be valid (since there is no such thing as  o.e.swt.win32/gtk64/swt.jar).  However in jared form the classpath entries are org.eclipse.swt.gtk64/@dot org.eclipse.swt.win32/@dot org.eclipse.swt.macosx/@dot  which leads to inconsistencies when plugins refer to internal classes (for  example ui.carbon).   All that could be fine

title: [jars] plugin import with source cannot reverse engineer a JARd plugin
desc: Let me start by explaining how importing a flat plugin with source works: 1. We create a new project for the plugin being imported. 2. We import all the files and folders from the target plugin into the project. 3. for each library declared by the plugin:     a. we locate its corresponding source zip and unzip it in a separate  source folder in the project.     b. we crack the library JAR open and we extract all the resources (i.e.  non-*.class files) and put them in the source folder. 4. We then create an appropriate build.properties file.  When dealing with JARd plugin, it is currently impossible to figure out how to  lay out the plugin project structure, since all files in the JARd plugin are  at the root.  what files/folders should go at the root of the project and what  files/folders should go into a src folder?  Here is the best I could come up with for now: 1. Import src.zip at the root of the project. 2. Import all the non-*.class files from the JARd plugin into the root of the  project. Two problems: 1. the source is at the root of the project which is typically discouraged. 2. what will the source.. entry of the build.properties now contain?  We must be able to support an import-export round trip while keeping the  plugin intact.

title: Delta pack is incorrect
desc: Now that SWT is being shipped as jar, the delta pack is incomplete because the  *so files are not gathered.  Context: The content of a fragment such as motif varies on the platform for which it is  being shipped. For example on linux, it will contain some native libs in    os/linux/x86/a.so  whereas on solaris the libs will be in os/solaris/risc/a.so.  When the packager is running on a non jared target, all the so files are being  copied in the org.eclipse.swt.motif folder and that was fine.  However now that we are shipping as jars, one jar overrides the other which  results in having only one set of library.  Sidenote: One thing that strikes me in this problem, is that SWT does not  respect the rule of one "id (fragment / plugin)" == "content" == "one set of  bytes".  There are several options to solve this problem: 1) SWT ships in multiple fragments:     org.eclipse.swt     org.eclipse.swt.motif (contains the classes)     org.eclipse.swt.motif.solaris (contains the native libs)     org.eclipse.swt.motif.linux (contains the native libs only) This one is nice since the fragments can be enabled on an os basis. On RCP use  case, it forces people to put more things in their config.ini, but the size of  the resulting app is optimal.  2) SWT put all the libs all the time:     org.eclipse.swt     org.eclipse.swt.motif (contains the classes and all the native libs for all  the platforms) Drawback: the download is bigger and the size of apps is bigger.   3) The Delta pack script does some magic to reassemble from the various SWT  jars one big jar. This jar (which is equivalent to the one we would create in  the solution 2) has the same drawbacks than the solution 2.

title: PDE Build must use the new platform properties API
desc: See bug 88226

title: FetchScriptGenerator adds  an extra "Fetching  " string
desc: Fetch script generator adds a "Fetching " infront of the unless="${fileToCheck}"  task. This causes the cvs to attempt unncessary exports during a build.    script.printTargetDeclaration(..., "Fetching ${fileToCheck}", ...);

title: unpack = false has no effect
desc: Using I-20050329-1105 and latest pde.ui from HEAD  1. create an rcp mail template with . on the classpath 2. create a sample.product based on product defined in 1. 3. bring up the product export wizard.   You will notice that the export options have now been simplified, as we will  implicitly add unpack=true/false in the fake feature.  Export the product.  In the container feature, I will set unpack=false for the  rcp mail plugin, but it still shows up as flat.

title: Unable to export plugins
desc: I20050330  * Select a plugin project that is source in the workspace (for example,  org.eclispe.debug.core) * Select "Export > Deployable plugins..." * Specify location and press finish > the following error appears:  Problems during export:  Reason:  c:\eclipse3.1\dev\.metadata\.plugins\org.eclipse.pde.ui\temp\org.eclipse.pde  The following error occurred while on this line:  c:\eclispe3.1\dev\org.eclipse.debug.core\build.xml:104: c:\eclipse3.1\dev\.metadata\.plugins\org.eclipse.pde.ui\temp\destination\plug not found  The line ending in "plug" is cutoff. I cannot read the entire message.

title: Branded executable does not have the proper permissions
desc: The branding iron renames the executable file to give it the proper name, which cause the loss of the permisssions.  Two solutions: - force a chmod when renaming the exe - set the permissions after the packaging steps on folder (note that now we are doing something similar to set the proper permission in the archives).

title: [doc] update the doc for the tasks
Product export creates empty .app directory structure on Mac
desc: When using 3.1M6 on MacOSX to export a product, the resulting eclipse.app directory structure doesn't contain anything (except subdirectories). The eclipse executable is placed in the directory containing eclipse.app and can be executed,  resulting in a terminal opening and the RCP application being started.  This looks a bit like the opposite of bug 89951 (which pertains to Windows 2000, though)

title: hard paths in generated build.xml, what about bytecode-enhancing?
desc: This is effecively the same as bug 85090 but it wasn't filed against PDE yet. In the <pluginname>.jar target in the generated build.xml for a plugin, there are paths to be found like the following: <pathelement path="../../Programme/eclipse3.1/M5/eclipse/plugins/org.eclipse.osgi_3.1.0/osgi.jar"/>  This only works on other machines if Eclipse is installed in the same directory structure as on the generating machine, let alone Eclipse on other platforms (e.g. Mac). This is a problem mostly for "custom = true" in the build.properties, when one starts off with a generated build.xml. It would be good if the Eclipse install directory could be configured in the build.properties.  I'm using a custom build.xml anyway only because I need some bytecode-enhancement in the build process, which is common at least with JDO based applications. I'm not very ant-savvy, but wouldn't it somehow be possible to configure a bytecode-enhancing task incl. classpath to be invoked between compilation and jar packaging? I mean, in a way that makes custom build unnecessary.   I don't really trust custom build.xml, because I never know what a newly generated build.xml looks like (and potentially must look like) in future versions of Eclipse.

title: some assemble scripts broken in M6
desc: Hi there. I'm currently responsible for releng of the CDT. Now that we've migrated to Eclipse M6, I am having issues with our build scripts. The assemble scripts that are generated for our linux,gtk,x86_64 and linux,gtk,ia64 configs do not contain the commands to tar up the build results. I am also seeing this in our test feature which has *,*,* for it's config. All our other configs seem fine.  These all worked when we did our build with M4. We skipped M5a and only moved to M6 since M4 doesn't handle the plugins as jars correctly.  I'd be happy to supply more info if you need.

title: fetch conditional should be based on file other than plugin.xml
desc: The generated fetch targets execute based on the non-existance of a plugin.xml in the plugin directories.   This results in an attempted cvs export for the plugins which use manifests only, thus longer overall build time.  This does not break anything, however with the recent slowdown of checkout from dev.eclipse.org lately, this might be worth investigating.

title: Jared plugins contains the @dot folder
desc: In M6, when creating a build in a releng style mode, the jars contains the @dot folder.

title: Change the source plugin to generate Manifest
desc: PDE builds generates source plugins from templates located in eclipse. We need to change those, but be careful with backward compatibility (2.1).

title: Feature scripts must be generated bottom up
desc: When generating the scripts, the scripts for the plugins are generated before the one from the included  feature which causes some problem when computing the classpath.

title: rootFiles* targets in build.xml may need overwrite="true"
desc: In a test build I ran this morning with PDE from HEAD, the SDKs produced  contained the configuration directory that should be used in the RCP drops,  thus the SDK could not run.  I think the problem is caused by the RCP feature  rootfiles being copied before the platform root files.  Without the  overwrite="true" in the call to <copy> we end up with the wrong config.ini  file for Platform and SDK drops.

title: [doc] need to document the new property on eclipse.buildScript
desc: So far: archivesFormat has been added.

title: AssembleConfigScriptGenerator.generateMoveRootFiles should try to use mv
desc: When exporting to a folder, generateMoveRootFiles move files using ant move, which  causes the loss of permissions.

title: Version of first plugin in feature.xml not updated by IdReplaceTask
desc: CVS module: org.eclipse.pde.build  Class: org.eclipse.pde.internal.build.tasks.IdReplaceTask  Versions: 3.0 and 3.1. Other versions not tested.  Description: If the feature.xml file contains a <requires> section infront of a <plugin> element and the <requires> section contains <import plugin ...> then the version number of  the first plugin that follows the <requires> section is not  updated.  Example feature.xml file: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <feature       id="featureId"       label="%featureName"       version="1.0.0"       provider-name="%providerName"       primary="true">     <install-handler/>     <description>       %description    </description>     <copyright url="[Enter Copyright URL here.]">       [Enter Copyright Description here.]    </copyright>     <license url="[Enter License URL here.]">       [Enter License Description here.]    </license>     <requires>       <import plugin="org.eclipse.core.runtime.compatibility"/>       <import plugin="org.eclipse.gef"/>       <import plugin="org.eclipse.ui.ide"/>       <import plugin="org.eclipse.jface"/>       <import plugin="org.eclipse.ui"/>       <import plugin="org.eclipse.ui.views"/>       <import plugin="org.eclipse.core.resources"/>       <import plugin="org.eclipse.debug.core"/>       <import plugin="org.eclipse.debug.ui"/>       <import plugin="org.eclipse.core.runtime"/>       <import plugin="org.apache.ant"/>       <import plugin="org.eclipse.ui.forms"/>       <import plugin="org.eclipse.ui.editors"/>       <import plugin="org.eclipse.ui.console"/>       <import plugin="org.eclipse.ui.workbench.texteditor"/>       <import plugin="org.eclipse.jface.text"/>       <import plugin="org.eclipse.update.ui"/>       <import plugin="org.eclipse.search"/>    </requires>     <plugin          id="plugin1"          download-size="0"          install-size="0"          version="0.0.0"/> <!-- remains 0.0.0 -->     <plugin          id="plugin2"          download-size="0"          install-size="0"          version="0.0.0"/> <!-- updated to version from plugins manifest file - ->    </feature>

title: Missing Ant JAR from help
desc: The library "ant_tasks/helpbase-ant.jar" specified  from "org.eclipse.help.base" for the extraClasspathEntries extension does not  exist.

title: Export Deployable plug-ins always exports JARed
desc: Scenario:  1) Check out org.eclipse.help.base from HEAD 2) Export it using 'Export Deployable Plug-ins and Fragaments'. Select to  export in a directory, and DO NOT check to be JARed.  The plug-in builds without errors, but the result is one JAR in the  destination.  Expectation: I wanted to see unJARed plug-in there.  Another problem: the Ant task JAR compiled without errors but didn't appear in  the final result. I know it compiled because originally I didn't have  org.eclipse.ant in the workspace and it reported build errors.

title: zipargs unset
desc: 3.1M6  In headless build, if property 'zipargs' is left unset, the archive file create is named "${zipargs}.zip" and located in "assembleTempDir" which is removed at end of archiving.  Take a look at the generated 'assemble......feature.xml' of a build.  The zip task is invoked:      <exec executable="zip" dir="${assemblyTempDir}"> 	<arg line="-r -q ${zipargs} ${archiveFullPath}"/> 	<arg line="${featureArchivePrefix}/...."/>  See that if zipargs is unset, then zip creates the file "${zipargs}"  The build-template.properties file in plugins/org.eclipse.pde.build../scripts should be chnaged to set zipargs to empty string, or the assemble script generator should set zipars to empty string, or both.

title: Generated assemble.elt.cfg.xml scripts fail in path containing spaces
desc: If I use pde.build to generate my build scripts, the generated scripts will fail if my basedir has a space in the path.  The culprits are the calls in assemble.<element>.<config>.xml to exec tar and rm and zip.  The arg line needs to be quoted properly but is not.  Changes are required to at least AssembleConfigScriptGenerator.generateTarTarget, generateGZipTarget, createZipRootFileCommand, and createZipExecCommand. (these three were sufficient in my use case).  The correct output should be as follows (note the use of the single quotes):      <exec executable="tar" dir="${assemblyTempDir}">         <arg line="-cvf ${tarargs} '${archiveFullPath}' ${archivePrefix} "/>     </exec>      <exec executable="rm">         <arg line="-rf"/>         <arg line="'${assemblyTempDir}'"/>     </exec>  and so on.  Following is a patch to correct the problem.  Index: AssembleConfigScriptGenerator.java =================================================================== RCS file: /home/eclipse/org.eclipse.pde.build/src/org/eclipse/pde/internal/build/AssembleConfigScriptGenerator.java,v retrieving revision 1.52 diff -u -r1.52 AssembleConfigScriptGenerator.java --- AssembleConfigScriptGenerator.java	14 Apr 2005 23:04:06 -0000	1.52 +++ AssembleConfigScriptGenerator.java	22 Apr 2005 09:08:06 -0000 @@ -216,7 +216,7 @@  				getPropertyFormat(PROPERTY_ARCHIVE_FULLPATH));  		List args = new ArrayList(2);  		args.add("-rf"); //$NON-NLS-1$ -		args.add(getPropertyFormat(PROPERTY_ASSEMBLY_TMP)); +		args.add("'" + getPropertyFormat(PROPERTY_ASSEMBLY_TMP) + "'");  //$NON-NLS-1$//$NON-NLS-2$  		script.printExecTask("rm", null, args, null); //$NON-NLS-1$  	}   @@ -459,12 +459,12 @@  			return;    		List parameters = new ArrayList(1); -		parameters.add("-r -q ${zipargs} " + getPropertyFormat(PROPERTY_ARCHIVE_FULLPATH) + " . "); //$NON-NLS-1$ //$NON-NLS-2$ //$NON-NLS-3$ +		parameters.add("-r -q ${zipargs} '" + getPropertyFormat(PROPERTY_ARCHIVE_FULLPATH) + "' . "); //$NON-NLS-1$ //$NON-NLS-2$ //$NON-NLS-3$  		script.printExecTask("zip", getPropertyFormat(PROPERTY_ECLIPSE_BASE) + '/' + configInfo.toStringReplacingAny(".", ANY_STRING), parameters, null); //$NON-NLS-1$ //$NON-NLS-2$ //$NON-NLS-3$ //$NON-NLS-4$  	}    	private void createZipExecCommand(List parameters) { -		parameters.add(0, "-r -q " + getPropertyFormat(PROPERTY_ZIP_ARGS) + ' ' + getPropertyFormat(PROPERTY_ARCHIVE_FULLPATH)); //$NON-NLS-1$ +		parameters.add(0, "-r -q " + getPropertyFormat(PROPERTY_ZIP_ARGS) + " '" + getPropertyFormat(PROPERTY_ARCHIVE_FULLPATH) + "'"); //$NON-NLS-1$ //$NON-NLS-2$ //$NON-NLS-3$  		script.printExecTask("zip", getPropertyFormat(PROPERTY_ASSEMBLY_TMP), parameters, null); //$NON-NLS-1$ //$NON-NLS-2$ //$NON-NLS-3$  	}   @@ -477,15 +477,15 @@  		//Need to do the copy using cp because of the link  		List parameters = new ArrayList(2);  		if (rootFileProviders.size() > 0) { -			parameters.add("-r " + getPropertyFormat(PROPERTY_ASSEMBLY_TMP) + '/' + getPropertyFormat(PROPERTY_COLLECTING_FOLDER) + '/' + configInfo.toStringReplacingAny(".", ANY_STRING) + '/' + getPropertyFormat(PROPERTY_COLLECTING_FOLDER) + ' ' + getPropertyFormat(PROPERTY_ASSEMBLY_TMP)); //$NON-NLS-1$ //$NON-NLS-2$   +			parameters.add("-r '" + getPropertyFormat(PROPERTY_ASSEMBLY_TMP) + '/' + getPropertyFormat(PROPERTY_COLLECTING_FOLDER) + '/' + configInfo.toStringReplacingAny(".", ANY_STRING) + '/' + getPropertyFormat(PROPERTY_COLLECTING_FOLDER) + "' '" + getPropertyFormat(PROPERTY_ASSEMBLY_TMP) + "'"); //$NON-NLS-1$ //$NON-NLS-2$ //$NON-NLS-3$ //$NON-NLS-4$    			script.printExecTask("cp", getPropertyFormat(PROPERTY_BASEDIR), parameters, null); //$NON-NLS-1$    			parameters.clear(); -			parameters.add("-rf " + getPropertyFormat(PROPERTY_ASSEMBLY_TMP) + '/' + getPropertyFormat(PROPERTY_COLLECTING_FOLDER) + '/' + configInfo.toStringReplacingAny(".", ANY_STRING)); //$NON-NLS-1$ //$NON-NLS-2$ +			parameters.add("-rf '" + getPropertyFormat(PROPERTY_ASSEMBLY_TMP) + '/' + getPropertyFormat(PROPERTY_COLLECTING_FOLDER) + '/' + configInfo.toStringReplacingAny(".", ANY_STRING) + "'"); //$NON-NLS-1$ //$NON-NLS-2$ //$NON-NLS-3$  			script.printExecTask("rm", getPropertyFormat(PROPERTY_BASEDIR), parameters, null); //$NON-NLS-1$  		}  		parameters.clear(); -		parameters.add("-cvf " + getPropertyFormat(PROPERTY_TAR_ARGS) + ' ' + getPropertyFormat(PROPERTY_ARCHIVE_FULLPATH) + ' ' + getPropertyFormat(PROPERTY_ARCHIVE_PREFIX) + ' '); //$NON-NLS-1$ +		parameters.add("-cvf " + getPropertyFormat(PROPERTY_TAR_ARGS) + " '" + getPropertyFormat(PROPERTY_ARCHIVE_FULLPATH) + "' " + getPropertyFormat(PROPERTY_ARCHIVE_PREFIX) + ' '); //$NON-NLS-1$ //$NON-NLS-2$ //$NON-NLS-3$  		script.printExecTask("tar", getPropertyFormat(PROPERTY_ASSEMBLY_TMP), parameters, null); //$NON-NLS-1$   	}

title: option to generate updateJar from releng style build
desc: There is no option to generate update jars in a releng style build. Adding an option on the buildScriptGenerator task could be good.

title: archivesFormat is redundant
desc: Do we need a separate archivesFormat property?  Could the -antZip (whatever)  just be included in the list of configs?  Seems error prone to have two lists  with alot of the same info.  Alternatively, perhaps archivesFormat could be  optional.  Assume antZip for all configs unless told otherwise?

title: support for crossplatform/releng/product build
desc: I will attach a patch shortly that updates PDE Build to do the following - cross platform builds both from the workspace and in releng mode - brands launchers regardless of whether or not you are exporting features or  products - brands based on information in the product file (if availabel) - does multiple platforms at once - improved scripts and templates to make life easier for people setting up a  releng style build - and much more...  Pascal and I have reviewed and it looks good.  Remaining issues - The bulid.properties for the platform.launchers feature should use  ${launcherName} for setting permissions.  This code path has not been tested.

title: Potential NPE in FeatureBuildScriptGenerator
desc: I0426, found with FindBugs code analysis tool  FeatureBuildScriptGenerator line 1051 checks if templateManifestURL is null, and iff it is then the next line does templateManifestURL.toExternalForm(), which is guaranteed to NPE.  FeatureBuildScriptGenerator lines 1132/1133 do something similar.

title: Product Export Fails
desc: Latest pde.core, pde.build and pde.ui from HEAD.  1. Create an rcp mail template. 2. Create a product file based on product in 1. 3. Try to export to a directory. The export will fail.  Some failure during the assembly process. Screenshot to  follow.  Other than that, there are a few other issues:  1. PDE/build tries to "convert" the fake feature and throws an exception into  the log when it fails to do so. I suspect this has to do with the fact that we "still" set the feature URLs  using the BuildScriptGenerator#setPluginPath(...).  It would be better if  PDE/Build introduced a new unambiguous API for setting feature URLs.  2. Every time I export, the following line gets printed to the console: org.eclipse.osgi.internal.resolver.StateDeltaImpl@1b5b632  Somewhere there is a print out statement.

title: NPE in DevClassPathHelper#load(URL)
desc: (copied from bug 93787)  NPE may happen in org.eclipse.pde.internal.build.builder.DevClassPathHelper#load(URL) if an IOException is thrown when calling URL#openStream(). The finally block tries to close the stream without checking first whether the stream was appropriately obtained. The effect is that if an IOException occurs while opening the stream, the NPE will hide it.

title: need to chmod when exporting to a directory
desc: Build: M7 candidate  Try it on gtk.   Create an RCP mail template and try to export it as a directory structure.  The resulting product has everything correct, but you would need to manually  chmod the executable to be able to launch it.  The build.properties for the fake feature does specify the following line: root.permissions.755 = <name of launcher>
