title: Review usage of tranfer stream
desc: In 93623, the problems were caused by the transferStream method as well as the reader. The transferStream method has been used in other places and they should be check to ensure PDE build is DBCS friendly.

title: errors in log on successful build
desc:
i0509-2010  I am building a feature that has some plugins being compiled and some already  compiled.  The build completes successfully but the log for the biuld is full  of the following entries.  It seems that there is one for every target plugin  (which of course do not have build.properties files).  For larger targets there  may well be 100s or 1000s of plugins so one entry per plugin per build is going  to add up pretty fast.  Can we turn these off?  Perhaps only show them in debug  mode or something?   eclipse.buildId=I20050509-2010 java.version=1.4.2_04 java.vendor=Sun Microsystems Inc. title: Filtering out what is copied to the plugin jar
desc: In our scenario it is really important to keep our generated jars as small as we can (our code is also available to stand-alone applications).  Because of that, we have to be extra careful with what is copied into the jar.  Right now, this is how the PDE generated build.xml copies the files:  <copy todir="${temp.folder}/runtime/codegen.jar.bin" failonerror="true" overwrite="false">   <fileset dir="src/" excludes="**/*.java, **/package.htm*"/> </copy>  It is great that the package.htm* is being excluded.  But this task is not considering, for example, the "doc-files" directories (that usually contains pictures used by the package.html).  It would be great if the snippet above could be generated using a property to define what is supposed to be copied.  For example:  <property name="notJarredFiles" value="**/*.java, **/package.htm*"/> <copy todir="${temp.folder}/runtime/codegen.jar.bin" failonerror="true" overwrite="false">   <fileset dir="src/" excludes="${notJarredFiles}"/> </copy>  This is a very small change that increase a lot the control we have over the build end result with almost zero risk of regressions.  I believe something similar would have to be done for the scripts that create "jarred" plugins.

title: qualifier in version id not replaced when exporting plug-in
desc: i200505130010  In M6, exporting a plug-in that had the string 'qualifier' in the version id would nicely replace it with a timestamp. This does not work anymore. Was the functionality dropped, or does the user have to make anything to make it work?

title: should be able to set qualifier globally
desc: Currently we can spec 1.1.1.qualifier in the manfiest for a plugin and than add    qualifier=context in the build.properties.    At build time the context is computed as either the CVS tag used to check out  or the time at which teh plugin in being built.  Builder need the ability to set the context explicitly.  For example, this  allows them to have all elements of a build stamped the same way.  So for  example, a build property like    qualifier.context=Foo might make sense.  Related to this, perhaps we can treat   qualifier=context in the plugin build.properties as a default.  that is, if a plugin/feature  has .qualifier at the end of its version number, assume that the  qualifier=context and don't require the developer to set that property in the  build.properties.

title: Build/Build from the update site editor doesn't create feature jar in Linux GTK
desc: The jar contaning the feature.xml is not created when clicking on either build or build all in the update site editor. Instead a directory containing the feature.xml is created.

title: Wrong property in build.properties template
desc: The template build.properties for custom component scripts in automated PDE builds containes a wrong property. (3.1M7)  The template containse: javacfailonerror  But the generated build.xml files look for: javacFailOnError  Note the Ant properties are case sensitive.

title: Generated /META-INF/MANIFEST.MF for source plugins not terminated by line break
desc: N20050523-0010  The generated /META-INF/MANIFEST.MF for source plugins are not terminated by a line break. This causes compile errors when importing plugins as source:  Severity	Description	Resource	In Folder	Location	Creation Time 2	Header must be terminated by a line break. title: <offline-allowed/> element in wrong place in generated JNLP file
desc: When you export a feature as a Java WebStart application, the generated JNLP file inserts the <offline-allowed/> tag in the wrong place.  According to http://java.sun.com/j2se/1.4.2/docs/guide/jws/developersguide/syntax.html#information, it should be placed nested the <information> tag.  Actually, it is placed between <information> and <security> tags.

title: Source plugins are not marked as singleton
desc: The source plugins in the sdk all have extensions.  However, their manifest.mf  does not contain the singleton directive.  therefore, all these extensions are  ignored by the registry.

title: Source plug-ins missing provider
desc: build N20050523  - Help > About > Plug-in Details  The source plug-ins have a blank Provider.  They should have the following entry in the MANIFEST.MF:  Bundle-Vendor: %providerName  and in the plugin.properties: providerName = Eclipse.org

title: Templates for source 2.1 plugins are invalid
desc: I've just realized that the templates we are using for the generation 2.1 source plugins have always been invalid. What is interesting is that no one has ever been bugged by it :) Still I would like to fix the problem, since it is straightforward.

title: [readme] Export  |  Deployable plug-ins and fragments silently drops .class files with long paths
desc: I tend to use descriptive class names and on large projects I wind up nesting packages quite deep. This problem arose for me when I used nested classes (82-character package path, 53-character class name, 59-character inner class name) but a simple test using a ridiculously long package path and a simple class showed the problem too.  When I 'Export...' my plug-in with 'Deployable plug-ins and fragments', the JAR file excludes .class files with very long paths. Personnally, I can live with this (now I know to avoid it) but the problem happens without any warning so it's likely to cause problems for people who don't know about the issue.   Jeff

title: Ability to specify default build.properties
desc: I am doing builds of packages and update sites that include zips of compiled  plugins from other sources. Since they are pre-compiled, they do not include build.properties or build.xml. The build requires at least a build.properties containing a bin.includes line  for the build to run successfully. I use a small perl script to run through the tree and create build.properties  files if they are not already present, but I think this functionality could be  better handled by PDE. I would like to see the ability to create a defaukt behaviour other than  failure if a build.properties file is not present.

title: qualifier=context should be the default
desc: currently if you want to have PDE build qualifiy your build with the context  you have to both set your plugin version ot 1.0.0.qualifier and put     qualifier=context in your build.properties.  The normal case is that someone would want the qualifier to be the context so  they shuld not have to set the build.properties value.  Assuming this is a two line change, we should consider it as a polish item for  RC2.

title: Control the ordering of the root files
desc: RC1. The order in which root files are being copied is not guaranteed, however there are many scenarios where making this order clear would help.

title: package.all.xml does not get generated when running packager with 3.1RC1
desc: I'm trying to run the packager to generate platform drops for Intel based on their linux-gtk-ia64 drop.  With the new rc1 plugins plus the new pde build you gave Sonia, I have the following error   BUILD FAILED /home/kmoir/3.1rc1/eclipse/plugins/org.eclipse.pde.build_3.1.0/scripts/package.xml:62: The following error occurred while executing this line: /home/kmoir/3.1rc1/eclipse/plugins/org.eclipse.pde.build_3.1.0/scripts/package.xml:48: The following error occurred while executing this line: java.io.FileNotFoundException: /home/kmoir/ia64-platform/workingPlace/package.all.xml (No such file or directory)  The issue is that the package.all.xml is not generated by pde build.  This does work with the delta pack in our test build.  However, in this case deltaPack=true.  In the example I am using deltaPack=false.  I will attach my packaging files.

When I checked my log file, I found the following stack trace.  !SESSION 2005-06-01 14:10:40.568 ----------------------------------------------- eclipse.buildId=I20050527-1300 java.version=1.5.0_02 java.vendor=Sun Microsystems Inc. title: The generation of build scripts for generated features is not recursive
desc: When a generated feature includes another feature, the scripts for the included feature does not get generated which causes the build to fails. This causes problem to the releng team to produce the rcp source feature.

title: Weird errors from headless PDE Build
desc: Headless PDE build is causing a perplexing compile error:       [java]     [javac] 1. ERROR in C:\jbosside-build\eclipse\plugins\org.jboss. ide.eclipse.core\src\main\org\jboss\ide\eclipse\core\AbstractPlugin.java      [java]     [javac]  (at line 0)      [java]     [javac]         /*      [java]     [javac]         ^      [java]     [javac] The type org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Shell cannot be resolve d. It is indirectly referenced from required .class files      [java]     [javac] ----------      [java]     [javac] 2. ERROR in C:\jbosside-build\eclipse\plugins\org.jboss. ide.eclipse.core\src\main\org\jboss\ide\eclipse\core\AbstractPlugin.java      [java]     [javac]  (at line 21)      [java]     [javac]         import org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Display;      [java]     [javac]                ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^      [java]     [javac] The import org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Display cannot be res olved      [java]     [javac] ----------      [java]     [javac] 2 problems (2 errors)      [java]     [javac] Compilation failed. Compiler errors are available in C:\ jbosside-build\eclipse\plugins\org.jboss.ide.eclipse.core\temp.folder\org-jboss- ide-eclipse-core.jar.bin.log  The odd thing is that this plugin (org.jboss.ide.eclipse.core) lists org.eclipse.ui as one of it's dependencies. Why would the build be unable to find SWT classes? It should be noted that we have copied GEF's method of downloading/extracting eclipse as our main build directory, so therefore all of our dependant plugins etc are living in ${buildDirector}/plugins.  Does this have anything to do with the new JAR-based plugin system? This is a build running from a clean install of 3.1RC1 on Windows XP in a dos command prompt.

title: [readme] problems when exporting plugins from various drive
desc: We need to readme the problems from bug #86020
